PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Commercial Sponsorship
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate of the Commonwealth Parliament assembled.
The petition of these residents of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:
that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation provides the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia with the only nation-wide, independent radio and television service;
that the independence of the Australian Broadcas-ting Corporation must be preserved in the interests of the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia;
that the introduction of commercial sponsorship or any form of advertising material from commercial sources, would destroy the independence of the Corporation.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the honourable senators will oppose the introduction of any form of sponsorship or advertising material from commercial sources into the programmes of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Public Order in the Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows that:
There is widespread concern at the increasing breakdown of public order in the A.C.T..
This breakdown is shown by the recent increase in reports of violent assault-one of which concerned the tragic death of a young man at a school fete.
The involvement of groups of youths in some of these assaults causes particular concern.
Such behaviour is affected by the ready availability, to young people, of alcohol and video and films which depict extreme violence.
Your petitioners therefore ask the Parliament to:
make unlawful the creation of a public nuisance by loitering;
ensure the enforcement of laws which prohibit the public consumption of alcohol by under-age persons, and
legislate to restrict the production, distribution and sale of material which depicts extreme violence.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Harradine (from 138 citizens), Newman (from 144 citizens) and Puplick (from 132 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned expresses concern that some scientists in Australia are intent on underta-king destructive experimentation on human embryos. This subject was examined exhaustively by the 1985-86 Senate Select Committee on Senator Harradine's Human Embryo Experimentation Bill, which received 270 submissions and more than 2,000 pages of evidence. The report of the Senate Committee recommended in October 1986 that the Commonwealth Government make unlawful any destructive experiment which frustrated the development of the human embryo.
Your petitioners therefore request the Senate and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to:
implement without delay the major recommendation of the Senate Select Committee to outlaw destructive experiments on human embryos.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Archer (from 202 citizens), Harradine (from 119 citizens) and Newman (from 255 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the President and senators in Parliament assembled.

Your humble petitioners showeth that the proposed Australia Card will have a dramatic impact on the lives of all Australians, and your petitioners therefore request a national referendum on the Australia Card Bill before the proposal is resubmitted to Parliament.
As in duty bound, your petitioners will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the proposed national ID Card and numbering system threatens the privacy of law-abiding Australians opening the door to computer matching of personal information will cause inconvenience to rural people in particular, and will result in massive compliance costs for private business.

That the Joint Parliamentary Select Committee Report of 1986 showed that the Australia Card will not be effective in combating taxation and social security fraud and illegal immigration, as its cost savings are based on faulty estimates.
That accordingly the Senate and Parliament should reject the Australia Card Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that the proposed Australia Card is an intrusion into the rights of the individual in a free and democratic country.
Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Government not proceed with this legislation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND GOVERNMENT OPERATIONS

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Government Response to Report on Non-statutory Bodies

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard paper No. 1, which is the Government response to the report on non-statutory bodies of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

The Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations tabled its report on non-statutory bodies in August 1986. The report looked at that large and diverse class of Commonwealth bodies which are neither departments nor statutory authorities. It was based on a survey conducted by the Committee, which found that some information about some non-statutory bodies was difficult to obtain or quite unobtainable.

The Committee's principal recommendation was that a central register of non-statutory bodies be established and maintained by a co-ordinating department, such as the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. Section 8 of the Freedom of Information Act already requires Ministers to publish statements about certain agencies for which they are responsible, either in the agencies' or in departments annual reports. The Government has decided, instead of having a separate register established, to require that information regarding NSBs be provided in annual reports either of NSBs themselves or of their parent bodies. The information will include some already required under the FOI Act, plus additional information. This decision meets the Government's concern to streamline and devolve administrative functions, while also responding to the Committee's concerns by ensuring that public sector accountability extends to the activities of NSBs.

Other recommendations of the Committee relate to the kinds of information to be made available and the need for Ministerial and administrative supervision. In considering these secondary recommendations the Government has sought to avoid imposing a large administrative burden on non-statutory bodies and their parent bodies. As a result, while the Government accepts most of these recommendations, some have been modified.
The modifications are set out in the attached Schedule of Recommendations and Responses.
SCHEDULE OF RECOMMENDATIONS AND RESPONSES

Recommendation 1: The Committee recommends that, for each NSB and each NSB sub-body, a document be prepared briefly outlining essential data and that the relevant Minister be responsible for lodging the document with a co-ordinating department such as the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, to form a central NSB register. The Committee further recommends that the register be completely established by 30 June 1987 and thereafter be continuously updated.

Response: The Government has decided, instead of having a separate register established, to require that information regarding NSBs be provided in annual reports either of NSBs themselves (more than one report may be published in a volume) or of their parent bodies, as the respective ministers decide.

Bodies about which information will be required are those consisting of one or more members, serviced wholly or partly at Commonwealth expense (either employing staff of their own or receiving regular secretariat support from staff of parent bodies), other than bodies of the following kinds:
statutory authorities
Offices supporting statutory office holders
sub-bodies of statutory authorities created pursuant to legislation providing for the creation of such bodies.
government companies
departments or parts of departments
inter-departmental committees
Royal Commissions
bodies created for fixed periods of less than 12 months
Commonwealth/State consultative bodies with high level ex-officio membership only
bodies established as integral parts of labour market programs administered by DEET or jointly with State Governments
bodies consisting of departmental officers and representatives of one outside organisation.

The exceptions listed above are intended not to qualify the Government's commitment to public sector accountability, but to provide for cases where other forms of reporting are more appropriate (and to avoid duplication of existing reporting requirements).
The kinds of information to be included in annual reports are set out below in the Government's responses to other recommendations of the Committee.
Recommendation 2: The Committee recommends that the date of establishment of an NSB be recorded in the document in the central NSB register.

Response: The Government agrees that information provided in annual reports should include the dates of establishment of new NSBs. In relation to existing NSBs, information regarding dates of establishment should be included in as much detail as is available.

Recommendation 3: The Committee recommends that in future no NSB be established without ministerial approval so as to ensure full ministerial knowledge and responsibility even when the establishment of an NSB is not a ministerial initiative.

Response: The Government agrees that information provided regarding each NSB should include an indication that the NSB was created or continues to exist (according to whether it is a new or existing NSB) with Ministerial approval. The NSB's functions and organisation should also be subject to Ministerial approval.

Recommendation 4: The Committee recommends that a date of termination of an NSB, or a period of time by which there must be a specific review of it, be included in the document in the central NSB register.

Response: The Government agrees that annual reports be required to show the date on which each NSB will cease to exist or before which it will be reviewed (whichever is the earlier). Reviews should be conducted every 3-5 years; they should address the need for the NSB's continued existence, and, if there is a continuing need for the NSB, its functions and organisation. The outcome of any review that recommends the continuation of an NSB should be submitted for Ministerial endorsement and, if that is obtained, recorded in the next annual report.
Recommendation 5: The Committee recommends that clear objectives be established for each NSB and that those objectives be included in the document in the central NSB register.
Response: The Government agrees that annual reports be required to show each NSB's objectives and functions.

Recommendation 6: The Committee recommends that the chairperson/members of an NSB should not be appointed for an indefinite period but that their terms of office be specified and recorded in the document in the central NSB register.

Response: The Government agrees that annual reports be required to show, in relation to each NSB, any positions provided for ex-officio government members, any for representatives nominated by particular non-government organisations and, in relation to other positions, the maximum terms of appointment. Except where there may be little or no continuity of membership from one meeting to the next, the names of individual members and their terms of appointment should also be shown.

Recommendation 7: The Committee recommends that guidelines for the selection of members of an NSB and a statement of their duties/responsibilities be determined and recorded in the central NSB register at the time of establishment of the NSB.

Response: The Government considers that the criteria for selection of NSB members and the nature of members' duties/responsibilities can best be indicated by information to be included in annual reports regarding the objectives and functions of NSBs (see response to recommendation 5) and the bases of appointments (see response to recommendation 6). It should also be noted that the Government reaffirms the application of the merit principle in the selection of people for appointment to NSBs (see response to recommendation 9).
Recommendation 8: The Committee recommends that NSBs take advantage of new communications technologies such as telephone conferencing to reduce costs.

Response: The Government agrees that NSBs should take advantage of new communications technologies such as telephone conferencing, wherever savings can appropriately be achieved by these means. Ministers have been asked to direct NSBs and/or parent bodies in their portfolios to ensure that the best possible use is made of technological developments. It may be appropriate for such use to be recorded in annual reports.

Recommendation 9: The Committee recommends that Ministers urgently examine the marked difference between the numbers of female and male NSB members and make an increased effort towards redressing the imbalance.

Response: The Government agrees that there is a need to redress the imbalance between the numbers of male and female NSB members. It also intends to seek adequate representation of Aboriginals and people of non-English-speaking backgrounds on NSBs. Ministers have been asked to ensure the application of the merit principle in the selection of people for appointment to NSBs in their portfolios. They have been reminded that the Office of the Status of Women maintains a register of women suitably qualified for appointment to statutory and other bodies, and that a similar register in respect of people of non-English-speaking backgrounds is being established by the Office of Multicultural Affairs.

Recommendation 10: The Committee recommends that Ministers review the status of NSBs which have not met for an extended period and review all NSBs with a view of rationalising the number and work of NSBs.

Response: The Government has agreed that the existence, functions and organisation of NSBs shall require Ministerial endorsement (see response to recommendation 3) and regular re-endorsement (see response to recommendation 4). Ministers have been asked to ensure that the review process involved in meeting those requirements includes a review of the status of NSBs which have not met for periods longer than 12 months and a review of the scope for rationalising the number and work of NSBs.

Recommendation 11: The Committee recommends that the Department of Finance initiate, and each NSB adopt, a financial system to ensure that adequate accounting standards and procedures are maintained and so that accurate financial information for each NSB is available.

Response: The Government agrees that all receipts and expenditures of NSBs be recorded. The Committee's report indicates that some existing NSBs maintain their own accounts. In the case of these bodies and any new NSBs which establish their own accounting systems, it is the reponsibility of the respective Ministers (in consultation as necessary with the Minister for Finance) to ensure that accounting standards and procedures are adequate. Annual reports of these bodies' activities are to include audited financial statements.

In the case of NSBs that operate through their parent bodies' accounts, the Government has decided that their activities should be incorporated in the program statements given in parent bodies' annual reports, so that receipts and expenditures are accounted for and reported on a program basis. Standard program budgeting techniques are to be adopted with performance related to objectives (see response to recommendation 5) and measured in terms of stated criteria.
Recommendation 12: The Committee recommends that the remuneration arrangements for an NSB be specified in the document in the central NSB register.
Response: The Government agrees that annual reports be required to show how the level of remuneration (if any) paid to members of each NSB is determined.

Recommendation 13: The Committee recommends that Ministers determine clear financial arrangements (including sources of funding and expenditure) for each NSB and record those arrangements in the document in the central NSB register.

Response: The Government agrees that Ministers be required to determine and annual reports to show how each NSB is funded. In addition, information should be provided regarding other financial arrangements (also to be determined by Ministers) such as the kinds of expenditure that can be made from the funds provided, and the nature of secretariat services provided and the way these are funded.

Recommendation 14: The Committee recommends that if an NSB is to be responsible for distributing funds to other organisations or individuals, this is included in the document in the central NSB register.

Response: The Government agrees that annual reports be required to show, in relation to each NSB, whether one of the NSB's functions is to distribute funds to other organisations of individuals. The amounts of each grant should also be shown in statements of the NSB's financial activities provided in the respective annual report.

Recommendation 15: While the Committee believes it would be preferable for the Auditor-General to audit the accounts of all Government companies, the Committee recommends that where the accounts of Government companies are audited by private auditors, the applicable standards followed must be those approved by the Auditor-General.

Response: Government companies are not covered by the requirements relating to NSBs. Consideration is currently being given to arrangements for implementing the guidelines for statutory authorities and government business enterprises announced by the Minister for Finance on 4 November 1987. Audit arrangements are being considered in the context of this exercise.

Recommendation 16: The Committee recommends that, in general, an NSB should be accountable and that for each NSB the form of its reporting and the interval of time between reports should be specified in the document in the central NSB register.

Response: The Government has agreed that an account of each NSB's activities should be provided either in an annual report of its own (or in a volume containing several NSB reports) or in the parent body's annual report. Parent bodies, in their annual reports, should list any NSBs of theirs which produce their own annual reports, showing to whom they are presented and whether they are tabled in the Parliament or made public in some other way.
Recommendation 17: The Committee recommends that Ministers ensure that sufficient resources are provided so that each NSB can report adequately on its activities to the Parliament and the public.

Response: The Government considers its decisions regarding NSBs to be one element in its broader range of measures to improve public sector accountability. It would expect the financial reporting requirements in respect of NSBs to be met from resources already allocated for the introduction of program budgeting. With regard to other reporting requirements, the Government has been concerned to ensure accountability without substantially adding to the burden on resources. Any application for increased resources to meet the requirements of providing information for annual reports would be closely scrutinised.
Recommendation 18: The Committee recommends that there be adequate procedures for recording minutes of all NSB meetings and that each NSB consider whether its minutes should be publicly available.

Response: The Government considers that NSBs which are operating efficiently with informal procedures should not be required to adopt rigidly structured procedures. The requirement to provide information in annual reports, together with the provisions of the FOI Act, should ensure adequate accountability.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Has the Government set in train the tendering process for the letting of a new long term coastwatch contract? Bearing in mind the fiasco of the last tender process, part of which was blamed on the Christmas-New Year holiday shut-down in the Public Service, can he now assure the Senate that a new contractor will be selected by the time the temporary arrangement with Skywest Airlines Pty Ltd expires in March? If not, is it the Government's intention to extend indefinitely Skywest's interim contract? When will the Government finally get in place a new long term coastwatch contract of a standard which it so disastrously attempted to do earlier this year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I answered a question on this, I think, in the course of the Senate Estimates committee debate, and I really do not have anything to add to what I said on that occasion, which is that the tendering request for the new contract has not yet been formally issued, but it is the subject of very active consideration at the moment. The difficulty is that it has become apparent that within the sponsoring department, the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, there has been in train for some time now a review on the quarantine enforcement issue which has raised questions as to whether or not there should be a renewal of the coastwatch contract on exactly the same terms as previously, or whether there should rather be some amendment to the quarantine enforcement and coastwatch regime that is applicable. That has given rise to a tricky question as to just how long the present Skywest contract should be sought to be extended while that obviously important threshold policy question is resolved. I would expect the whole question to be resolved within a very short time and some clear guidance to be given to Skywest, which of course has the major interest in this as the continuing contractor for the present, but also in order that the situation can be put on a proper footing.

ANSWER.PARA: There are and always have been quite complex issues involved in devising the best-the most cost efficient and the most effective-regime for the coastwatch function. Those questions continue to demand careful attention by the Government, and they will be given that attention and will be resolved before we leap into any ad hoc further process of extension of the existing contract.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. It is quite clear from that answer that the Government is not about to leap into anything. In view of the temporary nature-as I understand it, until March only- of the current Skywest extension, can the Minister say whether Skywest is prepared indefinitely to carry on until this now totally laborious and probably equally disastrous exercise is completed by the Minister?

—Senator Durack always used to tell me, when he was in government and I was in opposition, that he could not be too cautious about these matters of high policy and public administration, and I have taken an appropriate leaf out of his book. In light of the difficulties which have attended this contract, obviously each step along the way is being looked at very carefully indeed in order to ensure that the best possible value is received for the public dollar in the future, in a way that unfortunately was never able to be guaranteed to be the case during his tenure of various portfolios when these sorts of matters were in issue.
—Come off it! Why don't you do your job occasionally and stop looking after your mates? Have you ever heard of the public interest?

—I am entitled, in the spirit of Christmas, to make the odd gesture of this kind when I am challenged with indolence from the grand master in that particular discipline on the Opposition benches. There has been no unwillingness to come to grips with this issue. Of course, I acknowledge that the present contract cannot be extended indefinitely. Of course, the matter will have to be resolved very quickly. Of course, it is a very high priority for me and the Government, and we are giving it attention accordingly.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an article appearing in this morning's Melbourne Age newspaper headlined `Individuals set tax example'? Does the Minister agree with the comments attributed to the Commissioner of Taxation, Mr Boucher, regarding the need for tax compliance in the company tax area to be improved in line with the improvements now evident in the personal tax area? Is this a matter of great importance for macroeconomic policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the article. The matter certainly is very important in regard to macroeconomic policy. The article reports Mr Boucher as saying:

ANSWER.PARA: We make no apology for intensifying business audit activities . . . Last year, audits of 58 companies with annual turnovers in excess of $100m yielded $2.7m per company. Only nine of these companies were found to have a clean bill of tax health.
The article further states:
Companies should follow the improved behaviour of individual taxpayers in complying with income tax law, the tax commissioner, Mr Trevor Boucher, said yesterday.

That view is endorsed by the Treasurer and the Government. Companies have an obligation to comply not only with the income tax law but also with the other more general provisions of the Companies Act. This was the subject of a question answered by me in the Senate on 5 November regarding Senator Stone having been listed as at that date as a director of a company called Lartron Pty Ltd. Senator Stone, quite unjustifiably, took offence and made a personal explanation, even though I had made it perfectly clear, to quote myself, that `Senator Stone might wish the management of that company to correct that oversight'-that is, his still being listed as a director.

I am advised that Senator Stone, as of 8 December, is still listed as a director of that company. Clearly, the company is in breach of section 238 (7) of the Companies Act. It may have gone into receivership. That is a possibility. But as the company is, apparently, too negligent to comply with its obligations under the Companies Act, and as there are people who do know that this issue has been raised in the Senate and that Senator Stone informed the Senate that he resigned, as he put it, in either January or February of this year, Senator Stone might wish to draw the attention of the management of the company to the oversight and to its obligations, both to him in a moral sense and to comply with the law.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Transport and Communications: Is it true that the planes presently used by Skywest Airlines Pty Ltd for coastal surveillance failed to satisfy the more stringent requirements of the recent coastwatch contract tender won by Amann Aviation Pty Ltd? For instance, is it a fact that the Skywest aircraft are fitted with bubble windows which give inferior visibility compared with the windows stipulated in the defunct Amann contract? Is it true that the same planes are now being used by Skywest under its current short term contract to perform coastwatch services? If so, does this not mean that, by its own standards, the Government is now mounting a second-rate surveillance operation along Australia's northern coastline?

—My recollection is that it is the case that the continuation of the contract is pursuant to the previous terms and conditions rather than to those spelt out in the request for tender for which Amann was the successful contractor. Accordingly, there are some variations in the physical conditions in the two contracts. My further understanding, however, is that the particular specifications for the location of bubble windows and the degree of vision that is accessible through those windows have been enhanced under the current contract. Nonetheless, under the previous contract there is no effective inhibition on the capacity of the observers to perform their task. If there had been any question of an inability of the previous contractor to perform the tasks given it, it is a question which would have arisen during the currency of the previous contract and not just during the present term of extension. There is no doubt that there are a number of improvements built into the present contract, but there is no basis that I am aware of for any imputation that the basic task is being any less well performed as a result.
—I seek leave to table the list of deficiencies of Skywest aircraft.
—I table the document.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Government received any advice recently on the wisdom of implementing a consumption tax? What is the nature of this advice and will the Government be accepting it and acting upon it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has been getting advice from all over the place about the question of a consumption tax. For example, a National Party member of parliament, Mr Michael Cobb, who I understand is the secretary of the coalition's treasury and finance committee, has come out favouring a consumption tax at a flat rate in replacement of the present wholesale tax, which is levied at different rates. Last week we had some advice about the efficacy and appropriateness of introducing a broad-based consumption tax from a more traditional source of advice to the Government, Senator Stone. In his weekly column, while giving a few plaudits to the `Joh for PM' campaign, from which Senator Stone ultimately came into the Senate, he noted that the `Joh for PM' campaign had:

ANSWER.PARA: Put paid to notions then current in the conservative camp in favour of a broadly based consumption tax.

That notion is apparently presently being revived by one of Senator Stone's National Party colleagues, Mr Cobb. The next morning we found that the reason Senator Stone believed it was so necessary not to have a broadly based consumption tax was that a coalition government could not be trusted. I am sure not many people would disagree with him about that. In the Sydney Morning Herald of last Thursday, Senator Stone was quoted as saying:

In an interview with the Herald, Senator Stone said: `I support a consumption tax in principle, but I simply have said that until we get this big government in Canberra straightened out, there is no room for increasing taxes or introducing new taxes-especially new taxes.
The big job of the next government is to cut spending.
The report continues:
Asked if this meant that a Coalition Government, of which he would be a senior member, could not be trusted to resist using a new tax as a substitute for spending cuts, he replied: `That's right.'
He is also quoted as saying:
It hasn't a ghost of a chance-
that is, a broad-based consumption tax-
it is bad economics and bad politics.
In an interview on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's AM program the next morning, Senator Stone said:
I'm simply saying that to have a broad-based consumption tax would be so crazy that no sensible person would be part of it.
On the same program he was asked what he would do if, subsequent to the coalition's review of its tax policy, it adopted a proposal for a broadly based consumption tax. He said:
. . . I wouldn't, of course, in that case be in the coalition.

In the space of 24 hours we had Senator Stone saying that a broad-based consumption tax was `bad economics and bad politics' and `so crazy that no sensible person would be part of it', in spite of the fact that he supports a consumption tax in principle. The Government is not suffering from any shortage of advice on the question of whether there should be a consumption tax, but most of the advice comes from within the National Party. It is highly confused, highly contradictory and difficult to make any sense of at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. It concerns the decision of a Cabinet committee, chaired by the Prime Minister, to dispatch Australian military forces to the Persian Gulf war. Is it not a fact that the Australian Government made its decision without requesting or receiving a formal written request from President Reagan for Australian involvement in the Gulf war? Is it also not a fact that the Prime Minister, despite advice from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, declined an offer from the American Secretary of State, Mr George Shultz, for the American Administration to put in writing its request to the Australian Government? Will the Minister give an undertaking that, should any written request from President Reagan for Australia's involvement in the Gulf finally arrive, it will be tabled in Parliament?

—I will refer the specifics of that question as to the tabling of letters, hypothetical and otherwise, to the Prime Minister, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and the Minister for Defence and see what responses they care to make. On the larger issue, while it is true that yesterday the Government discussed the possible deployment of a Royal Australian Navy diving and clearance team to the Persian Gulf, this matter remains under consideration. The decision whether to deploy a team of Navy divers will be guided by a number of considerations-our desire to maintain a strictly even-handed policy on the Iran-Iraq war, our commitment to the principle of freedom of navigation in the Gulf, our desire to maintain good relations with the nations of the region and our support for efforts by the United Nations Secretary-General to bring an end to the conflict. The Government's clear and continuing commitment to neutrality in the war and our support for the basic principles of international conduct being equally applicable to all countries in the region are not changed by the present consideration of the deployment of divers to the Gulf.

—Is the Minister for Home Affairs aware that, during the extraordinary sitting of the Queensland Parliament last Wednesday, the National Party member for Broadsound used the veil of parliamentary privilege to attack the Australian Electoral Commission? Can the Minister comment on Mr Hinton's allegations of political pressure within the Electoral Commission in connection with his prosecution and conviction under charges arising from the Commonwealth Electoral Act?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Hinton was reported in last Thursday's newspapers as telling the Queensland Parliament the following:

ANSWER.PARA: I also put to the House that the timing of events and obvious political pressure applied to the Commonwealth Electoral Office and subsequently by that Office must lead one to seriously question the independence and neutrality of that organisation.

If I have any complaint, it is that the Electoral Commission was absolutely and without question totally fair in this matter. The Deputy Electoral Commissioner wrote to the Australian Federal Police in Queensland on 9 September 1986. In that letter the Electoral Commission advised:
In order to avoid allegations of party political bias, the investigation would need to be concluded before the announcement of the Queensland State election or left until after polling day.

On 12 September the Acting Chief Superintendent of the Criminal Investigation Department of the Federal Police indicated that there would be a delay. Accordingly, the investigation was left until after the Queensland State elections in 1986. Mr Hinton also apparently finds something suspicious in the fact that the summons in this case was issued a few days after the 11 July Federal election. The Federal Police wrote to the Electoral Commission on 6 July 1987 indicating that its investigation had concluded and it was awaiting advice from the Director of Public Prosecutions in Brisbane regarding a prosecution. A complainant summons was issued by that Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions on 13 July-the Monday following the Federal election. There is no doubt that the Electoral Commission and the Federal Police acted with political impartiality. I, for one, would have very much enjoyed Mr Hinton being charged a few days before the Federal election. I would have, fairly cynically, made some political capital out of the fact. But the Electoral Commission and the Federal Police did not take that course; they acted with absolute integrity, which is more than I can say for Mr Hinton.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Did the Government receive a report that a person named Spiridon Apokis was or had been a director of Continental Venture Capital-the company which financed Amann Aviation's purchase of aircraft for the coastwatch contract? Who prepared that report, which I understand was totally without foundation, and on whose information was it based? Did the Government investigate allegations that directors of Amann or Continental Venture Capital were drug users or drug smugglers? Will the Minister confirm that such allegations are totally baseless?

—I cannot recall, without checking the file, whether anyone of the name that Senator Knowles mentioned was the subject of any specific allegation or investigation. I will need to check that. My clear recollection is that a whole variety of allegations were made about people associated with the company and were referred to the Australian Federal Police. They were the subject of checking and the subject of conclusions that there was no foundation for any such belief. That was certainly true in the context of the allegations that I can remember having been made about drug trafficking and so on. Whether it is true of the allegation that may have been made about the person to whom Senator Knowles referred I do not know, and I will have to take that on notice. I will give her an answer as soon as possible within the next day or two.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to the proposed meeting between the leaders of the United States of America and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. I ask: What is the Government's assessment of the likely outcome of the forthcoming meeting in Washington between President Reagan and General Secretary Gorbachev?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think our assessment is that the treaty is likely to be signed. My brief states that the Australian Government warmly welcomes the decision of the United States of America (USA) and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics to sign a treaty, which I assume they will consummate in the next day or so, which will eliminate all their intermediate-range nuclear weapons. This intermediate-range nuclear forces (INF) treaty will be signed by President Reagan and General Secretary Gorbachev at the meeting taking place in Washington over the period from yesterday to 10 December. While INF weapons do not constitute a large proportion of the global nuclear arsenal, this agreement will create an historic precedent because it is the first agreement to eliminate a complete class of nuclear weapons and to reduce overall nuclear arsenals. The agreement is particularly welcomed in Australia because it includes systems deployed in Asia as well as in Europe. Although in terms of the overall number of nuclear weapons the percentage of weapons reduced is small, the number is still substantial, involving about 1,900 Soviet and 850 United States missiles deployed or held in reserves or in stocks. However, these measures should not be looked at in isolation. They are important indications of the improvements that are taking place in USA-Soviet relations. They both reflect and contribute to greater confidence and trust in each other. This in turn enhances greater faith in their own security, which improves the prospect of further arms reductions in the future.

ANSWER.PARA: One of the really important achievements of the INF treaty, and the one which I think that Australia is keenest of all to applaud, is the advances that it did make in the very difficult area of verification. Disarmament and security cannot be treated in isolation. The Australian Government very much welcomes the progress which the United States and the Soviet Union have made in building the confidence required through their progress on verification arrangements. It is the Australian Government's hope that the INF agreement will stimulate progress in other areas of arms control, particularly of the kind that we have been pursuing through multilateral organisations and forums. In particular, we hope that it will encourage the two sides to negotiate a strategic arms reduction treaty to make large stabilising and verifiable cuts in Soviet and American strategic nuclear weapons.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Attorney-General aware that Mr Justice O'Bryan of the Victorian Supreme Court in his decision of 4 December was severely critical of the Government for hiding behind the statute of limitations in its defence against compensation claims by HMAS Voyager survivors? In particular, I draw the Minister's attention to a comment by Mr Justice O'Bryan, who said:

QUESTION.PARA: This ruling is most unfortunate and reflects poorly upon the conduct of the defendant.

That is, the Government. Why has the Government acted in this cowardly and despicable manner, given that it had previously admitted liability for injuries suffered by at least six Victorian survivors and that in 1985 it had repeatedly agreed to waive the statute of limitations for compensation claims? Why is the Government denying natural justice to more that 100 survivors of the Voyager disaster in their proper and just claims for compensation? Will the Government urgently reconsider its position on the compensation claims and settle all the outstanding matters in a fair and equitable manner?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator McGauran for his question. I understand that notice was given of a motion covering much the same ground. Therefore, I will not engage in the debate, which I might otherwise be tempted to do, because the opportunity will no doubt arise as a result of the motion. The fact is that the HMAS Melbourne-HMAS Voyager collision took place on 10 February 1964, according to my brief, which is more than 23 years ago. The general principle invoked is that the Commonwealth should not now be presented with new claims unless there is a very good reason for the delay. Members of the Melbourne and Voyager crews, of course, were aware in 1964 that claims could be lodged against the Commonwealth. In 1964 there were 60 claims by dependants of deceased members and 232 claims for loss of kit and personal effects. Four actions against the Commonwealth had been commenced and there were three notices of intended action. The then Attorney-General publicly stated in Parliament his view that the High Court of Australia had jurisdiction to deal with such claims.

ANSWER.PARA: There comes a time when matters are stale and fall within the possibility of being covered by the statute of limitations. I am sure that Senator Durack would know that attorneys on all sides of politics in various jurisdictions have decided to take advantage of the statute of limitations, which of course is available.

TALK.START.PARA: —Then why did you admit liability?

—Well, I am quite sure that Senator Durack invoked it at various times during his illustrious holding of that august office. As a result of the delay over 23 years, the Commonwealth has suffered prejudice in defending the recent claims and has pleaded the statute of limitations in accordance with long-standing policy of Attorneys-General. When initially acting on the basis that the above defences would not be pleaded, officials were relying on the then Government's decision in 1964. After careful consideration the Attorney-General decided, for the reasons I have given, that that decision should no longer be relied on and the Commonwealth was granted leave by the Court to amend its defences.

ANSWER.PARA: In answer to Senator McGauran, I have not read in detail the judgment of Mr Justice O'Bryan in the Supreme Court of Victoria, although His Honour, of course, did decide that the Commonwealth had not waived the defence and was not estopped from pleading that defence. No criticism was made by the Victorian Supreme Court in earlier stages of the matter, such as before the Master and Mr Justice Vincent. Nevertheless, criticisms were made by Mr Justice O'Bryan. But, of course, it is for the Executive Government, in reliance on the statute of limitations, to make these decisions, and the decision was taken in accordance with long-standing practice and policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Special Minister of State as Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women. In the Budget the Government allocated $1.6m to a campaign against domestic violence. In the light of the Victorian legislation introduced last week and the South Australian Government's announcement last week about domestic violence, can the Minister say at what stage the Federal campaign is, and how it does or will fit with the State initiatives?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the case that the Government decided at the time of the last election to respond to the very widespread concern expressed by women from all kinds of backgrounds about the incidence of domestic violence in our community. Although law enforcement and legal controls over violent partners in these cases is a matter for the States, the Commonwealth believes it is appropriate that we try to offer the community some assistance in reducing the incidence of these tragic events. Consequently, we have allocated a $1.6m appropriation for an education campaign aimed, first of all, at raising within the community a consciousness of the extent of the problem and then at providing, particularly for the victims but also for the potential perpetrators of domestic violence, information that may be of assistance to them.

ANSWER.PARA: Agencies were invited to submit proposals to undertake market research as the initial stage in developing the campaign. That research is about to be commissioned. The campaign will have three overall objectives: to increase community awareness that domestic violence is a criminal offence; to inform victims of the options that are available; and-of course, the most difficult and most important thing to do-to change community attitudes towards domestic violence. The Prime Minister has written to State Premiers, the Northern Territory Chief Minister and the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories seeking their support in conducting the campaign on a co-operative basis so as to complement the excellent work already undertaken, including the recent legislative changes referred to in Senator Crowley's question, by the States.

Further, we will seek their nominations for a national co-ordinating task force. There is no doubt that the work already undertaken by the States and Territories makes a wider-ranging multifaceted campaign timely. Of course-I know that this is something Senator Crowley will be particularly interested in-the project will include measures appropriate to all cultural groups, including Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TEXTILES, CLOTHING AND FOOTWEAR INDUSTRIES PLAN

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, is about the sectoral plan for the textiles, clothing and footwear industries initially announced by the Minister in a Press release late last year and expanded by him shortly prior to the last election. Does the Minister recall claiming in the Senate that the first principle which guided the Government `during its consideration of an appropriate future strategy for these industries' was that predictability and stability of policy would be essential in such complex industries if they are to restructure and rationalise operations? In view of the Minister's answer to my question yesterday, will he now give the Senate and these industries an undertaking that the Government will abide by the terms of the plan which he announced?

—It is inevitable that, in the life of a plan in which continuity and predictability are seen as major objectives, there will be adjustments and changes along the way. For example, Senator Lewis will know that that has happened in respect of the motor vehicle plan, which it was announced could operate for a period of years. There have been substantial adjustments in the course of that plan.
—The plan hasn't started yet.

—Just a minute; let me finish. I am trying to answer the honourable senator's question. No doubt, during the course of the textiles, clothing and footwear plan, adjustments will be made. So the answer to the honourable senator's question is that there may well be adjustments to the plan, but the essential elements will be maintained.

—My question is addressed to the Special Minister of State in her capacity as Minister responsible for the drug offensive. Can the Minister inform the Senate whether the Government has, as part of the national campaign against drug abuse, set in motion any programs explaining the dangers of tranquilliser abuse? Is it a fact that more than 70 per cent of tranquillisers are issued to women and that a large percentage of these are migrant women? Finally, are any measures proposed to reduce the rate of prescribing these drugs for women?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a distressing fact that, of tranquillisers prescribed in Australia, over 70 per cent are prescribed for women and, within that group, the majority of recipients of tranquilliser prescriptions are migrant women. In some ways, I suppose that that is understandable. It is understandable that migrant women seek the assistance that they believe-often wrongly-that tranquillisers can provide them, because migrant women are faced with even more pressures than are other women in our society. Often they find themselves working in blue collar occupations and being subjected to a lot of physical and psychological stress. Usually they have the complete responsibility for the management of their household. They have to deal with cultural and generation conflicts. Often their children have a different attitude to the home culture from that of the women themselves and their husbands. If they experience marital or family difficulties, as of course many women do, often they are isolated from an extended family network or from close friends who could give them the kind of support that they need. Consequently, they seek some sort of assistance from tranquillisers. The problem is a very great one because, in many cases, they do not understand how to use the tranquillisers safely and, in their somewhat desperate circumstances, they are very susceptible to overdosing on the tranquillisers, which aggravates their problems enormously and does not provide them with any assistance at all.

ANSWER.PARA: In recognition of this fact, our Government made available a grant to the Leichhardt Women's Community Health Centre to develop a video which would warn migrant women of the dangers of tranquilliser abuse and to assist them to see that there are much safer alternatives available which will assist them through difficult periods. The video was also supported by the New South Wales Department of Health, with a grant of $10,000, and there was a grant of $18,205 from our drug offensive. I had the opportunity to launch the video, called Medicina Amara, at the Leichhardt town hall last week with the migrant women who had made it themselves. I must say to honourable senators who are interested in this very serious problem in our community that it is an excellent resource for any health or community workers working with migrant women. The video is available in Spanish, Italian, Polish and Turkish, with English subtitles, and it has been produced in a multicultural version, using all four languages, which is suitable for television. The video will be circulated to hospitals, health centres and rehabilitation centres for loan, free of charge, or it can be bought for $35,000 from the Leichhardt Women's Community Health Centre.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sorry, I meant $35. I can see Senator Puplick getting into another Estimates committee phase. I think $35 is a very reasonable price for those who can afford to pay it. This is a most practical and informative video and it addresses a very serious problem among our female migrant communities. I hope that those honourable senators who have health centres in their communities or who have particularly close relationships with the ethnic communities-as I know some honourable senators do-will avail themselves of this very important resource to help migrant women through these difficult problems.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer the Minister to recent reports of a proposed joint venture in the Soviet Union for an aluminium plant-I think a refinery-near Vladivostok and to remarks attributed to the Prime Minister that under the arrangements he made recently there will be a two-year tax holiday for this new investment, a 30 per cent tax on repatriated profits only and no tax on re-invested profits in Russia. I ask the Minister: Does this mean that Australian participant companies will not have to pay tax on foreign profits earned in this sort of joint venture? If so, why is the Soviet Union being given special consideration compared with the rest of the world? If not, what would be the advantage to the Australian participating company? When is it expected that this investment will take place?

—I have heard something about a proposal for an aluminium smelter at Vladivostok, but all the other matters that Senator Parer has raised are new to me. I do not have any information on them, and I will see whether I can get an answer.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. Has the Minister seen an article by Professor Blainey in the Australian of 5 December lamenting the fact that discussion on the intake of non-English speakers has slipped from the public agenda since the comments of Senators Sheil and Stone in the Senate on 23 November? Does this reflect a greater tolerance in the Australian community than in sections of this chamber?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The simple answer to Senator Childs's question is yes. While Professor Blainey may be disappointed that the discussion has not taken off in the Australian community as perhaps Senator Sheil and Senator Stone would have liked, I am sure that the majority of Australians are very pleased, for very good reason. The public has more insight, and Australians generally have fewer prejudices, than has Professor Blainey. Professor Blainey writes from a minority point of view and he has very limited understanding of the bipartisan Australian immigration program. The immigration program plays an essential role in economic and social development and population building in Australia. As I advised the Senate on 24 November, the greater proportion of the Government's migration program is directed towards economic benefit and is designed to select skilled migrants to fill labour market needs immediately, business migrants to contribute to economic development and independent and concessional migrants who are immediately employable, young, skilled and educated.

ANSWER.PARA: Selection criteria are designed to ensure immediate economic contribution. Assessing employability has regard to likely language requirements of the specific occupation of employees or employers. These categories account for 52 per cent of this year's migration program. At the same time the Government maintains its commitment to social and humanitarian programs which allow reunion with close family members and entry on refugee and special humanitarian grounds. Entry for these people is under relaxed requirements and in this context it would be quite untenable and, indeed, quite unthinkable to deny people reunion with close family members such as spouse, children or parents or relief from refugee situations or on humanitarian grounds just because of a limited fluency in English. Those without fluent English can possess many other valuable assets and skills obtained without cost to the Australian taxpayer. Furthermore, it is a very misguided view that many of those who are now arriving without fluency in English will not quickly acquire it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment and the Arts. I refer the Minister to his statements in Estimates Committee F hearings on 22 October when he said that some $300,000 had been spent on eight consultancies investigating the effects of World Heritage listing on north Queensland. At that stage he advised that only one consultant's report had been submitted and received, that of the eminent biochemist, Dr Keto, and her non-biased rainforest conservation society! I now ask the Minister whether any of the six socio-economic consultancies appointed have made their reports and, if so, why have they not been made available to members of this Parliament for debate prior to the announcement of the World Heritage boundaries expected this Friday?

—I thank Senator Boswell for his question. We have received preliminary reports from a number of the consultants; we have received final reports from none. They will be received in January. When they are received they will form the basis for a submission on compensation that I shall make to the Cabinet. It would be pretty ridiculous to make submissions on compensation to Cabinet before we had received the results of the consultancies; that would defeat their purpose. However, that does not affect an announcement on the boundaries because the decision to list the wet tropics for World Heritage listing is taken on the basis of their intrinsic heritage value. As Senator Boswell would well know, those magnificent forests definitely have that value and I am sure that next year the World Heritage Committee will accept the nomination.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Would it not be equally ridiculous for the Minister to declare the boundaries without having the reports in his hand?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought that I had answered that question but I will have another try. Apparently the honourable senator needs some assistance on this issue.
—Speak slowly and in one- syllable words.

—Senator Sanders thinks I should use monosyllables. Okay, I will try to answer the question slowly. The decision to list areas for World Heritage listing was not made on economic grounds but on the heritage values of the areas. However, any compensation package for north Queensland must obviously be based on economic grounds. So we are waiting for the socio-economic reports to come in before we make a decision, or, at least a recommendation, on compensation.

ANSWER.PARA: As Senator Boswell well knows, there are other reasons why the compensation package has been delayed. The honourable senator has not been urging the new Premier of Queensland to come to the negotiating table and consult with us on how we can help north Queenslanders. I would have thought that that is exactly what Senator Boswell's job is-and should be. The real worry I have is why the Liberal Party of Australia will not stand up against the National Party; why will Senator Puplick not tell the world where the Liberals stand? I am told that we will have to wait until next August to find out. I think that Senator Puplick should tell us right now; next August is too late.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. I noted her reply a moment ago in relation to the consumption of tranquillisers by migrant women. My question relates to the Port Pirie Education Centre, where there are a large number of migrant people, including migrant women. Is the Minister aware that the Port Pirie Education Centre is to be left unfunded by her Government after December? Is the Minister also aware that the education centre, which has been operating for over 12 years with government support, is now providing an excellent, widely accepted and appreciated service to the people of the Port Pirie region, and has been successful in attracting outside grants? Does the Minister agree that to build up an organisation such as this over that length of time and then to remove its funding is a wasteful way of operating? Will the Minister attempt to provide the $45,000 base grant requested by the Port Pirie Education Centre?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is very well aware of the value of education centres. The education centres were actually set up as a part of the Whitlam Government's Schools Commission program back in the 1970s, and many of them have survived and flourished since that time. There is no questioning of the overall value of education centres, particularly those that operate in rural or isolated areas, as they are able to assist teachers and other people interested in education to get access to better resources. However, in the budgetary constraints of last year's Budget, it was necessary to streamline the education centres program in terms of Commonwealth funding.

ANSWER.PARA: I should point out to Senator Coulter that education centres are able to get funding from a variety of sources. They are able to get funding from other Commonwealth agencies, and often do. They are able to get funding from State education agencies, and often do, and they are also able to take on work from the community, so they are not reliant necessarily on direct funding under the education centres program. The Port Pirie centre has received funding from other sources. For example, in 1987 it received funding from the Commonwealth, under the projects of national significance program, to conduct research concerning the education of girls in rural areas. That was a one-off grant, and it is an example of the capacity of the Port Pirie Education Centre to attract funding from sources other than the education centres program. At this stage, there are no proposals to revive recurrent funding for the Port Pirie centre, although that matter may be considered in next year's Budget. However, the Port Pirie centre is, as I said, able to get funding from other sources. It is incorporated as a community organisation and no doubt will be able to get alternative sources of support.

I should point out in conclusion that there is still a good geographical spread of directly Commonwealth funded education centres. There are other centres in the Iron Triangle which have continued to be funded and the Port Pirie centre, as I said, has been able to get a one-off grant from the Commonwealth Schools Commission. It is well placed to get other smaller kinds of grants in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women and for the Bicentenary. Is the Minister aware that there is only one personal memorial to Captain James Cook located anywhere in Great Britain, namely a family burial monument in the Church of St Andrew the Great in Cambridge? Is she further aware that this memorial is now threatened as a result of a proposal to demolish the church and build a shopping centre? What steps has her Government taken to persuade the British Government, or what steps has it directly taken itself, to ensure the preservation of this monument?

—As far as I am aware, the answer to Senator Puplick's question is none-no steps whatsoever. I am not aware of any, and I am not entirely sure that it would be appropriate for us to take any. After all, if it is a memorial that has been supported by the British authorities, it is up to them whether they continue to support it. I would remind Senator Puplick that the main thrust of the bicentennial program for next year in Australia is a broad-based recognition of the achievements of all the elements of this society-Aboriginal Australia, multicultural Australia and women in Australia. It does not leave out a recognition--
—Men, too? Or do we leave them out?

—I do not know why Senator Walters is interjecting in such a disorderly fashion. After all, the Bicentennial Authority has had the benefit of Senator Walters's presence for some time. She probably knows more detail about what the bicentennial program is about than I. Generally, the thrust of the bicentennial program is not historical, although there are some historical elements in it. The weight of funding for programs is for programs which will benefit the Australian people generally and then various parts of Australia-rural Australia will benefit greatly from the great travelling exhibition, remote Australia will benefit from special programs and so forth. The British Government may have some intentions with regard to the Captain Cook memorial. I will make inquiries about that, but it would not be a matter very high on our Government's agenda.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for her answer, which once again betrays the clear prejudice which this Government has in its Bicentennial program against our British heritage in the foundation of this country. I ask her: As the memorial is not a British Government memorial, and despite the fact that as Minister responsible for the Bicentenary one would have expected her to know something about this significant memorial in Great Britain, is her answer to my previous question to be taken as an indication of the priorities which this Government has as far as the Bicentennial celebrations are concerned, particularly bearing in mind that the saving of this monument by the British Government would not be at any cost to the Australian taxpayer?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had better reply to Senator Puplick's supplementary question, otherwise he will rush out a Press release saying that the Government has placed our British heritage as the lowest possible priority. As that is not the case, I had better point out to Senator Puplick that we have placed on record our appreciation of the British Government's very generous gift to the people of Australia as a bicentennial memento, that is, the Young Endeavour sailing ship which will participate in the tall ships in Sydney Harbour on 26 January. That will be a long term gift to the people of Australia. It will be used to provide sailing experiences for school students, particularly those in disadvantaged circumstances. I am sure that all the students who have the opportunity to enjoy some sailing experiences on the Young Endeavour will be in no doubt either of the fact that it is a gift from the British Government or that it is a gift that is an appropriate recognition of the contribution made by Captain Cook in his voyages of discovery.

ANSWER.PARA: There is also to be a loan from the United Kingdom for exhibition in Australia of the original Act by the British Parliament which set up the Australian Parliament. A facsimile copy of the Act given to us by the British Government will form a part of the travelling exhibition. I have also acknowledged that gift on behalf of the Government. One of the major art exhibitions, the Terra Australis exhibition, will contain a number of accounts of Captain Cook's voyages of discovery and a number of items in recognition of the work of Joseph Banks, the great botanist who accompanied Captain Cook on some of his voyages. So there will be no doubt at all about the historical contribution of British sailors, navigators and botanists to the early settlement and discovery of Australia and our region.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister for the Environment and the Arts advise, as a result of the Nella Dan incident, the full extent of, firstly, any pollution damage in the sub-Antarctic, secondly, the costs to and obligations of the Australian Government to the owners of the vessel and, thirdly, the repercussions for our Antarctic program and the scientific investigations for this season? When can the Senate expect an announcement that an Australian-owned replacement vessel will be acquired?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —All the crew and passengers on the Nella Dan, bar six of the crew and an officer of the Antarctic Division, are now being transported on the Icebird to Hobart and are expected to arrive at 12 o'clock on Friday. The crew remaining will await investigations into the possibility of salvage. However, to go to the various parts of the question-I hope that I got them all down-the first part of the question related to pollution. It is true that some light diesel oil has spilt into the sea. It is of such a nature that it evaporates and dissipates very quickly and, according to the zoologists and biologists who have been monitoring it on Macquarie Island, it has done very limited damage. I am also told that a very small amount of light oil escaped as well. I understand also that this has done the minimum of damage, but obviously I am still awaiting a full report, given the difficulties of communication that we have had. There are still some 500 tonnes of light diesel fuel on the vessel. It is, however, at this stage secure and will be pumped out when a replacement vessel arrives.

ANSWER.PARA: The next question that I think Senator Archer asked concerned costs to the Australian Government. The cost of getting another vessel is being borne by the company which has operated the Nella Dan. As far as the costs of removing the people from Macquarie Island are concerned, I shall be talking to Lauritzen about those costs very shortly, but I think they will be borne by it as well. As for the repercussions on science, unfortunately I have to report that the critical marine science program which is essential for Australia to play its role as a leading advocate for conservation within the Convention for the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources will not be able to be carried out this year. A decision on what will happen next year will depend on the availability of a suitable vessel for next season. We are, of course, at the moment examining lists in the world shipping market to try to make certain that we can get another vessel. However, as honourable senators are probably aware, the Lady Franklin has been obtained by us and will arrive in Hobart, I think on 15 January. It will then be fitted out with some extra lifeboats and accommodation modules and resume work. We believe at this stage that other programs will not be affected. However, I will give honourable senators a further report on that if anything else occurs.

As far as an Australian-owned vessel is concerned, fortunately I have been working on a submission on a replacement vessel for the Nella Dan over the last couple of months and have lodged for Cabinet consideration already a proposal for that. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

Some operators may have entered into commercial arrangements which exceed the reality of that situation, but I believe that they would be very few. —Queensland, for example.
