DEBATE.TITLE: OFFICIAL VISIT BY PRIME MINISTER TO SINGAPORE, THE SOVIET UNION AND JAPAN

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make and have have incorporated in Hansard a statement relating to the overseas visit to Singapore, the Soviet Union and Japan by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke).

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
From 27 November to 4 December, the Prime Minister made an official visit to Singapore, the Soviet Union and Japan. I make this Report to Parliament on the issues raised during that visit.

The Prime Minister's principal purpose in making the trip was to assess the nature, direction and implications for Australia of the policies being pursued by the new Soviet leadership-in particular as they affect our region-in order that we may be well placed to respond to any new political or commercial developments that may arise.

On his way to the Soviet Union, he made a brief visit to Singapore, to deliver the 1987 Singapore Lecture; on the way back, he held talks in Tokyo with the new Japanese Prime Minister Mr Takeshita. During a stop-over between Singapore and the USSR he also had a useful talk with the Prime Minister of Bahrain Sheik al-Khalifa on the situation in the Persian Gulf and the Middle East, and on bilateral matters.
SINGAPORE

In Singapore, the Prime Minister held useful discussions with Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew and Deputy Prime Ministers Goh Chok Tong and Ong Teng Cheong. These talks reaffirmed the close, friendly and cooperative relations which Australia enjoys with Singapore.

While in Singapore, he delivered the 1987 Singapore Lecture on the topic ``The Challenge of Change in the Asia-Pacific Region''. The invitation to deliver this lecture was extended to the Prime Minister by Mr S. Rajaratnam, Senior Minister, Prime Minister's Office, on behalf of the Institute of South-East Asian Studies.

In the Lecture, he discussed a number of developments likely to have an important influence on our region in the forthcoming period-principally, the emergence and modernisation of China, the current reforms in the Soviet Union and the requirement of the major Western economies to solve their fiscal and current imbalances and to resist protectionist pressures.

The Prime Minister drew particular attention to the paradox that at a time when both China and the Soviet Union are, in different ways and for different reasons, giving greater recognition to the Western concepts of competition and open markets, the leading Western economies are making disturbing moves in the opposite direction. In particular, we are facing a growing threat to our collective prosperity from the pressures of protectionism in the United States, Western Europe and Japan.

The Prime Minister made the point that economic reforms, however necessary, can be stalled or frustrated where they are not accompanied by a cooperative response from the whole community. The bottom line in achieving successful change is the informed cooperation of those who will ultimately be charged with implementing it and those who will be affected by it.

This broad prescription is particularly valid in democratic societies whose institutions are created for the purpose of public involvement in public affairs. It is an essential task for all societies, whatever their political systems, to win the understanding and acceptance of their entire communities in the making of necessary changes.
The importance of this task is, I believe well understood by the current leadership of the Soviet Union. It is the Prime Minister's visit to that country to which I now turn.
THE SOVIET UNION

From 29 November to 2 December, he visited Leningrad and Moscow at the invitation of the Government of the Soviet Union. This is only the second visit made by an Australian Prime Minister to the Soviet Union, although it was the fifth visit Mr Hawke had made. Since he was accompanied by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Mr Hayden, his visit in fact represents the most senior level of contact which has taken place between Australia and the Soviet Union.
This high level of contact is appropriate in view of the significant global and bilateral context in which the visit took place.

The policies of perestroika and glasnost which are being pursued by General Secretary Gorbachev and his colleagues are of potentially profound significance for the internal arrangements of the Soviet economy and society.

Beyond that, we in the West, including Australia, may well be profoundly and directly affected by those new policies through, for example, improved Soviet economic performance and greater involvement in the world economy.

Perhaps most significantly of all, we will be affected by the new directions in Soviet foreign policy which are related to the internal reforms. They include a stated intention to become more involved in the Pacific region, some greater sensitivity to Western concerns about human rights issues, and, of course, a commitment to engage in far-reaching negotiations over arms control and disarmament.

Bilaterally, the Soviet Union is an important, though still unpredictable, customer for Australian primary products. Government to Government contacts have been steadily improving since 1983 including, most significantly, the valuable visit to Australia last March of the Soviet Foreign Minister, Mr Shevardnadze, and the constructive preparation of the four agreements signed in Moscow by Mr Hayden and Mr Shevardnadze last week.

Accordingly, the talks the Prime Minister held with Mr Gorbachev, with the Chairman of the USSR Council of Ministers, Mr Ryzhkov, and with other Soviet leaders, were aimed principally at exploring the style and substance of perestroika and glasnost in domestic policy and ``new thinking'' in foreign policy. His objective was to advance further the already improving relationship between the Soviet Union and Australia in trade and other contacts, and to encourage greater Soviet flexibility on humanitarian issues including family reunion and the free movement of Soviet Jews. He sought also to discuss global and regional issues including the INF agreement and the prospects for further arms control agreements, and Soviet activities and intentions in Afghanistan, Indo-China and the Pacific region.

The Prime Minister made it clear, of course, that Australia's relationship with the USSR would continue to be based for our part on our continuing membership of and commitment to the Western Alliance-an alliance which is not solely of a military nature but which derives its greatest strength from a shared and enduring commitment to the values of freedom and democracy.
Mr President, before I address the substance of these discussions let me take this opportunity to comment on the statements which the Federal Opposition issued during the visit.

I put to one side the Opposition's apparently wilful distortion of the Prime Minister's remarks in Singapore where he said he would welcome a constructive-I repeat, a constructive-involvement of the Soviet Union in our region, and where he cautioned that we would judge them not by their words but by their actions in, for example, Indo-China and Afghanistan.
Australians have paid a very high price indeed for the predilection of the conservative parties in this country to project their domestic political preoccupations onto the screen of foreign policy.

One need only recall the tragedy of the Australian involvement in the Vietnam War to recall both the myopia with which the then Liberal-Country Party Government viewed our region, and its determination to derive and advance domestic political gains from the region, which it failed, or refused, to comprehend.

That was more than fifteen years ago. But it seems the current leaders of the conservative parties have learned nothing of the lessons of the past. Indeed, to judge by their recent statements about the Soviet Union, one would be forgiven for assuming the Opposition yearns for the confrontationist days of the Cold War, when any issue could be judged simply in black and white terms.

The essence of the Liberals' world view, which we are now seeing applied to the Soviet Union, is that we should explicitly ignore any signs of change and continue to operate on the assumptions of the past.

That attitude-which not coincidentally has also coloured the conservatives' view of events in China-is at odds with that of conservatives overseas such as Ronald Reagan and Margaret Thatcher. Nor is it one shared by significant parts of Australia's business community. Nor, I believe, is it shared by the Australian people as a whole.

The Prime Minister put it to Mr Gorbachev that he would never find Australia frightened of ideas. We would always be prepared to discuss any concept or idea advanced by the Soviet Union or anyone else as to ways in which existing mechanisms for dealing with regional problems may be improved.
That is a frank and constructive approach which enhances Australia's capacity to protect its own interests and influence events in the region.
It is not, apparently, an approach of which the Opposition approves.

But they are an isolated Opposition. In holding out against a cautious and deliberate response by the West to events in the Soviet Union, the Australian conservative parties are showing themselves as isolated from the mainstream of foreign policy thinking as their election defeat in July showed them to be isolated from relevant domestic policy.

Mr President, while in Moscow the Prime Minister held more than eight hours of formal talks with Mr Ryzhkov and other Ministers and a further 3 1/4 hours with Mr Gorbachev. Despite this generous allocation of time they were not able to cover fully the fascinating and complex question of the nature of the changes underway in the Soviet Union.

However, this much is clear. The Soviet leadership has embarked on a wide ranging and genuine attempt at restructuring the Soviet economy. They are motivated by a recognition that the Soviet command economy-an economy which for instance requires 200,000 separate decisions on wholesale and retail pricing-was, as Mr Gorbachev had put it, in a ``pre-crisis condition''. They recognise too, that changes are necessary if the Soviet economy is to resume its growth and if, in particular, the unfulfilled material needs of Soviet citizens are to be met.

The measures suggested clearly do not amount to any renunciation of Marxist-Leninist principles. However there is an explicit acceptance that excessive emphasis had been placed on the notion of centralised planning of enterprise-level activities. As Mr Ryzhkov put it, this had led to the loss of creativity in the workforce; egalitarian tendencies, as he put it, hindered others from exercising initiative and resulted in apathy. Since the late 1970's the economy had begun to perform well below its potential.
Such sentiments convince me of the genuineness of the Soviet leadership's commitment to change in domestic economic practices.
They leave unresolved of course the question of whether the leaders will be prepared, or permitted, to go far enough to make a success of perestroika.

Clearly, great changes of attitude are required on the part of both the government and the governed. Political pressures will undoubtedly impose their limits. Mr Gorbachev and his colleagues will mix vision with caution as they seek to implement their plans.

What can be said is that the changes proposed are in the right direction and if carried through hold the potential for some improvement, perhaps significant improvement, in the efficiency of the Soviet economy.

Certainly there will be no overnight transformation. Restructuring and openness have a long way to go in practice. Clearly therefore we must not be naive or complacent. But, on the whole, the talks have created a sense of cautious hope for the long term.
The implications of perestroika for international trade are profound.

The Prime Minister had lengthy discussions on trade with Mr Ryzhkov; the First Deputy Chairman of the Council of Ministers and Chairman of GOSAGROPOM, Mr Murakhovsky; and the Deputy Chairman of the Council of Ministers and Chairman of the State Foreign Economic Commission, Mr Kamentsev. His discussions with Mr Gorbachev also ranged over multilateral and bilateral trade issues.

At his meetings with Mr Murakhovsky and Mr Kamentsev the Prime Minister was accompanied by a delegation of 11 Australian businessmen. This allowed those businessmen to make direct contact with the top echelons of the Soviet leadership and to express their views to the leadership on ways of facilitating and expanding trade and other forms of economic co-operation between Australia and the Soviet Union.

Mr Ryzhkov emphasised on a number of occasions that as an integral part of perestroika, the Soviet Union wanted to become, as he put it, ``organically involved in the international division of labour''. The Soviet Union was seeking to do this through both multilateral and bilateral approaches to the rest of the world.
Mr Ryzhkov and the Prime Minister agreed that the Australian-Soviet trading relationship should be put on a more stable footing.

One of the four agreements they signed deals with economic co-operation, which offers the prospect of expanded commercial exchanges between our two countries. The other agreements, covering space science, sport, and medical co-operation, also hold out the prospect of closer and mutually beneficial ties between Australia and the Soviet Union.

Mr Ryzhkov and the Prime Minister agreed that progress towards remedying the trade imbalance between Australia and the Soviet Union-which heavily favours Australia-should be through growth in trade. In that context, Mr Ryzhkov provided a detailed list of products that the Soviets believed might find a market in Australia. The Prime Minister undertook to make the list available to the Australian business delegation and to Bill Hayden.

The Prime Minister indicated that in redressing the trade imbalance the Soviet Union should play its part by getting to know the Australian market better. In that context he made an offer for a Soviet delegation to visit Australia to familiarise themselves with the requirements of the Australian market. His offer was accepted and the delegation will visit Australia at a mutually agreeable time early next year.
He also invited the Soviet Government to send a Ministerial representative to Australia-the Prime Minister if he could find the opportunity-to share in our bicentennial celebrations next year.

Perestroika also encompasses the concept of joint ventures between the Soviet Union and foreign companies, with a 49 per cent holding by the foreign partner. This is an area in which a number of Australian companies will have considerable interest and therefore will give us the opportunity to derive a mutual benefit from these new changes in the Soviet Union.

As a first concrete step in fostering joint enterprises between Australia and the Soviet Union the Prime Minister urged the Soviet leaders to expedite the approval of a proposal by Comalco for a joint venture integrated aluminium complex in the Soviet Far East, ultimately consisting of a one million tonne per annum alumina refinery based on Australian bauxite, and a half million tonne per annum aluminium smelter. Each of Messrs Gorbachev, Ryzhkov and Kamentsev undertook to have the proposal considered as a matter of priority and expressed optimism about its approval.

Other areas of potentially expanded economic cooperation identified during our meetings included agricultural machinery, food processing, sheep breeding and shearing, cattle breeding, forest products, and mineral extraction and marketing.

The involvement of Western companies, including Australian firms, in the development of the Soviet economy, on mutually advantageous terms, can only have a positive impact on East-West relations. Just as the ``open door'' to China has been welcomed by us, it is in our interests to have an open mind to economic cooperation with the USSR.

Let me turn now to the second of the elements of the Soviet reforms, namely glasnost. We must understand that the Soviet leadership is not trying to reproduce liberal Western democratic features within the Soviet Union. Far from it.
But there are some attempts to allow greater freedom and greater diversity of expression, and these will succeed, in my opinion, to the extent that perestroika succeeds.

In other words, any lifting of the dead hand of the command economy and any devolution of decision-making power in economic affairs will encourage and almost inevitably be accompanied by a greater desire and capacity to exercise the freedoms suggested, in however constrained a way, by glasnost.
The Prime Minister pressed Mr Gorbachev and the other Soviet leaders firmly, but without antagonism, on the merits of a greater respect for individual human rights within the Soviet Union.

Australia has been negotiating with the Soviet Union for several months on a human contacts agreement which aims to win Soviet commitments to a more liberal approach in this field. Negotiations continued during my visit, including directly between Mr Hayden and Mr Shevardnadze. Though agreement has yet to be reached, progress was made during the visit and we shall continue our efforts in the future.

Mr Gorbachev understands that the differences between the Soviet Union and the West on human rights are fundamental and our capacity to have full and constructive cooperation will reflect our perceptions of progress in this area.

Australia is concerned about family reunion, about the right of Soviet Jews to emigrate, about the right of entry and exit for visits and about the plight of prisoners of conscience in the Soviet Union.

We have been achieving progress in family reunion and we welcome this. We also recognise and welcome the steady increase this year in the numbers of refuseniks allowed visas. Emigration approvals since April have been at a monthly rate of some 800-close to the entire year's emigration in 1986, but still well short of the 2000 approvals granted per month during the early 1970s.
In his discussions with Mr Gorbachev, the Prime Minister presented a list of six cases of refuseniks-cases which were typical of a larger group, of 28 cases of which we are aware.
Mr Gorbachev said that past practices on this matter were now under review and he gave me an undertaking that he would personally study the cases nominated on the list presented to him.

As honourable senators will be aware, two of the groups of people raised with Mr Gorbachev were in fact given subsequent approval to leave the Soviet Union. This news was conveyed by one of Mr Gorbachev's assistants immediately prior to the Prime Minister's departure from the Soviet Union.
The two cases cover five people-Pavel Abramovich and his wife Marta, and Professor Alexander and Rosa Joffe and their daughter, Anna.
The Soviet Union has also granted, after seven years refusal, permission for Mr Leonid Romanovsky to be reunited with his wife Danuta, who lives in Melbourne.

While too many cases remain outstanding, there is the prospect of further visa approvals-not least while East-West relations improve and countries like Australia insist that this issue be part of the dialogue with the Soviet Union.
This Government will continue to make every effort to obtain a positive resolution of every outstanding family reunion case and every outstanding refusenik case.
Mr President, as well as discussing these developments, the talks in the Soviet Union covered the related issue of the Soviet perceptions of and initiatives in global and regional affairs.

The Prime Minister congratulated the Soviet leadership, together with the United States, for their achievement in reaching the agreement on INF. This is a treaty of truly historic proportions: it is the first time in which the superpowers' nuclear arsenals have been cut rather than simply having their rate of growth reduced.

He expressed the view that the INF Treaty should be a first step, and that the cooperative approach displayed by the Soviet Union and the United States in reaching this agreement should now be turned to the search for progress in reduction of strategic weapons and chemical weapons.
This was a view which was accepted by Mr Gorbachev and equally the United States has indicated that INF is only a first step.

Indeed the Soviet Union expressed the hope that agreement on strategic nuclear forces could be reached in time for a possible meeting between Mr Gorbachev and Mr Reagan in Moscow in the first half of next year.

In view of the fact that the Prime Minister's visit took place immediately prior to the current Reagan-Gorbachev Summit, he passed on to President Reagan a report on my talks and his views on the current situation in the Soviet Union.
In his Singapore lecture, the Prime Minister made the point that the changes within the Soviet Union were likely to lead to a more subtle and imaginative diplomacy by the Soviet Union.

In our own region, we have already seen some manifestations of a greater interest by the Soviet Union in the affairs of the Pacific. I refer in particular to Mr Gorbachev's Vladivostok speech of July 1986 and his interview with the Indonesian newspaper Merdeka of last July.

The Soviet Union is of course a Pacific nation and it therefore has a legitimate interest in the Pacific. We recognise the fact that the Soviet Union is entitled to economic relations with Pacific countries.
No amount of sabre rattling by the Opposition will change those facts.

What is important is that we seek to ensure that the South Pacific not become an arena of superpower rivalry, and that the rest of the region-which paid a heavy cost for superpower rivalry in the Korean and Vietnam wars-never again be forced to pay such a cost.
The Soviet Union's influence on Vietnam and Kampuchea is already significant and it has a large naval base at Cam Ranh Bay.
The Prime Minister told the Soviet leadership that we would judge the Soviet's intentions in our region not by their words but by their actions in, for example, Indo-China and Afghanistan.
That is in part what I mean when I say that we would welcome a constructive involvement by the Soviet Union in our region.
We do not want any fishing agreement signed by the Soviet Union with an island State to be anything other than just that-a fishing agreement.
To take another case, we would welcome a full and unambiguous association by the Soviet Union with the protocols of the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty.

Mr President, what we are seeking is a businesslike and fruitful relationship with the Soviet Union which is of benefit to both nations. It comes at a time when our Western friends and allies in general are seeking to build such a relationship. I trust that the Prime Minister's visit has constituted a part in that process.
JAPAN

The Prime Minister took the opportunity of a stopover in Tokyo to meet the new Japanese Prime Minister, Mr Takeshita. We had a warm and constructive conversation reflecting the close ties between our two nations.
In his Singapore Lecture, he dealt at some length with the emerging economic and political role of Japan, both in our region and more generally.
In particular, he made the point that the real test of Japan's leadership will be its performance in the crucial area of economic adjustment.
Japan's massive current account surplus and its associated accumulating wealth imposes a responsibility on Japan's economic leadership which is just as heavy as that on the United States.
The Maekawa Report provides clear guidelines for Japanese economic reform which involve reduced Japanese reliance on exports and a greater willingness to open its domestic markets to imports.

It is essential that Japan begin to give effect to the principles enunciated in that report-principles which will impose their own economic and social pressures on Japan but which nonetheless are an essential element in restoring global economic balance.

The Prime Minister was therefore pleased in his discussions with Prime Minister Takeshita to hear him reaffirm the theme of his policy statement to the Diet-that Japan would be embarking upon a program of restructuring which would increase import penetration into the Japanese market, and which would seek to substitute domestic demand in the place of exports as the major engine of growth in Japan.

We welcome this objective. While acknowledging the political difficulties which Japan's leadership would encounter, I note that we in Australia have not been afraid to confront and overcome such difficulties ourselves in our efforts to open up our economy, to make it more efficient, to diversify our economic base, to integrate our economy with our region and to improve our competitiveness in the world economy.
The Prime Minister also had more detailed discussions with Foreign Minister Uno on both multilateral and bilateral trading issues.

Mr Uno advised me of Japan's attitude to the new round of Multilateral Trade Negotiations. Japan, like Australia, wanted an ``early harvest'' from the negotiations but had some differences with Australia and the Cairns Group on agriculture.

The Prime Minister expressed Australia's deep regret that Japan did not fully support the Cairns Group proposals, noting that Japan has to face up squarely to the questions of agricultural reform in order to meet the broader national and global interest. He stressed that if there were not a substantial ``early harvest'' of agricultural trade reforms there could well be a ``bitter harvest'' in years ahead which would have disastrous consequences for all nations.

He also raised with Mr Uno the particular issues of access for our beef and the state of the markets for iron ore and coal. He sought and received assurances that Japan would not allow non-commercial considerations to enter as a factor in its efforts to remedy its trade imbalance with the United States. Australia is happy to trade on our merits. We welcome free and open competition.

The Prime Minister's discussions also touched upon the growing political role of Japan in the Asia-Pacific region. He welcomed Japan's perception of itself as both part of the West and of this region. In doing so, however, he registered the deep regret of the Australian Government of the stance which Japan has taken on New Caledonia in the United Nations General Assembly-a decision which does not sit easily with that perception.

Mr President, the Summit now beginning in Washington is an event of historic international significance. The relations between the super-powers now present the real prospect of producing a more stable and more constructive world.

We are all, I believe, both privileged and challenged to be part of this critically important and potentially rewarding point in history. We should all by our own words and actions be worthy of that challenge.

If we can maintain our patience, our determination and our realism, we can yet achieve a meaningful and constructive peace between nations and a commensurate capacity for turning the world's resources more directly to meeting the material needs and aspirations of its people.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the President, I present an erratum sheet relating to the explanatory memorandum to the Parliamentary Privileges Bill 1987.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND GOVERNMENT OPERATIONS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I welcome the Government response to the report by the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, although I regret that it took 15 months to appear. Despite some reservations which I will explain in a moment, I think the response is a great advance in dealing with non-statutory bodies (NSBs). The Government has indicated that it has decided that, instead of having a register of non-statutory bodies maintained in the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet (PM and C), it will require information regarding non-statutory bodies to be provided in annual reports either of NSBs themselves or of their parent bodies as respective Ministers decide. This is fine as far as the detailed information is concerned but it still means that there is not even a central simple list naming NSBs, let alone a centrally available reasonable amount of information.

I raise a query about what is meant by NSB parent bodies; whether that is intended to mean a department or whether it is something else. Even if it does mean a department or portfolio, it still means that there are at least 16 separate lists for checking on non-statutory bodies. I would have thought that the least a central department, such as Prime Minister and Cabinet, could do was to keep a list of all such NSBs in order to make it easier for those interested to keep track of such bodies, of their formation, disappearance and activities. Obviously, the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, which has replaced the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, will still have to maintain a list, as its predecessor has tried to do in recent years, by itself collating all the information from annual reports-a job which I do not think it should have to do. I think it should be a function of PM and C as the central co-ordinating Department. A further drawback of such a procedure is that even such a list as the Committee produces will effectively be out of date. It will be historical to some extent because it will be collated from departmental annual reports rather than always being an up to date snapshot of the position of non-statutory bodies existing at any one time.

The Government has listed 11 exceptions to the bodies about which information would have to be provided in annual reports. I can understand the listing of the first seven. I would indicate that government companies are included amongst those. I think government companies basically need to be listed separately, but I acknowledge that that is a separate issue. As I say, I understand the listing of the first seven, but not of the other four. For instance, it is proposed that bodies created for fixed periods of less than 12 months be excluded. The speech read as follows-

I present the report of the delegation. In September 1987, this delegation, representing both Houses of the Australian Parliament, visited several European Cities to attend the Autumn Sittings of the European Parliament and the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe. The delegation also attended meetings of the North Atlantic Assembly, the Second Strasbourg Conference on Parliamentary Democracy and conferred with officials of the European Commission and the Council of Ministers. The delegation took the opportunity to visit the European Court of Justice in Luxembourg and the Headquarters of the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation in Brussels. The visit commenced with an official program in Finland as guests of the Finnish Parliament.

The report tabled today records the official activities of the delegation and makes recommendations and suggestions for future visits to European Parliamentary institutions by other delegations. The delegation's visit to Finland was the first extensive visit by an Australian Parliamentary group to that country, although a shorter visit was made by a previous delegation to Scandinavia in 1982. An excellent program was arranged for the visit by our hosts in conjunction with the Australian Embassy in Stockholm. In fact, I would like to take this opportunity to personally and on behalf of the delegation thank the Australian Ambassador, Ros McGovern, for her very competent assistance and support during the delegation's visit to Finland.

While in Finland, the delegation's itinerary included briefings and a tour of the Industrial Power Company Limited and its facilities, a nuclear power station which imports Australian uranium. As well as meeting members of the Finnish Parliament and representatives of Parliamentary Groups, including members of the Agricultural and Forestry Committee and Foreign Affairs Committee, the delegation also met the Minister for the Chancellery, the Speaker of the Finnish Parliament and the Prime Minister. The delegation also conducted discussions with representatives of the Finnish Australian Trade Association, the Finnish Australian Society, the Central Union of Agricultural Producers and visited the Helsinki shipyard of Wartsila Marine Industries Incorporated.

In addition to the formal program of discussions and inspections, the delegation visited a wilderness area in Lapland, north of the Arctic Circle. As well as observing reindeer raising, which is a primary source of livelihood for the Lapps, the delegation spent time in part of the substantial wilderness area in the region and received an extensive briefing on the impact of the nuclear accident at Chernobyl on local flora and fauna. The delegation was gratified to learn that radioactive fallout in this region of Finland was not as severe as it was in other parts of Scandinavia and did not pose a major threat to reindeer herds in Lapland. The delegation would particularly like to thank the Speaker of the Finnish Parliament and his staff for making special arrangements for the delegation to visit Lapland as guests of the Salla community.

As with previous delegations, issues of agriculture and trade dominated many of the discussions held with European Parliamentarians and officials of the institutions of the European Community. However, other important issues were also discussed and these are set out in Chapter 2 of the delegation's report. These include the role of the nordic countries, nuclear power, disarmament and security, the French role in the South Pacific, South Pacific security, European unity and parliamentary democracy. As well, the delegation considers that it was able to contribute to the kangaroo debate in Europe by providing a greater understanding of the issues concerned leading to the determination of a European position which is favourable to Australian export trade and earnings.

In the delegation's discussions on agricultural trade and the European common agricultural policy, it was recognised that in order for Australia to have a major impact in this debate it is necessary for its representatives to adopt an Australian strategy in Europe. It became clear from individual discussions between delegation members and European politicians, that a groundswell is developing in Europe against the common agricultural policy. This derives largely from the fact that the major beneficiary of the policy is agribusiness, including large corporate farmers, fertilizer companies and other interests. The small farmers, for whom the common agricultural policy was developed, are in serious financial difficulty and are increasingly expressing their hostility. It is the view of the delegation that the political perspective of the common agricultural policy will change. This change could be accelerated if countries, such as Australia, were more aggressive in highlighting the discontent that exists.

Europe needs to be made more aware that the more resources diverted to artificial support measures for an inefficient agricultural sector, the less is available for productive investment in manufacturing and service industries. Thus, the trend towards increased imports of manufactured goods and the greater need for foreign sourced capital for domestic investment will continue. Fundamental to the social implications of these issues is that not only has the common agricultural policy not been able to retain jobs in the agricultural sector but it has caused a continued loss of jobs in manufacturing. It is vital that these implications are better known and understood, not only by those Europeans involved in the manufacturing sector, but Europeans from all walks of life.

In this report, the delegation also makes recommendations of a practical nature designed to ensure that the greatest amount of benefit will be derived from future visits by Australian Parliamentary delegations to these European Institutions. The delegation considers that some continuity of membership would enable greater advantage to be gained from opportunities presented during these visits and therefore recommends, in line with previous recommendations of similar delegations, that whenever possible, the leader of any future delegation should have been a member of a previous delegation. The delegation also thinks that the inclusion of the European Court of Justice in Luxembourg and the European Court of Human Rights in Strasbourg was worthwhile and recommends that they be included in all future visits of this kind, preferably when the Courts are in session. Furthermore, the delegation considers the visit to NATO Headquarters in Brussels to be important and informative and recommends that it should be maintained as part of the program for future Parliamentary delegations to European institutions. As a matter of practical advice, the delegation recommends that a standard set of instructions for future delegations be prepared, specifically setting out the nature and scope for participation by the delegation at each of the institutions to be visited and indicating the aims of the delegation's participation at such sessions.

The range of institutions visited and the number of meetings and discussion held, indicate that this was a demanding and sometimes hectic tour of the European institutions. I would like to add to the recommendations already made that a future delegation could spend more time in Brussels to gain a fuller understanding of the role and functions of the European Commission and Council of Ministers and their relationship with the European Parliament. Members of the delegation felt that not enough time was set aside to gain a thorough understanding of the complexities of these interrelationships.

As I have just mentioned, the nature of this extensive program required a high level of support and assistance from host countries and Australian Missions where these institutions were situated. Reference has already been made to our hosts in Finland, particularly Mr Matti Ahde, Speaker of the Finnish Parliament, and his very competent staff. The delegation would also like to thank the staff of the European Parliament and the Council of Europe who so ably assisted the delegation during its visit to Strasbourg and Brussels. Special mention should also be made of the President of the Norwegian Storting, Mr Jo Benkow, for the hospitality extended to the delegation during its visit to the North Atlantic Assembly. The delegation is also appreciative for the assistance and excellent briefings provided overseas by representatives of the Australian Government in Brussels and Paris. On behalf of the delegation I also express our appreciation to the Parliamentary Relations Office, to officers of the Parliamentary Library and would also like to place on record the delegation's thanks to the Ambassador to Finland, Mr Slotte and Mr Juul Jorgensen, Head of Delegation, European Communities Commission for their assistance prior to the delegation's departure and friendship shown on our return.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like Senator Sanders, I do not want to rehash the report but to add a little of my own perspective to what was in the printed report. It was a very cohesive and hardworking delegation, more so than average from what I have heard and experienced. The whole delegation participated very fully in discussions at every opportunity. It is unfortunate that all of the speeches made could not be attached to the report but transcripts from the organisations have not yet reached Australia. They are not as efficient as our Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Our contributions to the various debates, particularly those relating to the circumstances of Australia, such as the compulsory voting system we have in Australia, which was of great interest, and the fact that we have to provide for a multicultural society in our education and government information processes, created a lot of interest. I am only sorry that the excellent material we have seen recently coming out of the parliamentary information service was not available for us to take with us, because we were able to talk about the sorts of services provided in that area as well.

We not only learnt a lot about the issues which were current in Europe, particularly those relating to peace and security and to agricultural policies, but also we got an insight into other forms of parliamentary democracy, other sorts of electoral systems, other ways of dealing with legislation and even other parliamentary procedures, such as Question Time in the European Parliament. We were interested to find out that the people who answered the questions were the senior bureaucrats, not the Ministers. All questions were answered on considerable notice, sometimes up to three months. The only way one can ask a real question is to somehow work it in as a supplementary to a question on notice. So we learnt a lot about the formal structures and policies of the parliamentary institutions in Europe.

We also learnt a great deal in a more informal way, particularly about the attitudes of members of the parliamentary institutions and of member states. I would like to read out a few quotations which I took note of while I was over there. Senator Sanders has already referred to the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation (NATO) perception of what was sometimes explicitly called the threat of the Gorbachev initiatives or, even on one occasion-I think this was in private, though-the `threat of peace'. On that matter, one of the NATO officials said to us, `We do not know where the Soviets are going to attack', not `if', but `where'. A Colonel Akan, an ex-military gentleman from the United States who is now working on briefing visitors to NATO, told us that it was his view that the United States should take all of its money out of the United Nations and put it into NATO. I do not know whether it would also remove the United Nations headquarters from the United States.

One of the British Conservative delegates at the North Atlantic Alliance said, `Nuclear free zones could diminish the credibility of Western nuclear deterrence'-not a view which Australia would share. France, in one of many justifications of its nuclear tests in the Pacific, claimed that its nuclear deterrent gave it security at least cost. I suppose that depends on what sort of cost one is talking about. Another delegate said that `only the deployment of nuclear missiles in Europe has brought the USSR to the negotiating table'. Those like me who have been active in the peace movement for many years might as well pack up and go home in that case. A member of the British House of Lords said that peace studies in schools were `biased, lacked intellectual honesty and taught subversion'.

Getting away from the security issue, which is a little too depressing, a delegate to the Council of Europe Conference on Democracy, replying to speeches about the lack of representation and participation, particularly by women and young people, in the democratic process said, `Women will first need a period of adaptation to acclimatise them to the clan', before they can participate fully in democracy. I found these insights not always pleasurable and sometimes chilling but for me they were one of the fruitful outcomes of our delegation to Europe.

I come penultimately to the happiest part of our journey, also referred to by Senator Sanders. It was our first visit chronologically, our visit to Finland, where we were not only shown a great deal of genuinely warm hospitality but also had the opportunity for very open discussion on a range of issues, from trade to Finland's relationship with the Soviet Union. All of us felt very much at home. We even found that the Finns had a sense of humour very like our own. It is easy to understand why the Finnish community in Australia has been so readily integrated into our community over the last 200 years.

Finally, I draw the attention of the Senate-I hope that some honourable senators will read the report-to the section at the end of the report headed `Other Administrative Matters', which should help future delegations. I would like to add to that list a plea for more thought and attention to detailed preparation before delegations leave Australia. One example which got to me was that as a female member of the delegation I was not clearly notified as such. I was on the list not as Senator Zakharov, although the other senators were labelled senator, but as Mrs Zakharov, which is not what I call myself at any time. I continually found myself being asked, `Whose wife are you?'. When I got to the North Atlantic Alliance and we were issued with tickets to get into the building I found that my ticket was for an accompanying person, not for a delegate. I had to take it back and say, `I am a delegate'. Perhaps these things could be foreseen once people understand that those biases still exist in other parts of the world, even if we hope that they are dying here. This could save embarrassment. I was not embarrassed but there was embarrassment to other people who suddenly found that they were talking to a delegate and not to an accompanying person.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION TO INDIA AND SRI LANKA

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I table the report of the parliamentary delegation to India and Sri Lanka. I seek leave to move a motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

I wish to speak briefly to the report of a delegation which unfortunately I became a member of at the expense of Senator Messner. Indeed, I was the only senator in the group of six. It is more than 12 months since the delegation left Australia. Given the rapid pace of events in Sri Lanka in the intervening period, the report has some of the character of ancient history. Nonetheless, it was a very worthwhile outing.

I want to compare two aspects of the trip to India and Sri Lanka. In India we met, essentially, with a low level range of officials, whereas in Sri Lanka we met with all the leading Ministers in the Government from the President downwards. That opportunity gave us some real insights into the difficulties faced by the Sri Lankan Government and some of the complexities of the problems that have beset the island in recent years. The peace accord that was signed subsequent to our visit-and of course in no sense related to it-was eminently foreseeable because it involved the presence of the Indian Government and ultimately some 15,000 troops. Unfortunately, and regrettably, it had become increasingly clear to all concerned with trying to resolve the escalating violence and certainly to the members of the delegation that unless the Indians were able to be involved in the process there was little prospect of a resolution of the conflict.

Since that time, despite the presence of Indian troops on the island and despite what I think were realistic, if not long delayed, proposals by the Sri Lankan Government-and particular credit should go to President Jayawardene-unfortunately those concessions have been almost too little too late in the sense that, despite the best endeavours of the Government, we have not only seen violence on the part of the Tamil Tigers, although the indications were that Prabhakaran was likely to want to reach an accommodation, but we have also seen a counter-reaction from Sinhalese extremists. The end result is that both sides are as much apart as ever. Despite the supposed surrender of arms by the Tigers, who had managed to obliterate most of their competitors, they have managed to retain sufficient weaponry, and perhaps even managed to confiscate a quantity from the Sri Lankan army, to enable them to maintain what is a very destabilising and destructive counter-attack against both the Indian and Sri Lankan troops.

It is a matter of considerable regret that there does not seem to be any easy solution to the problem. Even the offer of relative autonomy for the northern and eastern provinces, which has much to recommend it, would have involved, and still does involve, the holding of a referendum in due course within 12 months to enable the eastern province, which has equal numbers of Sinhalese, Moslems and Tamils, to decide its own future. Despite all those concessions it would seem that the Tigers are intent on pursuing their goal of Eelam, which I regard as unattainable. There is much to be said for the Tamil cause, and in many ways they have had a very raw deal over some 20 years or so. At present their ultimate solution would seem to be not only unachievable but one which can only result in substantial and continuing bloodshed.

I would only hope that the insights we have gained will be of some assistance in helping us in Australia understand the dimensions of the problem. More importantly, I hope that the people of Sri Lanka will have the foresight and wisdom ultimately to achieve a solution which will give something less than total independence, but nonetheless a large measure of autonomy, to the Tamils, who have much to commend their cause but who at the moment seem intent on nothing less than achieving an ultimate military solution. All those who have had the opportunity to study the problem will recognise that no such solution is available.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: PETROLEUM RETAIL MARKETING SITES AMENDMENT (DIVORCEMENT OF OWNERSHIP) BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator McLean) agreed to:
That the following Bill be introduced: a Bill for an Act to amend the Petroleum Retail Marketing Sites Act 1980.
Motion (by Senator McLean) agreed to:
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate my second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill is an updated version of the Bill introduced by my colleague, Senator Janet Powell, last year. In introducing it, I use much of Senator Powell's second reading speech as it is still relevant and accurate.

This Bill is a significant step in bringing a measure of sanity back to petrol pricing in Australia. We do not believe that Australia's irrational petrol pricing structure will be simply resolved by this legislation. More action, including legislative action, will be needed. However, we propose a simple solution to a problem which currently causes massive variations in petrol prices within cities, between States, and between metropolitan and rural areas . . . The problem is that petrol companies use their retail prices to start petrol price wars. These price wars almost never benefit rural consumers, who do, after all, travel greater distances and use more petrol. These price wars never benefit independent petrol retailers, who cannot anticipate their cash flow, and therefore have great difficulty negotiating loans, and indeed, their normal, everyday, living expenses. Many are going bankrupt.

During petrol price wars, it is not unusual for petrol to be retailed below the maximum wholesale price set by the Prices Surveillance Authority. It seems strange that petrol companies who from time to time make representations to the Prices Surveillance Authority can afford to retail petrol below the wholesale price the PSA sets, having due regard to the submissions, views and profitability of the petrol companies themselves.

The major determinant of petrol prices in Australia is the Federal Government. This follows the decision by the Fraser Government to introduce Import Parity Pricing. This means that despite the fact that Australia is about 90 per cent self-sufficient in petrol production, and about 80 per cent of this Australian petrol comes from Bass Strait, which has been producing since the late 1960s, the Fraser Government decided to equate the price of Australian crude oil with the price of Arab oil. As a result, the federal government was able to get billions of dollars of extra revenue because about half of a litre of petrol goes to the Commonwealth government in the form of excises and royalties.

In Opposition, the Labor spokesperson for Minerals and Energy, Mr Keating, attacked import parity pricing as a ``tax by stealth-with a branch of the Tax Office at every petrol pump''. As Treasurer, he discovered that it is too hard to give up billions of dollars in revenue. When the price of petrol fell last year, Mr Keating responded by passing on ``some'' price reductions to the consumer but he increased the excise so that Commonwealth revenues were not diminished by the fall in world petrol prices. As a result:
Increasing petrol prices feed into the C.P.I. and lift our inflation rate;
Australia does not get a significant competitive advantage in production costs despite the fact that we are relatively self-sufficient in petroleum production; and
Rural dwellers, who have greater distances to travel, are hit the hardest by high petrol prices.

This Bill does not attack the problem of import parity pricing. It is true, however, that a high proportion of the price of petrol goes to the Government, and that this artificially inflates Australia's petrol prices. Our aim with this Bill is to help the independent petrol retailers and to curtail the situation where, when the most common petrol price may be 55c, but the range will be 44c-66c. We believe some of that variation is due to petrol companies, who own and operate petrol retail outlets, using those outlets to maintain market share at any cost.

In their attempts to maintain this market share, they use price wars in selected areas. Consumers in those areas benefit, and the petrol companies argue that this is healthy competition in the marketplace. We are not against competition or price discounting, but we do not believe the time and place for these activities should be dictated purely by petrol companies-the decision ought to flow from market forces.

The petrol companies are part of a powerful oligopoly, able to manipulate the market and the lives of independent petrol retailers in a ruthless and purely self-interested manner. It ought to be left to the small businesses, the independent petrol retailers, to decide on the competitive level of the marketplace.

This legislation calls for divorcement, meaning that petrol companies would not be allowed to own and operate retail sites. This call for divorcement is based on our desire to create true price competition in the petroleum industry, with the oil companies competing at the wholesale end of the market and the retailers being responsible for competition in their own retail section. The independent petrol retailers should not have to worry about how far below the wholesale price the service station down the road, owned by one of the big oil companies, is willing to retail petrol to its customers.

The Liberal/National parties in Government appeared to favour divorcement when they made a promise on 30 October, 1978, when the so-called Fife package was announced, that oil companies would be prohibited from retailing petroleum through direct sales sites. But towards the end of 1980 the Fraser government introduced its petroleum retail marketing legislation which reneged on this undertaking, and introduced a quota of sites for each integrated oil group. The initial number of sites allowed in 1980 was further reduced in 1983. Currently, while petrol companies still own only 5 per cent to 7 per cent of the total number of retailing sites in Australia, these still account for 11 per cent to 18 per cent of the volume of petrol sold in this country.

The inequity of this marketing chaos becomes obvious when travelling between urban and rural areas. In certain areas of the city, petrol can probably be bought for under fifty cents a litre. In rural areas, that figure may very well be over sixty cents per litre. Commonwealth and State taxes, and freighting costs do not explain these wide variations in the same State on the same day. They certainly cannot explain why some petrol retailers can afford to retail petrol below the official wholesale price.

It is time to reduce the market power of petrol companies, who are, after all, ultimately interested in maximising their profits and are not selling petrol at the lowest possible price in carefully selected areas for the good of the motoring public. In passing this Bill, we will remove a considerable part of the petrol companies' power to distort petrol prices for their own long-term advantage. This legislation would also give the small business petrol retailing entrepreneur the ability to run his own show without direct competition from those who supply him with the product he sells. Petrol companies, unlike small businesspeople, can afford to make significant short-term losses to further their long-term strategic advantage.

Most importantly, this legislation will go some way to stabilizing petrol prices and giving all Australian consumers, whether they live in the city or the country, access to petrol at the best prices that can be provided by retailers subject to healthy competition from each other. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —When this Bill was being considered in committee yesterday, I was concerned by some aspects of the attacks on radio station 3CR in relation to the Broadcasting Amendment Bill (No. 3), which largely addresses issues concerning community radio, 3CR being the first and one of the most successful community radio stations in Australia. I believe that in substance those attacks by Senator Short are unworthy. I noticed, however, that his sentiments did receive some support from the Minister opposite at the time.
—It was not me!

—Not the Minister currently in the chamber, I might add. I am afraid that in that onslaught we may have seen a rather crude attempt at a form of political censorship in an effort to silence those who do not preach the sort of New Right philosophy that Senator Short finds so endearing. I take this opportunity to remind the Senate of 3CR's own broadcasting code, which specifically excludes threatening, abusive or insulting behaviour and the promoting of hatred against or hostility towards groups of persons distinguished by their sex, sexual preference, race, religion, colour, ethnic or national origins and so on. I do not agree with everything I hear on 3CR, nor do I agree with everything I hear on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, but I do not accept an option which smacks of political censorship.

SPEECH.PARA: I find it rather ironic that Senator Short should have taken this line, because if ever there was a section of the media which it might be argued should suffer this kind of censorship-a section of the media which is guilty of racism, intolerance and unprincipled character attacks-and which should be the target of this criticism it is the infamous excuse for a newspaper called the Toorak Times. Who has a weekly column in this newspaper but Senator Short himself, alongside other eminent social thinkers like Bruce Ruxton, Jennifer McCallum, Roger Shipton and so on. This chamber, as the upshot of all this, should remember that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal is set up to assess whether stations are complying with the broadcasting guidelines, and it should be left to the ABT to rule on these matters. If Senator Short has a complaint to make about specific programs on 3CR he should make it at a licence renewal hearing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take up again with the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) the points that we were raising last night in relation to 3CR but before I do that, in response to Senator Powell, I say that I am not sure whether her comments were a defence of 3CR. She seemed by implication to be defending 3CR by virtue of criticising my criticisms of 3CR. I am surprised beyond comprehension if she was in fact doing that, but it appears that Senator Powell has now gone on the record as a defender of 3CR. I point out to her the inaccuracy of her statement that I have a regular column in the Toorak Times-not that I would mind having that as the Toorak Times is widely read. I do have a weekly column in a very well read and widely circulated newspaper called the Northerner, which circulates in some of the northern parts of Melbourne. I am delighted to have the opportunity to communicate to the electors and people in that area what happens in Canberra on matters of concern to them. That is a slight diversion, though.

SPEECH.PARA: I wondered whether the Minister had had an chance to have another look at the point we were discussing when the debate concluded last night. Having today read the Hansard record of the debate I am still not clear on the situation we discussed. We were talking about the conversion of the limited commercial licence which 3CR now holds, and which the Minister said is of an idiosyncratic nature, into a special interest licence. Does the Minister feel that what we are talking about would be merely an administrative change and not a major change in the potential reach of the station? As I understand it, a special interest public licence is normally granted to a station which targets on a particular interest group and by so doing it gives it a wider geographic coverage because the members of that special interest group might be widespread; for example, through the whole of Melbourne. On the other hand, 3CR is not that type of station, as I would have envisaged it, yet it appears that giving it a special interest public licence will considerably extend its reach. May we have some clarification of that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me try to clarify this once again. It is the case that usually community licences as they traditionally have been understood within the public radio sector have involved lower power coverage of a limited area with a demonstrated community of interest and have not been easily definable by reference to the character of the programming; rather they have been defined by reference to being a community access station for a particular locality and using, as I say, usually a low-power transmitter. Special interest licences, by comparison, which have been acknowledged in the past and whose existence is now formalised in the legislation, have generally been those that have been targeted by reference to the nature of the programming rather than the particular geographic area with which they have been associated and potentially, I suppose, if not very much in practice, have had a wider range of physical coverage than that involved in the traditional notion of the community licence as such.

SPEECH.PARA: Where does 3CR fit within that? It was originally given, as we know, a limited commercial licence without any particular restriction upon it as to coverage. The existing service area for 3CR, which covers the area within 16 kilometres of the transmitter in Collingwood, is in fact quite close to metropolitan-wide. It was limited to the particular boundaries that it now has not for any policy reasons relating to the community it intended to serve but only because it was not possible to allow higher power transmission from the inner city site that was preferred by 3CR. In fact, the first public licences granted in other cities-cities as distinct from smaller rural communities-were given metropolitan-wide coverage. So nothing really hangs on the physical distinction at this stage.

Quite independently from the issue of the conversion of the licence, 3CR has been seeking a wider physical coverage within the metropolitan area. As I have said, it already has a coverage of nearly all of the metropolitan area. A 16-kilometre radius from the Richmond studios covers a pretty substantial slab of the Melbourne metropolis. It has been seeking, however, a slightly wider area quite independently of the proposed conversion. The proposed service area for the station has already been circulated for comment in the usual way. Other licensees may lodge objections to it; whether they have or not, I do not know. In due course it will come forward for decision in the ordinary way. But that is a separate exercise from that involved in changing the character of the licence.

The reason it is specifically identified in this Bill as being given a special interest licence rather than a community licence is that, whatever may have been the case in the past, we want so far as possible to get the distinction known and understood: a community licence involves essentially wide-ranging community access radio targeted on a particular geographical locality with a common interest in that sort of physical geographical locality sense, and special interest licences really involve everything else. It is not possible to define in advance with any particular precision what the range of special interest public licences may be. That is something that will evolve over time.

I will finish by saying that the particular character of the special interest that 3CR is to be identified as being vested with has not yet been determined. Everyone seemed to think that it was a good idea for the Minister to determine it rather than the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. I am not sure about that but that was the view of the Tribunal, I think, and also 3CR. It is essentially a matter of recognising that 3CR is a particular kind of station that has acquired an identity, one involving accessibility to all sorts of groups and programmers with an appeal to an alternative audience, as it were. I think the view is that we will be able somehow to define that in a satisfactory way and that essential programming style will be the one that will continue in the future under this new regime. I hope that is sufficient to explain it. There are a number of different bits and pieces of this that come together and it is a bit difficult to do it all with military precision because these different licences have come together as a result of an evolutionary process. I do not know whether that is reasonably accurate-none of my departmental troops are getting too hysterical so I assume it is accurate-but that is my understanding of how the situation has evolved and where we are now.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for that explanation. He has clarified for me that the question of extending the range of the station is not at all related to the conversion of the licence. He is therefore saying that the conversion of the licence will not affect the power output of the station or its 16-kilometre range.
—It is a completely separate exercise; that is what I am saying.
—I thank the Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just come in at this point because it seems to me-I am sure the Minister will agree-from a policy standpoint, and given his apparent misgivings about having to make a decision about 3CR, that there must be some concern about the precedent which is being established by going down this track of being able to change a licence in the fashion that he has set. I will not argue the particular point about 3CR-a low-powered unit-which is the point that my colleague Senator Short has been making, and the change from that low-powered licence of a community kind towards a rather larger one which is more special interest directed but with a larger coverage. That surely opens the question as to whether other public broadcasters may well seek to apply the same argument to the Minister about the extension of their activities. One could envisage, for instance, that public broadcasters with a licence under the new arrangements that are set down in this legislation would then, having obtained a licence, seek to go to the Minister and say, `Look, I am going to change the character of our broadcasting and the special group of people to whom we are trying to appeal', and seek to have a broader coverage of their licence.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the point on which I would like some answer from the Minister because it seems to open a possible loophole by which public broadcasters could extend their activities on a broader base than might otherwise be expected. After all, we cannot have a coding system that blocks out those who are not specially interested in what is coming forward from any public broadcasting station.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to that is very simple. The provision that has been made for 3CR is a special one-off provision embodied in the specific terms of clause 34 of this Bill. It is specific to 3CR itself. It is not as though we are creating a regime whereby a Minister, by the stroke of a pen, can change the character of the licence. It is a one-off thing and it has to go through this legislative trial and tribulation before it can be brought into effect. In the future I will not have the capacity to change the identification of the other existing community--
—Those that will get licences; those that will be registered.

—In the future I will identify in advance whether it is to be a community type of public licence or a special interest type of licence. As I have indicated-I think this is specific elsewhere, in the second reading speech and in other policy statements-the general intention is that a community licence that is called in the future will prima facie be one for a specific confined locality. A special interest licence will be one that has a specific defined programming character but no particular geographical coverage, just whatever is appropriate to the metropolitan or rural regional area that is involved. All of those ground rules will be laid out in advance. People will make applications and the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT) will grant the licences according to the particular category that has been identified. This is just an ad hoc provision to deal with an anomalous situation.

SPEECH.PARA: I should further add for the record that the reason why the legislation is written in this way, that is, with 3CR vesting the responsibility in me as distinct from the Tribunal to identify the particular licence description, is that 3CR has just been through an extensive licence renewal process. It was thought inappropriate under the circumstances to put everyone to the trouble of going through it all again. I am now indicating that it is my intention to pick up as much as possible the previous ABT description and to make the processes as policy free and as administrative as possible. The last thing I want to do is to get into a row about 3CR.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

BROADCASTING (OWNERSHIP AND CONTROL) BILL (NO. 2) 1987-GOVERNMENT AMENDMENTS
OUTLINE
Section 13 of the Broadcasting Amendment Act 1987 (the Television Equalisation Act) introduced in the Broadcasting Act 1942 (the Principal Act):

(a) a ``one television licence in an Approved Market'' prescribed interest limit which prohibits a person from holding a prescribed interest in two or more commercial television licences within the same Approved Market (sub-section 92 (1a) of the Principal Act); and

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of the motion, add:

(a) the decision to abandon the proposal to auction new broadcasting licences only six weeks after the proposal was announced;
(b) the decision to implement an establishment fee system for new FM radio licences, which will:
(i) seriously disadvantage local or community groups from obtaining the new radio licences in regional markets,

Most of the issues mentioned in the amendment have been discussed in the cognate debate on all five Bills. I point out again that the amendment highlights the confusion in the Government about its policy on radio licences. I reiterate the situation that developed following the announcement in the Budget Speech of the tendering system for radio licences. The Government abandoned that system within four weeks and adopted a new proposal of establishment fees. That proposal is now the subject of a challenge in this place in that the Opposition is seeking the reference of the question of licence fees to the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, while I understand the Australian Democrats will move further amendments which would also change the method by which the establishment fees would be calculated and put into place. So we have a vastly confusing situation. I indicate that the Liberal and National parties believe that the only way to sort out the mess-the debacle-that has developed in the last several weeks over the licensing fees is for the Government to join with the Liberal and National parties and the Democrats in referring the whole matter to the Senate Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure for investigation and report.

There is plenty of time for this investigation to be undertaken. Because of the timetables arranged for applicants for licences that have already been called to face the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal and the time that would be taken to pay any fee that might be assessed for a successful applicant, it is clear that no money will be received by this Government in this financial year under any establishment fee system. Consequently, the Government will not achieve its Budget objective of $11m or whatever lower figure it has now agreed in conjunction with the Democrats, if this system were to apply. I think it is a significant point that there is plenty of time for the Senate Committee to investigate and report, because clearly this system will have no effect until the next financial year anyway. There will be plenty of time for legislation to be put in place during 1988.

For all those reasons the Liberal and National parties will not support the Democrat amendment and, if we fail in our move to have this Bill referred to the Senate Committee, we will oppose the legislation at a later stage. I make one other point. We will also move a committee stage amendment to ensure that the licence fee system, whether it be as agreed to by the Democrats or otherwise, does not apply to the four areas of Gosford, Geelong, Shepparton and the Gold Coast. Applications for these licences had been called prior to the Budget being announced on 15 September and had been part heard by the Tribunal at that point. This move is in the nature of retrospective legislation, to which the Liberal and National parties are opposed. Consequently, we believe that these particular areas, for which applications had been called, should be exempted from the effect of this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will not support this amendment. We have basically outlined the reasons for this in the cognate second reading debate. However, I would like to pick up one particular point made in Senator Messner's amendment, and that is the call for consultation with the industry. I reject the claim that there has not been consultation with the industry, at least since the announcement in the Budget Speech of the auction system. Certainly that measure was an Expenditure Review Committee grab at something that was seen to be lucrative, without much due thought for the consequences down the track. Since the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) has seen the light and since a great deal more consultation with the industry has taken place, I must reject the Opposition's claim that that has not happened.

SPEECH.PARA: All I can say is that it is quite possible that this complaint by the Opposition is genuine on the basis that it has not been consulted by the industry. If that is the case, Opposition members should ask themselves some questions about why this industry-one in which a great many genuine small business people have wanted to get involved-has not consulted them. Certainly these people have consulted the Australian Democrats and, as I understand it, they have consulted the Minister and the Department, on a daily basis and even many times a day, since the initial announcement in the Budget. So, as far as I can see, the Opposition's claim is without foundation. In fact, the end result of the successful passage of this legislation, as amended by amendments which I will move, will be due to that consultation with the industry and aspirants to the industry. For that reason at least, it seems to the Democrats that there is no justification for responding positively to this second reading amendment.

In the consultations we have had with the industry one thing has been very clear; that is, that the industry wants action. There are people who want to get into the industry and there are radio listeners out in regional areas who want and deserve increased service. The worst thing that could possibly happen is any further delay resulting from the matter being shunted off to a committee when a resolution can be achieved now. I have some serious reservations about what a committee, made up overwhelmingly of Liberal, Labor and National party members, might do to the whole package on radio ownership and control which has resulted from negotiations over this period. I believe that the package as a whole-this Bill and the subsequent legislation which will result from the Minister's statement on ownership and control-will be to the benefit of localism and diversity of ownership in the radio medium.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the reasons canvassed at the second reading stage, the Government will accept the Democrats' amendments. As Senator Powell has said, they will produce a result that is rather more progressive in character than was the case with the original Government establishment fee proposal, so that the applicants on the Gold Coast-on any view, a rich market-will pay somewhat more than would have been the case under the Government proposal. Equally, those in the other markets that will come up this year-Gosford, Geelong and Shepparton-will each pay rather less. In those numerous regional markets that will come up in the future, there is some reason to suppose that perhaps the entry barrier established by a fee calculated simply by reference to the gross revenue of the service area in question-which is the Government proposal-might have been a little high and might conceivably have resulted in the determination of the non-viability of the market in question, thus opening up the scenario that Senator Powell painted.

SPEECH.PARA: I say-as did Senator Powell-that this whole exercise has involved a very great deal of consultation with the industry.
