However, we believe that the regime that the Australian Democrats have proposed is a sensible one, is a workable one, and I accordingly indicate that we are prepared to accept it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This cheap and nasty deal which the Government has done with the Australian Democrats is just an attempt to salvage some respectability. Of course the people they are holding hostage are the local radio groups that are seeking to obtain licences in the Gosford, Geelong, Shepparton and Gold Coast areas. These licences have been issued well in advance of the proposed budgets for which people have put up quite a deal of money, and these people have committed many voluntary resources to obtaining the licence. They have found halfway through the process of getting it that the rules have been changed by the Government in its announcement in the Budget. We all recall the history of that matter. The Government announced in the Budget that it would forthwith start a tender or auction system for radio licences. That system lasted about five weeks. Then Senator Evans said: `Now we will have an establishment fee system and the formula will be based on 100 per cent of average gross earnings of the station that is applying for the licence'. That system lasted about another three weeks. Lo and behold, the Democrats have now done another little cheap deal and have sold out all their principles on localism, on local broadcasting, and have decided to ensure that people who are able to afford rather large sums of money for licences are the ones who will obtain them. The little people, the little community groups, the little organisations that have been struggling to get their resources, the applications and submissions together over a long period are the ones who will drop out of the application process.

SPEECH.PARA: Already we have seen in Geelong, Shepparton and Gosford several applicants who have announced their decision to drop out of the application process. They have found that the money being demanded by this Government is now far too much and way beyond their resources. So local radio will suffer as a result. That is a direct result of the Democrats' involvement with the Government in this cheap and nasty little operation.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a difference of tens of millions of dollars in those two columns.

—What the Australian Democrats have done is reduce the potential revenue from the Government's estimate of $11m to $9.2m, a huge saving for local interests. If that is the best that the Australian Democrats can bargain, they had better go away, get re-elected and try to do a decent job. That is what they would do if they were really concerned about the interests of local radio station broadcasters.

SPEECH.PARA: Later in the committee stage debate I will move an amendment to ensure that retrospectivity is not imposed by this Government upon licence applicants in the Geelong, Shepparton, Gold Coast and Gosford areas. Those areas should not have to suffer having the rules changed halfway through the race-as the Government has sought to do and which action is now supported by the Australian Democrats. That is the only legitimate position for any party in the Senate to take and, consequently, the Liberal and National parties are taking that position on this very important issue.

I have already pointed out that there is no likelihood that the Government will get any money during the 1988 financial year as a result of this new scheme. So why do the Democrats see fit to support the Government in introducing this legislation at this time when it will be of no value whatsoever to it this financial year. The $11m which the Government estimated it would get before June 1988 will not be obtained and, consequently, this whole measure is a farce. That is why the Liberal and National parties will at a later stage move-if we do not succeed in our endeavour to have this matter stopped dead in its tracks-to have the Broadcasting Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1987 referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure so that it can examine the whole question of the kinds of licence fees that ought to apply where new licences are put in place. That is the only fair way to address this question. We should look at giving organisations small and local in nature the opportunity of applying for a licence in the same way as the larger, more wealthy organisations can. We must find a way in which localism can be preserved and protected. I believe, as do a large number of potential and present applicants for licences, that the only way to do this is to have an in-depth analysis. The Government should be supporting this approach because, quite obviously, it will not get any money out of this measure this year anyway. What the Government should do is try to salvage some vestige of self-respect by calling together the people who are interested in this problem and making sure that it gets it right next time.

This legislation follows nearly two months of absolute disaster and confusion in the area of radio broadcasting licences. The Government ought to come to its senses. Having said that, we know that it is practically impossible for Senator Evans to come to his senses in this area but at least we might have expected something from the Democrats, that they would have stuck to their principles on this matter. Therefore, I express grave surprise at what they have done; they have sold out localism in radio right across Australia. The people of Australia will remember this and we will make sure that they remember it. Their local interests are being sold out for a mess of pottage by the Democrats. Who knows what the outcome of that little deal will be for the Democrats in future? The amendments as proposed have the effect of striking out from the effect of the Broadcasting Amendment Bill (No. 4) those applicants who have sought to obtain licences for the four areas for which applications were called prior to the Budget announcement of the change of system on 15 September. As we know, those four areas are Geelong, Shepparton, Gosford and the Gold Coast. What the Government did by announcing the changes to its system toward a tendering or an auctioning system for licences was to change the rules in midstream as they applied to those applicants who were in the course of making submissions or, as in most cases, had already made submissions to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. The Tribunal had set down a timetable by which it would hear the applications that had been submitted on behalf of those various groups.

It is wise to remind ourselves that those various groups represented, in the main, local community organisations and small business people in the local towns who got together to set up small companies or incorporated bodies to seek to obtain these licences. In other words, we are not talking about large corporate networks or operators in some far off capital cities seeking licences, but rather the small organisations with very local concerns, local ownership and interests in local programming. Those were the kinds of applicants who were seeking to obtain licences in this situation. Yet on 15 September the Government, without any consultation or any warning whatsoever, changed the rules by which the submissions were to be judged by the Tribunal and pulled the rug out from under the applicants' feet. The system which the Government adopted at that stage subsequently changed, as we know. We will not go through all of the procedures up to now, but we have just observed the passage of a further alternative, it being, I think, No. 3.5 of the options that the Government has considered, and which represents a deal which it did with the Australian Democrats in respect of a new system of establishment fees.

Our point is simply that those four areas for which applications had been called should be exempted from the legislation. The reason is obvious: the Government chose to change the rules in midstream. The organisations concerned had already put their applications in train and made submissions to the Tribunal, and the Tribunal was ready to hear their applications at the time these changes were announced. That is the reason for our opposition to the passage of this legislation in its present form. We seek to move to have those four areas struck out of the Bill so that they will not be retrospectively affected by this Government's heavy handed legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Governments often have to be in the position of changing policy in such a way that people are affected in ways they do not fully anticipate at the time. Were governments to be constricted from ever affecting anybody, policy making, particularly at Budget time, would clearly be drawn to a halt. One has to look at whether, in all the circumstances, the disadvantage that is caused is unreasonable in terms of the reasonable expectations and the overall position of the person who is affected by the legislation in question. In the context of this legislation the Government had to look in particular at the comparative justice that would be done as between the initial applicants for the four areas, to whom Senator Messner refers, and the subsequent applicants in future years, who would be in exactly the same position but who would have the misfortune, if they were treated differently, of having to pay a substantial additional impost simply by virtue of being unlucky enough to be down the track rather than in the first year of the new process.

SPEECH.PARA: We are talking about a new process. We are talking about a new category, a new bundle, of regional licences, the issuing of which was announced by my predecessor some little time ago and which process had barely got under way so far as the first four applicants were concerned. It is true that money had been spent in preparing the applications for an appearance before the Tribunal. In the form that the legislation now takes that appearance will still have to be before the Tribunal. It will not simply be a hurdle or threshold requirement; it will be a knock down, drag out argument of a familiar kind as to which of the applicants is the best possible. So that particular part of the argument we have heard, that the money would be wasted, has no possible application at all in the present circumstances.

The only remaining issue is whether it is somehow inequitable to require this category of applicants, who will not be getting their licences until some considerable number of months from now have elapsed, on the receipt of those licences to have to pay the fee that subsequent generations of applicants will have to pay. The Government has taken the view, which I think the Senate as a whole would share, that it would be far more inequitable for the licences which have already been called to be exempt from the fee than it would be to have them subject to the fee. The Tribunal is still a long way from reaching decisions on the four areas in question. As I said, that is some months away and only the initial stages of a complex inquiry process have been completed. The imposition of an establishment fee will not change the nature of the selection process. It simply adds an extra layer of impost and, as such, is indistinguishable from any other kind of tax increase or impost increase-from $500 in this instance to a very much more substantial fee-which is borne by taxpayers and members of the community generally.

This raises the whole question, which I do not want to go into, of whether we are talking about genuine commercial risk-takers here, or some special class of little Aussie battlers who ought not under any circumstances to be exposed to the responsibility, the obligation, of paying a substantial contribution to the community coffers for the right to make very substantial sums of money. I have taken the view throughout this debate that little Aussie battlers are pretty thin on the ground when it comes to applicants for commercial licences. If they are really imbued with a sense of overwhelming public spiritedness and just want to get into the radio business for the joy of communicating to their fellow rotarians, butchers, bakers and candlestick-makers in the country towns in question, they have the option of getting into public radio through community access provisions of the kind we were debating earlier.

What people are talking about here, what they are clamouring for, is the right to get into the commercial radio business and to make money from it. That does not mean the fees that are imposed should be impossibly high, should constitute a barrier to entry or should operate in the way Senator Powell was describing to limit, in effect, the capacity of the market to support new entrants, new competitors. That has to be a limiting factor, but the basic principles involved here are pretty clear cut. I find it difficult to believe that any kind of credible argument can be justified for giving these first four groups of applicants a free kick in the way that Senator Messner and the Opposition would propose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats do not support this amendment, either. I remind the Senate that there was an opportunity for the Senate to increase the terms of reference of a Senate committee back as far as February. TALK.START.PARA: —We are cognately debating a package of three Bills-the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill (No. 2), the Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill. Prior to dealing with these Bills, I must make a reference to the comments of Senator Gareth Evans in the chamber in the previous debate. Yet again Senator Evans has displayed a capacity to use sexist language or speak in a sexist way that is inconsistent with the principles his Government allegedly would want to follow. In response to Senator Powell, Senator Evans, perhaps unwittingly, said that he would resist commenting on the slurs on his Government's political manhood. I think he meant to say `political capacity'. Yet again we have another example of a senior Government Minister equating manhood with capacity. I would be interested to hear Senator Ryan's comments on that matter.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition will not oppose any of these Bills, but we have some serious concerns with some of them. To reflect those concerns we will move various amendments both at this, the second reading stage, and later at the committee stage. Let me first address the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill. The Bill makes some positive changes in the social security area which I will deal with shortly. But let me first outline why they are necessary. Welfare, of course, is a necessary part of government activity. It is through welfare that we can assist people in need. But the greatest assistance we can offer to people is to stop them falling into need in the first place. It is the economic management of this Government that, the coalition asserts, has resulted in more people being in need of welfare. For example, if we take the debt faced by this country on an individual basis, we find that individual Australians, putatively speaking, owe between $6,500 and $7,000 each. I am sure Australians would be stunned to realise that the corresponding amount in the United States of America is not $15,000 or $20,000 but about $1,800, a much smaller amount. Our inflation rate is about double that of Japan and the United States. Our current account deficit is the second worst in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries.

I mention these points because, as I say, it is all very well to make amendments in the social security area but it would be far more appropriate not to have to spend so much in the welfare area-not simply to cut as an exercise in expenditure reduction but as an acknowledgment that fewer people were in need. The coalition has a very positive record in the social security area. The relevant Ministers in the previous coalition Government, former Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle and Senator Chaney, made substantial contributions. It is apparent, from reading the debates in the other place and from the general comments that have been made, that many Government members believe that they are the only ones with compassion and understanding and that they alone can care for those in the community in need. I put it to the Senate that the contributions of Senator Guilfoyle and Senator Chaney in the previous Government show how mistaken Government members are in that view.

It is the coalition's view that the Government simply does not understand that the best way to help people in need is to ensure that they do not fall into need in the first place-as I have said, to ensure that the economy is sound, that business is confident and looking to expand so that individuals and their children can get jobs and not need welfare. Nonetheless, this Government consistently hides its head in the sand. Despite constant warnings, it ignores our growing debt, ignores the precarious situation of the international economy and continues to tell Australians that all is well.

The Opposition supports specific initiatives in this package. This package deals, for example, with amendments to the family welfare area, providing for what is now referred to as the family allowance supplement. People with an income of approximately $300 a week who in the past would have got $17 for a child under 13 years will now get $22. Whereas children between 13 years and 15 years would have previously qualified for a family income supplement of $17 a week, they will now qualify for a payment of $28. Amendments to rental assistance and improvements in the child disability allowance are also contained in this Bill. There is a patching up job with respect to sole parents. The Government made some changes earlier in the year and, having realised their effect on sole parents seeking to complete their study, has admitted its error and made some corrections in that regard. There are changes in the carer's pension and so on.

I think that future speakers will deal with certain matters that I will not go into detail about now. Suffice to say that basically the Opposition supports the details in the package of these Bills. However, there are some regrettable aspects and I will return to them. First, I will make some comments about the veterans' area. It is regrettable that, while the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 does do some things that should be done, it does not provide the extra benefits to servicewomen from Korea, Malaya and Vietnam, even though perhaps they are very few in number, and it does not address the situation of the defence service home loan scheme as perhaps it should.

The Opposition is particularly concerned with the removal of the discretion in hardship cases with respect to the 2.5 per cent income deeming provisions. Our concern was reflected in the form of a second reading amendment in the other place. In this place, we will seek to refer that portion of the Bill dealing with this matter to the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs. Accordingly, I move:
At the end of the motion add:
``, and the provisions of subclause 11 (2) be referred to the Standing Committee on Community Affairs''.

The reference of clause 11 (2) to that Committee will permit a further discussion of this contentious area. A large number of people believe that they would be very unfairly affected by this legislation were it passed with clause 11 (2) as it stands. The coalition understands that the Government needs to have this Bill passed in order to allow, for example, the family assistance supplements to be paid. Therefore, a satisfactory way of addressing the problem is to refer clause 11 (2), which deals with our concerns, to a committee and the rest of the Bill can be given passage and it can then go back to the other place. Having moved that amendment, I indicate that, during the committee stage, we will move that clause 11 (2) be removed. That procedure will allow the passage of the Bill while clause 11 (2) can be considered by the Committee.

The second Bill in this package of three is the Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987, which basically deals with the extension of pharmaceutical benefits concessions to a variety of groups. Senator Puplick will canvass these matters later. There is a temptation to address the disaster of this Government's health administration across the nation and, in particular, in the Australian Capital Territory. For the benefit of all concerned, I will resist that temptation. The people affected by the disastrous health administration know how badly they are affected and it appears that when the coalition, health administrators and people with an interest in this area talk to the Government about problems with health, their comments fall on deaf ears.

I noted the comments in the other place-I think they were from Ms McHugh, but they may not have been-which referred to the Opposition's use of scare tactics on social security matters. Without having the direct quote in front of me, all I can say is that the honourable member concerned basically said that with all the scaremongering that the coalition had done, pensioners were probably surprised that they still had their gold teeth. When one considers the letters that were sent to very many pensioners as part of the Government's scare campaign to get itself re-elected, this did not seem to be an appropriate course of action for a member of the House of Representatives and a member of the Australian Labor Party to take. I draw the Senate's attention to one paragraph of the letter that was sent to pensioners in marginal seats and it reads:
Now Mr Howard wants to reduce pensions and services you receive so that he can pay tax cuts to the well off and restore free lunches and other untaxed fringe benefits to them.

I am sure that honourable senators are aware of the fact that no suggestion was made by the coalition that pensions would be reduced. This Government took the opportunity to write to pensioners in a clear and unambiguous way saying that Mr Howard wanted to reduce their pensions. If that is not frightening pensioners and using the social security debate as a means to win votes rather than addressing the substantive issues, I do not know what is. When I read the comments of the relevant Labor Party member in the other place that we had supposedly used scare tactics to the extent that pensioners would be surprised that they still had their gold teeth, I was somewhat resentful, because those comments came from a member of a party which, at election time, chose to target the pensioners quite specifically in a fearmongering campaign. Further, it chose quite specifically to misrepresent the aims of the coalition in order to win itself some more votes without being concerned about the effect on pensioners of its scare campaign that pensions were to be cut.

I now turn to the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1987, which deals primarily with the targeting of Commonwealth funds for hospitals and other related matters, including the requirement for the provision of information by nursing homes. The Opposition will seek to refer this Bill to the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs. Further, I foreshadow that the coalition will move that the motion for the second reading of this Bill be amended by adding the following at the end of the motion:

``, but the Senate is of the opinion that the Hawke Labor Government's autocratic approach to aged care is jeopardising the successful implementation of its policy in Australia, and has seriously threatened stability and future improvements in this most important area, especially by-
(a) its refusal to consult on this legislation with voluntary and private sector providers of aged care;
(b) the removal of ministerial discretion in reviewing fees determination decisions;
(c) the unnecessary, costly and excessive reporting requirements imposed by the Bill;
(d) the duplication of State Government regulations relating to standards; and
(e) the exclusion of private investment from the provision of hostel accommodation''.

These words adequately reflect the coalition's concern about this Bill. The coalition is very much concerned with the lack of consultation on these matters and, for that matter, those in other portfolios where the lack of consultation makes an absolute mockery of the much talked of desire of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) for consensus. I have canvassed the primary areas of concern for the Opposition and I will leave it to my colleagues to address other specific matters which they may choose to raise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening we are debating a package of Bills and I wish to address my remarks in particular to the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987. As a member of the Government, naturally I support this Bill. Also I am pleased to support it because it will enable the Government to introduce its long awaited and major family assistance package. The Bill implements Government initiatives on social security which were announced in May when the economic statement was brought down by the Government and which were mentioned also in the 1987 Budget Speech of the Treasurer (Mr Keating). The most important initiative introduced by this legislation is the $500m family package, which is the centrepiece and the main thrust of this Government's attack on the scourge of poverty in the Australian community.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bills provide for the expenditure in the current financial year of some $215m on the family package and that will be the opening shot in the battle against poverty. That opening shot will bring a real increase in the standard of living for many hundreds of thousands of Australian children. It is very important to note that the legislation actually targets the children of low income working families, that is, families whose head is in the work force as distinct from and in addition to those families whose head depends on social security payments. The package targets children in particular, because in Australia, regrettably, poverty is linked significantly with the presence of children.

The Government recognises that low income families in Australia have shared the burden of economic restraint that was forced on us by difficult international circumstances. The family assistance package that is provided under this legislation will give a substantial boost to the disposable income of low income families in Australia, and thus it will bring about greater fairness in the Australian community; it will add to the level of social justice in our community. The family package is a major redistributive measure introduced by the Hawke Government. It will incorporate a new system of child payments called the family allowance supplement, which is to be introduced this month as a central weapon in our attack on poverty, particularly on child related poverty in the Australian community.

The family allowance supplement will replace the existing family income supplement, which is at present $17 a week per child. The new family allowance supplement will total $22 a week per child and it will operate along the same lines as the former family income supplement. The family allowance supplement, in effect, will be a top-up for child payments to low income families and, as I pointed out previously, particularly to low income families whose head is actually working in the work force but is receiving a low wage or salary. The means test for the family allowance supplement will be relaxed so that thousands more low income families in Australia will be eligible for the new payments. Tens of thousands more families will be eligible for the family allowance supplement than are presently eligible for the family income supplement.

The new system provides for cash payments, thus adding to the cash in hand and disposable income of low income families. By making cash payments, we will enable those parents of children to spend the money as required according to the family's priorities. Families earning less than $300 a week will receive a payment of $22 a week per child but, as was pointed out in the explanatory memorandum in relation to this Bill, families with older children will receive $28 a week for every child aged 13, 14 or 15 years. Social security pensioners and beneficiaries currently receive a child benefit payment of $17 a week, and those child payments will be increased to $22 a week in line with the payments provided under the family allowance supplement arrangements.

A family earning less than $300 a week with two children aged under 13 years and one child of, say, 14 years will receive the existing family allowance payment of $23.58 a week together with the new supplement of $72, which represents a large increase in the disposable cash payments from the Government to that family. The $300 income threshold for full payment of the family allowance supplement is increased by $12 a week for every additional child. Therefore, larger families can earn more than $300 a week in wages but still qualify for the full payment under the family allowance supplement. For example, the income limit for a family with three children to receive the full supplement will be $324 a week.

Some families earning more than $300 a week-in fact, well above $300 a week-will still be able to obtain some payment under the family allowance supplement; every dollar earned above the income threshold reduces the supplement by 50c. It is interesting to note that the income limit for some payment of supplement rises well into the $20,000 a year range where families have a number of children. For example, a single income working family with four young children will still be eligible for some payment under the new arrangements until its income reaches $512 a week. Therefore, we are looking at an income of about $25,000 or $26,000 a year, and that is well into the middle class in Australia, certainly in my State at least. Those families will receive some payment under this supplement arrangement. The relaxed income threshold for the new family assistance package in comparison to the old family income supplement will help to alleviate so-called poverty traps in the Australian social welfare system-that is, the high effective marginal tax rates that result from a combination of income tax rates and withdrawal rates for pensions and benefits.

Families on low wages will be able to receive the full payment of family assistance supplement and maintain it until their wage goes above the income limit. In implementing this system, the Government has provided low income families with an incentive to remain, or to try to find work, in the Australian work force. The family assistance supplement is the biggest single dollar increase that has ever been made to child payments in Australia. The new payments will be tax free and will be complemented by other measures in the package, including rental assistance of up to $15 a week for low income families who rent from private landlords. As a matter of interest, I point out that this payment is the first that any government has provided to help low income families-that is, low income families whose head is in the work force-with the cost of private rent. At present parents who receive unemployment benefits and who are renting privately must wait for six months before receiving the maximum rent assistance of $10 a week. Under the family package they will be eligible immediately for up to $15 a week in rental assistance.

The family package also takes heed of the costs associated with the rearing of disabled children in the Australian community. It introduces a special payment for families with disabled children. In fact, last month a new child disability allowance of $112 a month replaced the old handicapped child allowance of $92 a month. The new child disability allowance will be paid with no income test and will not distinguish between so-called severely and substantially disabled children. The family package is a significant measure to assist children in need in the Australian community. It builds upon the previous increases to child payments that have been made by this Government, that is, child payments in respect of the children of social welfare pensioners and beneficiaries. It is important to note that since this Government has been in office child payments for the children of pensioners and beneficiaries have increased by about 70 per cent. When we came to office in 1983 child payments in respect of the children of pensioners and beneficiaries amounted to $10 a week for each child; they are now $17 a week and, as a result of the family package they will be increased further from $17 to $22 a week. Therefore, in the life of this Government, child payments have risen from $10 to $22 a week, or by 120 per cent. I believe that that is a major supplement to the disposable income of social welfare pensioners and beneficiaries.

In conclusion, I believe that the Hawke Government has made real progress in reversing the neglect of the poor that occurred under the Fraser-Howard Government. Labor has acted to boost, in real terms, payments to pensioners, the unemployed, the children of pensioners and beneficiaries, and other Australians in need. Unlike the previous Liberal Government, we have not turned our back on those in need in the Australian community. The Government has protected the living standards of those who depend on social welfare assistance. In addition, this family package will increase and extend financial assistance to low income working families and I believe that the family assistance package that is to be introduced under this legislation is tangible proof of the Hawke Government's commitment to ending child poverty in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this cognate debate I rise to speak on the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987. My comments will be confined to the veterans' entitlements aspects of the Bill and my colleague Senator Powell will address the Australian Democrats' concerns with the social security aspect of this Bill. This Bill has evoked great interest among veterans. It has certainly attracted the attention of those who frequently legally represent veterans at several of the levels of appeal. I have been surprised at the intensity of the lobbying which as been directed at me as the Australian Democrats spokesperson on veterans' affairs. Indeed, I have been convinced that several critical amendments to this Bill are necessary. I now foreshadow that I will move amendments at the committee stage of the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a coincidence that this Bill reaches the Senate at about the same time as the annual report of the Repatriation Commission and Department of Veterans' Affairs (DVA), which was tabled in the Senate yesterday and which I read with great interest. The annual report of the Repatriation Commission and Department of Veterans' Affairs understandably cites the Department's considerable achievements and the Commission's achievements in the past year, many of which are worthy of our congratulations.

In presenting this report, the President of the Commission paid tribute to the outgoing Minister, Senator Arthur Gietzelt, for his `genuine concern for the veteran community and an energetic quest for improved practices and more effective delivery of services'. This sentiment has been echoed over and over again in comments that have been made to me by veterans' representatives who have lobbied me intensively in recent months. However, I think it is true to say that there is considerable ambivalence among veterans. They feel that, despite the fact that they have been represented by a Minister who truly had their interests at heart, their conditions have steadily declined under this Government and that in these demanding economic times they are seen as an easy mark. Reluctantly, I sense that I must report that there is very real suspicion that the Government has decided to save dollars in this area of expenditure. So there is very genuine ambivalence among veterans.

Their suspicion that dollars are being saved in relation to their services in not without foundation. The veterans cite the fact that even a sympathetic Minister such as Senator Gietzelt was unable, because of Cabinet pressure, to fulfil critical promises such as that which he made in his address to the sixty-eighty annual New South Wales State congress on 30 May 1984, when he stated:
Let me also say firmly, that it is not the intention to change the onus of proof which rests on the Commonwealth in deciding if a disability is service related.

Of course, it is apparent that the changes to the standard of proof provisions were a clear breach of that undertaking regarding a most critical procedure. I think it was despite the best intentions of the Minister of the day that those changes come into effect.

I refer to a brief paper which has been prepared by and circulated among veterans' groups in New South Wales and which is entitled Summary of Losses by the Veterans 1985-87. I take this summary on trust and invite the correction of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) if any of the points made in it are in error. It states, among other things, that rumours of pending erosion of veterans' benefits first became a reality in the economic statement of May 1985. Unfortunately, the veterans' fears were confirmed in the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986. The realities of veterans' new circumstances are still unfolding, but I will state some of the realities facing veterans in 1987. Firstly, they are facing the deletion of the dependants pension and, secondly, the removal from the DVA repatriation schedule pharmaceuticals of war widows and their dependants and service pensioners-that is Red Card holders-by the transferring of these entitlements to the social security national health pharmaceuticals list.

Thirdly, veterans face a reduction in dental benefits relating to expensive dental treatments such as crown and bridge work. Fourthly, beneficiaries are now obliged to have their monetary benefits paid directly into a bank or building society account. The fifth observed loss is the deletion of the 10 per cent disability pension assessment previously allowed when glasses were prescribed. The sixth observed loss is the restriction on the issue of glasses. Previously two pairs were allowed but that has been reduced to one pair, and there are also other associated losses in benefits to the partially blind veteran. The seventh observed loss is that the intermediate or special rate pension rates disability pensions are not protected by the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986. If a veteran suffers a new disability which requires nursing home care, the veteran must decide whether he can fulfil all of the criteria contained in sections 23 or 24 of the Act. Either way, the veteran loses benefits, whether it be a nursing home care benefit-in which case he will incur an expense-or a reduction in pension.

The eighth observed loss to veterans in this list of 18 is that veterans have lost benefits in respect of reimbursement of substantial costs incurred in obtaining medical opinion in support of a claim or an application. Paragraph 14a (1) of the abolished repatriation regulations provided for such reimbursement, but section 85 of the Veterans' Entitlements Act makes no such provision. Indeed, veterans are being refused such reimbursements, so they now incur the total expense of servicing their claim or application.

Section 29 of the Veterans' Entitlements Act refers to the `guide to the assessment of rates of veterans pensions' and specifically provides that this guide is binding on the Commission, the board of review or the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Veterans have lost the benefit of independent medical opinion in respect of impairment ratings. The determining authorities' hands are tied. They cannot alter an impairment rating, irrespective of how much medical evidence the departmental medical officer (DMO) might muster in support of that opinion.

The tenth observed loss is that the veterans' children education scheme is now means tested. The eleventh is that the intellectually handicapped dependants allowance has been deleted and the twelfth is that the social security portion of pensions related to war widows has been frozen. I have now listed 12 of the 18 losses listed in the paper distributed by veterans' organisations. The thirteenth loss is that travelling and milage allowances have been restricted, and the fourteenth is that the defence re-establishment agricultural and loans schemes have been terminated. The automatic right of admission to a private hospital without prior approval by a DMO has been lost. A nursing home patient contribution rate will apply from 1 January 1988 for veterans who are resident in nursing homes or who are receiving psychiatric care for war-related disabilities. This is the first time in the long history of the Repatriation Commission and the Department of Veterans' Affairs that a veteran has had to contribute towards the cost of hospitalisation for war-related disabilities. It is proposed to abolish the defence service home loans scheme. There has been a reduction in the treatment of skin care, podiatry and physiotherapy. That completes a comprehensive list of 18 ways in which veterans have been disadvantaged in the period 1985 to 1987.

Of the 18 examples of veterans' losses I have just cited, one stands out. I refer, of course, to the callous decision to charge totally and permanently incapacitated (TPI) veterans in nursing homes approximately $111 a week. I remind honourable senators of my recent question on this matter and of the Minister's reply that the measure was in the interests of equality between all pensioners. Those who become totally and permanently incapacitated, many for most of their lives, as a result of serving their country have always been considered as warranting special attention, and justly so. We in the Australian Democrats are disgusted by this decision, which presents these special Australians with a happy New Year present-a bill of $111 a week for the rest of their lives. To make it worse, this coincides with massive and extravagant expenditure on bicentennial celebrations commemorating achievements of the country for which they made such enormous sacrifices.

Since this extraordinary and callous imposition flows from the Minister's powers under section 90 of the Act, I foreshadow that the Australian Democrats will move an amendment in the committee stage to force the Minister to apply such variation through regulation. The passage of this amendment, which will, of course, need the support of the coalition, will allow us to stop this hideous imposition upon this special and deserving group of veterans. We find it difficult to muster the words to cast judgment on the nature of the decision to impose that weekly penalty of $111 on totally and permanently incapacitated Australian veterans.

The Vietnam veterans are also wary of the Government's ongoing attitude to veterans. They have much to lose from the erosion of veterans' entitlements. A recent letter from the National President of the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia, which was addressed to the Minister for Veterans Affairs and circulated to all members of parliament, expressed deep concern that the vital counselling service has not got the staffing and financial support it urgently needs. This is despite six separate positive reports on the service's effectiveness and importance since its inception in 1982. The letter contrasts the reluctance to expand the counselling service from its present staff of 35 to a required 40-plus, with the extraordinary increases in departmental staff numbers in the last decade. The Hogg report, which I recently tabled in the Senate-a report on the findings of the Royal Commission on the Use and Effects of Chemical Agents on Australian Personnel in Vietnam-cites an expanded counselling service as crucial to Vietnam veterans.
In summary, veterans claim that a vastly enlarged department is administering what they see as a markedly reduced range of inferior services. One ex-prisoner of war veteran said to me recently:
The trouble with this Government is that they think we oldies all suffer from Alzheimer's disease but we really only suffer from old timers' disease.
I think that captures the ambivalence which many veterans feel towards the attitude of the present Government.

I now turn from general objections to some of the more specific aspects of this Bill. Clauses 63 and 64 have attracted special attention from veterans' legal advocates. Amendments to these clauses are aimed at ensuring a continuation of the rights of TPI special rate pensioners beyond their 65th birthday, since legal judgments have threatened this continuity. Legal counsel of veterans' groups argue that the provisions of clause 63, which introduces the concept of the application day, fail to preserve continuity and, even worse, will make it extremely difficult to seek the special rate successfully in the future. Departmental legal opinion does not foresee such difficulties. So there appear to be two genuinely separate interpretations of the legal effect of the amendments inherent in the Bill. I find the arguments of the veterans' legal counsel convincing, and will move amendments aimed at resolving what are seen as potential serious problems. I will justify these amendments in the committee stage of the Bill.

It is argued that the introduction of an application day imposes an absolute time limit, which is unjust in that it imposes a limitation of action-that is a legal term-inappropriate in this legal context and not typical of legislation at large. In almost all other areas there is provision for discretion, but the introduction of the application day amendment in fact removes discretion from appealing veterans. The Veterans Advocates Advisory Group briefly summarises its objections to clauses 63 and 64 in a letter sent to most, if not all, senators. Its first observation is:
All the criteria of the TPI must be considered on only one day.

You will be aware, Mr Acting Deputy President, that there are three criteria which must be fulfilled. These legal advocates argue that it is virtually impossible to fulfil them on one day, and therefore the implication of the application day provision is that it imposes a potential penalty upon applications. Its second observation is:
Most veterans are unaware of when is the most appropriate time to lodge their application and may inadvertently disentitle themselves.
The Group's third observation states:
Even a single day's difference might disentitle a veteran; there is no discretion.
There is no discretion against disentitlement. The fourth observation is:
There are Sections in the Act which, by their nature, pre-suppose views up to the date of hearing/review. These clauses are inconsistent with those Sections.
In other words, it observes an inherent contradiction in a legal sense between the requirements of this amendment and the requirements of the sections of the Act. Its fifth observation states:
Like suffering and loss due to war service should merit like compensation. That is not achieved when compensation can depend simply on when the Department receives a piece of paper.
That is, rather than upon the inherent merit of the application. Finally, it makes the observation:

Under the proposed legislation, if there are two veterans otherwise equal retiring early, one lodging an application on the last day of employment, the other one month after that time, the first will be disentitled whilst the other will not. It may be years before appeals procedures for the first are concluded and further applications will fail because of increased age and length of time out of the workforce. This legislation is retrospective and is therefore grossly unfair to such veterans.

There I complete my quoting of the Veterans Advocates Advisory Group. I am sufficiently convinced by these arguments to foreshadow amendments which I believe to be adequate enough and designed to rectify these foreseen difficulties. I am at a loss to see why such amendments would be unacceptable, especially to the coalition, which I have been advised is inclined to oppose them. You are probably aware, Mr Acting Deputy President, that at the moment women are discriminated against in this legislation. I will move to correct that and to give service women the same entitlement as service men. I cannot imagine that this amendment will be opposed. With reference to this anomaly, in the debate of this issue in the other place on 18 November Mr Adermann cited the cost of such inclusions as a mere $65,000 per annum. Rejection of these foreshadowed amendments must serve only to heighten suspicion among veterans as to the motives of the Government, and perhaps also of the Opposition, the alternative government. I can, of course, hear the outcry that it is all right for us Democrats who are able to be critical without having to live with the consequences. That is true to a degree. We are indeed in a unique position to keep governments, and even oppositions, honest. No doubt that is why veterans and others are now lobbying us so heavily on this issue and other issues. Of course, it is not strictly true that we do not have to live with the consequences. We will all have to live with the consequences of our stance on this Bill and the proposed amendments. I sense that the consequences will be considerable.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this evening to speak on behalf of the Opposition on one of the Bills we are debating in this cognate debate, the Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987. The purpose of this Bill is to amend the definition of `pensioner', `concessional beneficiary' and certain categories of disadvantaged persons in the National Health Act and the Health Insurance Act. The amendments will extend eligibility to free or concessional benefits, that is, the $2.50 pharmaceutical benefits, from 1 September 1987 to 31 December 1988, first, of those no longer eligible for the class A widow's or supporting parent's pensions but who satisfy certain conditions for eligibility for free pharmaceutical benefits; secondly, of persons aged 16 and 17 years who from 1 January 1988 will receive a job search allowance instead of unemployment benefit; and, thirdly, of persons affected by the new family allowance supplement from 13 December 1987. Children under the age of 13 years will attract a benefit of $22 a week and there are higher rates for children aged 13 to 15 years.

SPEECH.PARA: The cost to the Government for class A widows and supporting parent beneficiaries with full time dependent students is estimated, in the Government's own calculations, to be in the vicinity of $200,000. There is no cost, we are told, associated with the changes to the job search allowance and the family allowance supplement. An amendment to section 5b of the Health Insurance Act changes the basis for determining the level of allowable income for a person to be classed as a disadvantaged person, that is, a person on a low income. Such a person is entitled to concessional pharmaceutical benefits. With the implementation of the family allowance supplement, provision is made for the rate of additional benefit for a child to be fixed at $34 for the time being, with the power to set a differing amount by regulation. The formula for eligibility to be classified as a disadvantaged person if one is married is twice the weekly rate, plus the additional benefit for dependent children, plus $20, plus the weekly income `cut-out'.

Amendments to section 5d of the Act allow for those people now included in the category of job search allowances instead of unemployment benefits to be eligible for concessional pharmaceutical benefits. The National Health Act is amended to allow for a definition of `pensioner' to include a person being paid a job search allowance under sub-section 117a (2) of the Social Security Act. Persons receiving a job search allowance will not transfer to a sickness benefit if temporarily unfit for work but will remain on a job search allowance. This will allow them to be eligible for free pharmaceutical benefits and, therefore, not to be disadvantaged compared with those in receipt of sickness benefits. The National Health Act is further amended to extend eligibility for free pharmaceutical benefits from 1 September 1987 to 31 December 1988 for class A widows and sole parents with full time students aged from 16 to 24 years who are no longer eligible for a pension. Finally, the definition of `concessional beneficiary' in section 84 is amended to cover persons in receipt of a job search allowance.

Those are the primary amendments which are made to the various health legislation provisions. The Opposition does not in any way oppose the changes that are being made. I do, however, want to make one brief observation, which arises from the tabling today of the annual report of the former Commonwealth Department of Health. I draw attention to the following statement on page 35 of the report:
During 1986-87 the Health Insurance Commission processed claims for 128.5 million services.

That is an extraordinarily large number. The number recorded in 1985-86 was 121.4 million. In 1984-85 it was 113 million. In 1981-82 the figure was 93 million, and in 1982-83 it was 96.2 million. It is true that the 1981 to 1983 figures reflects not the entire Australian population, because at that stage approximately 1.8 million Australians who would normally have to be included in one's calculations were not covered by health insurance arrangements. But, of that 1.8 million, approximately 30 per cent chose to stay out of the scheme because they were young people under the age of 30 and, therefore, more likely to be fit and less likely to be consumers of health care services or indeed need those services. It is certainly not valid simply to compare the pre- and post-Medicare situations as far as the number of health services provided is concerned.

It is relevant to compare the rate of growth of the annual utilisation of health care services over the period prior to Medicare and over the post-Medicare period. This evening I seek to draw attention to the fact that this Government has encouraged the Medicare system to operate by encouraging the uncontrolled usage of the system to the financial disadvantage of the Australian health care system and of the Australian public purse. Those 128.5 million services had a Medicare benefit cost to revenue of $2,881.8m, of which 51.8 per cent were claimed through direct billing by medical practitioners. The report of the former Department of Health goes on to claim credit for the fact that the bulk billing proportion of Medicare rebates has grown steadily since the introduction of Medicare from 45.2 per cent in 1984-85.

It may be a cause of self-congratulation on the part of the Government that both the utilisation of bulk billing and the utilisation of services are increasing considerably faster than the natural rate of growth of the population, even making allowances for the aging of the population and, therefore, presumably the greater call upon health care services. I simply wish to point out in these very brief remarks indicating our support for the legislation before us that this continued burgeoning of the use of the health insurance system and of the number of services provided under the Medicare system simply cannot be allowed to continue without having enormously adverse effects upon the revenues of this country. The figure of 128.5 million services in 1986-87, as reported in the Department's annual report, is not a statistic to be proud of. It is a result of the deliberate health care policies pursued by this Government, which the Opposition believes are fatally flawed and which will have to be addressed as one of the prime matters of urgency upon our return to office.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my remarks to certain amendments to the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987. There are around the chamber tonight certain amendments which will probably emanate from the Australian Democrats and which touch on clauses 63 and 64 of the Bill, and also certain matters affecting servicewomen's entitlements to benefits under the repatriation legislation. The Opposition regards this as a Budget Bill introduced by the Government. Consequently its passage demands, and will receive, the support of honourable senators. Matters of great consequence will be raised and we in the Liberal and National parties will address those issues as a matter of policy development in the next year or two. We shall be examining the entitlements of various people such as servicewomen in present circumstances, but we do not believe that the legislation and the form of amendments proposed tonight by the Democrats are the appropriate vehicles for ensuring that those benefits are put in place. This is a matter of Budget legislation and the Government is entitled to its Budget. Therefore, we must wear the consequences.

SPEECH.PARA: In regard to clauses 63 and 64 affecting totally and permanently incapacitated (TPI) pensions, the Opposition has been in communication with the Returned Services League (RSL). There is some legal difficulty of interpretation as to whether TPIs are being appropriately catered for in the legislation. Our advice from the RSL is that it regards the legislation as suitable for passage, and consequently the outcomes which might flow from the legislation in due course should be subject to continuing monitoring by a suitable committee to ensure that all the intended consequences of the legislation occur. For that reason we believe that the legislation should pass in its original form. Therefore, if further amendments are proposed, the Opposition will not support them in the Senate.

This legislation has generated a great deal of community concern, especially among veterans. This is a matter about which all honourable senators should be concerned, particularly those in the Liberal and National parties. We note in passing that the legislation does not address the position of servicewomen who served in Korea, Malaya and Vietnam, and we believe that those matters should be examined in the course of policy development by any party represented in this Parliament. We shall certainly consider those matters in the coming months. The Government should be considering those omissions and making statements. We wonder why that is not happening. Clearly, a great deal of concern and demand have been generated on those questions in the community. Another area of concern relates to the defence service home loans scheme which has remained in limbo since May last year. It does not appear to have received any attention. Therefore, we are not sure what the Government finally intends in this regard.

Finally, my colleague Senator Vanstone has addressed herself to the other parts of this legislation in respect of social security beneficiaries and those who are subject to the assets test. These provisions also affect veterans who fall within the same category. Those veterans who are subject to the new tests that will be applied by the Government hopefully will be relieved by the amendment which the Opposition has already moved. The amendment seeks to alleviate the position of such people. We hope that the Democrats will support the amendment, and indeed we implore them to do so. The point at issue is simply that we seek to refer that part of the Bill which refers to the assets test changes to the Standing Committee on Community Affairs. This relates to the social security legislation. From my reading of the amendment, I believe that it covers veterans also. I should like to hear the Minister for Local Government (Senator Reynolds) comment on this point. I shall seek to ensure that an appropriate amendment covers that aspect as well.

The Government amendments regarding veterans, the assets test and social security beneficiaries need redress. The Government has been heavy-handed and has not considered the hardship to farmers and others with illiquid assets who find themselves without income and unable to do anything about those assets. Consequently, they will be caught by the new provisions whereby 2.5 per cent of the value of their assets will be taken into account as income and treated as part of the income test. I believe our amendment to be appropriate for the investigation of this matter. Clearly, this problem is generating great concern in the community, and no doubt it will receive more and more attention in the weeks and months ahead as it gains steam. The Government might consider it fair to hit with this kind of special test people who are stuck with illiquid assets and who have no other form of income. The truth is that this is unfair, unreasonable and brought in at a time when desperate situations are starting to develop in this country, especially with regard to illiquid assets. We all know that the state of the stock market and markets generally will lead to people being unable to realise assets. Consequently, this will become of greater and greater concern to the community as weeks and months go on. For that reason I have moved the amendment on behalf of the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight the Senate is debating the Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill and the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill (No. 2) cognately. This has been forced upon us by the Government's mishandling of the business of the Senate, which has resulted in a buildup of legislation to be dealt with before Christmas. Because of this I will be concentrating on just the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill (No. 2). We were told in the second reading speech to the Bill of the wonderful record of the Australian Labor Party in the payment of money to assist families with children. We were told that that New South Wales Labor Government had introduced a form of child endowment. Of course, what we were not told was that it was the Menzies Liberal Government in 1941 that first brought in child endowment in the Federal sphere, and it was a Curtin Government which later extended it to cover Aborigines and people with custody of orphans. However, it will go down in history that it was the Hawke Labor Government that tore down the concept that all families, in recognition of the added cost of raising children, should receive an amount of money to assist with the additional financial burden. The means testing of family allowances is only one of the many steps the Government has taken that have reduced the living standards of families in Australia during the term of the Labor Government. I would like to read from the report of a review the Government commissioned. The preface states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Social Security Review was established by the Minister for Social Security, the Honourable Brian Howe, MP in February 1986 . . . Associate Professor Bettina Cass of the University of Sydney was appointed Consultant Director of the Review . . .

She was given three major aspects of social security policy to cover and the one we are dealing with tonight is income support for families with children. As I said, the Government commissioned this review. I shall read a few extracts from the report because I think it is very important for the people of Australia to understand the review's recommendations. Under the heading `Why do governments support families with children?' it says:

Firstly, governments assist all families with their expenditure on children's needs, in recognition of the increased costs which they must meet. Secondly, governments provide additional assistance to low income families whose circumstances make it very hard for them to be in the workforce or whose workforce earnings are low.

It must be remembered that this review was commissioned by the Government and the report was put out in October 1986, before the May mini-Budget and before the Budget decisions which did away with general family support by the Government. The report goes on:

A fundamental principle of ``family equity'', meaning ``a fair share for families'', has been established through these programs. This holds that it is appropriate for the social security and taxation systems to redistribute income to families in recognition of the increased costs which they bear in carrying out the essential and socially valuable tasks of child-rearing.
When dealing with horizontal equity, which means a fair share for all families, the report says:
This principle recognises that at any level of family income people with children incur greater costs and have greater needs than do people without children at the same level of income.
That is pretty clear and sounds pretty fair. The report then goes on to vertical equity, which means additional support for low income families. It says:
The objective is to provide increased assistance to low income families so as to protect families with children from poverty.

The summary says that horizontal equity is to provide a fair share for all families, while vertical equity is to provide adequate support to low income families. Intra-family equity is to provide resources to the parent primarily responsible for the child's care. So assistance is usually given to the mother. Incentives are to provide family assistance which does not discourage parents' work force participation and income earnings. I would like to go back to that at some later stage because I think that that is a very important point that Bettina Cass has stressed early in the report. The report goes on:
all families have experienced a decline in their disposable incomes relative to individuals and couples without children.

So the report recognises that all families have experienced a decline in their living standards compared with individuals and couples without children. Again, that is a very important acknowledgment made in the report. The report goes on:
. . . some 38 per cent of recipient families-
that is, families receiving family allowance-
have adjusted incomes-
that is, taking children into account compared with couples without children-
So 38 per cent of recipient families have adjusted incomes below $16,000 a year. The report continues:
75 per cent have adjusted incomes below $28,000. Only 7 per cent have adjusted incomes above $40,000.
Again, I think that that is very important information. It proves just what a financial burden it is for a family with children compared with couples without children. The report says:
One of the key areas of concern is the deterioration in the real value of family income support which results from the non-indexation of both payments and tax measures.
Again, it is pointed out that family allowance over a period of years has deteriorated because of lack of indexation. Bettina Cass stresses reducing work disincentives. The report says:
Low income families with children receiving social security can face severe ``poverty traps'' and consequent work disincentives.
That is very important because this is just what the Government has succeeded in doing. The report goes on:

As noted previously, income-testing or taxing family allowance payments would involve redistribution of resources between families. This would not address the problem of maintaining the disposable incomes of all families with children as a form of tax equity.
It is terribly important to understand that Bettina Cass has said that it is not on to means test or tax the family allowance out of the hands of the mother. In conclusion she states:

In summary, when formulating future directions for reform of family income support programs in Australia we need to address the fundamental objective of redistributing income to all families with children so as to improve and maintain their position in the tax/transfer systems. As a community we need to reassess the value which we place on children and focus again on the concept of the shared parental/community obligation to recognise the increased costs which parents bear.

That seems to me to be very just and very clear on the part of Bettina Cass. But what did the Government do? It ignored her recommendations completely. It ignored the horizontal equity and chose to means test the family allowance. Not only that; it also chose to go down the path of creating further poverty traps and disincentives for families on low incomes to earn additional money. I will come back to that in a few minutes.

We are told by this Government that it cares about the family. What utter rubbish! It has never cared about the family; that has not been its particular priority. I will give a little proof of that by looking at what we did when in government to assist families. This can be shown by looking at how the dependent spouse rebate was increased. When we came to government in 1975 the dependent spouse rebate was $400 a year-a paltry sum. In 1976-77 we increased it to $500. In 1977-78 it was $555; in 1978-79 it was $597; in 1980-81 it was $800; and in 1981-82 it was increased to $830. We also said that that $830 would be for a dependent spouse without children. But for a spouse with dependent children we increased it to $1,030 in 1982-83. That is an indication of just how we, when in government, supported dependent spouses, particularly those at home looking after children.

We also increased the family allowance. What has this Government done? It has done absolutely nothing. It has not increased the dependent spouse rebate one jot. It has not increased the family allowance, but taken away the family allowance for children of 16 years and over and told us that it will give the children-if they are dependent full time students-Austudy. It has means tested the family allowance and yet in this family support statement, the second reading speech, it tells us that it is very concerned about families.

Another thing that the Fraser Government did was to introduce a family supplement. That was for low income families and was one of the great moves that the Fraser Government worked on in its last Budget. I will read from the second reading speech because I have never read anything quite so hypocritical. It states:

The family package is the centrepiece of this Government's attack on child poverty, not only for families where parents depend on social security because they are sick or unemployed, but for working families who have carried the burden of economic adjustment over the past few years.

We all remember Bob Hawke's election speech. What were the words he used? He said, `By 1990 no Australian child will be living in poverty'. People ridiculed that comment. Now there seems to have been a complete about-face because this second reading speech, which has been changed quite a bit. It states:
The measures outlined in this Bill demonstrate this Government's firm commitment to ensure that no Australian child need live in poverty by 1990.

Let us look at what the Government is producing as vote-catching, off the top of the head, election comments. We have a new poverty trap. Let us take the case of a single income family with two children where the wage earner, the father, earns $330 a week and, with a little overtime-say, 7 1/2 hours work-earns an extra $90, which brings him up to $420 a week. By working an extra 7 1/2 hours a week, what will he get? If he is in public housing or owns his own home, he will get an additional $18.59 out of the additional $90 he earns for 7 1/2 hours work. But if he is in private rental accommodation-let us bear in mind that under this wonderful family package the Government is giving an additional $15 to those who are renting privately-that same father who is doing an additional 7 1/2 hours work and earning an additional $90 will get the princely sum of $8.59. Do honourable senators think for one minute that any man will work an additional 7 1/2 hours, supposedly earning $90, to get $8.59 for it? What do honourable senators think is going to happen?

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you think people should work overtime?

—Of course I think someone ought to be able to work overtime. If he has the incentive to do so, he ought to be able to get a just amount for it. He should not have to work 7 1/2 hours to earn $90 but get a measly $8.59 because of this ridiculous family package. This Government is creating a handout mentality in this group of people. It is succeeding in ripping off $40.39 in tax from that family earning $330 and giving it back $35 in the family package.

SPEECH.PARA: What is wrong with the Government and the Department? Why do they not simply say to that group of people, `You do not have to pay the tax; we will not take $40.39 off you. We will not tax you that amount'? But the Government rips $40.39 off those families and then, as nothing more than a vote catcher, it gives them back $35. So all the cost of having the Australian Taxation Office taking off the tax and all the cost of having the Department of Social Security handing it out is for naught-except that it creates a handout mentality. This measure is being introduced by a government that is so cynical that it is doing it only to get votes. That is a disgrace, because people will now enter a poverty trap. That same father now cannot possibly take on extra work and get anything decent out of it, because he will lose his family allowance supplement if he does. So the Government is creating all the disincentives possible for that particular family. I would like to ask a question of the Minister in charge. Have we a Minister in charge of this Bill?

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you lost your eyesight?
—Who is in charge?
—We have two Ministers.
—Well, who is in charge of the Bill?
—We are both in charge. Continue your speech.
—They cannot both be in charge of the Bill. Can the Government tell me which Minister is in charge of the Bill? Is it Senator Richardson or is it Senator Reynolds?
—I am.

—I would like to ask the Minister to explain to me why it is that the Taxation Office takes $6.81 a week too much, over and above the normal weekly tax when calculated over the year. I know it always takes some, but why does it takes $6.81 over and above the normal weekly tax? The Minister will know how the Taxation Office always takes a little too much-at least I hope he does, because if he does not he is completely--
—It always takes too much from me.
—It always takes a little extra just in case, and it gives it back to these poor families, very graciously, at the end of the year. Does the Minister remember that?
—For a rainy day.

—The Minister can be as flippant as he likes, but if he were earning only $330 a week and had two children he might view this matter a little more sympathetically. At the moment the Tax Office takes $6.61 from that crowd, but people on $420 a week have only an additional $3.60 taken. Can the Minister please explain that? I am really most interested. As I have said, the Government has brought down this very cynical family package that creates shocking poverty traps. It creates a handout mentality when really all it has to do is not tax the families in that bracket-it could allow them to keep their tax rather than take $40.39 from them and then hand them back a paltry $35 as a vote-catching gimmick which it calls a family allowance supplement.

SPEECH.PARA: This, I believe, is the difference between the two parties. The Australian Labor Party is prepared to do anything at all for a vote. It does not matter what it creates. It does not matter how it treats families, whether they are on middle or low incomes. It commissioned and received a report and then chose to ignore it completely. Not only did it ignore its recommendations but also, despite the fact that the recommendations stressed that poverty traps were the worst of all worlds, it went about creating additional ones. This is something that has concerned me greatly. I ask the Minister whether he believes that it is better not to tax a family rather than to hand it back its own tax.

The Minister has not been present during all of my speech. I will tell him about the example I was giving. A family on $330 a week is taxed $40.39 and, on the Government's family allowance supplement, it is given back $35. I suggest that the Government allow these families to keep their tax rather than hand them out a sum of money. Also, if a person in private rental accommodation earns an additional $90 from 7 1/2 hours work, he makes only $8.59 from that. I believe the whole thing is a sham. It is a disgrace, and I would like the Minister to explain it to us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard one of the more imaginative analyses of this whole question. I think Senator Walters would probably stand alone in her opposition to the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 which introduces, among other things, the family package. I could say, almost without contradiction, that the proposals in this piece of legislation have drawn support from around the community and from the Opposition. To try to tackle the arguments that Senator Walters proposed would, I think, take a couple of days, and the clear understanding I have is that it would not change Senator Walters's view one iota. I am very pleased to hand that principal task across to the Minister for the Environment and the Arts, Senator Richardson, and the Minister for Local Government, Senator Reynolds.

SPEECH.PARA: But, by way of comment, I do find very curious Senator Walters's suggestion in relation to that $200 for children under the dependent spouse and dependent children rebate. That $200 a year comes to $4 a week. Senator Walters wanted to say that a $50 a week Austudy payment for 16-year-olds was a nothing compared with a dependent spouse and child rebate of $200 a year-with that $200 rebate applying whether one has one child or 20-which amounts to $4 a week. I suppose that only Senator Walters's imagination would enable one to think that $4 a week was more than $50 a week.

Senator Walters pleaded for an answer to the question: `Why not stop the tax rather than give the family allowance package?'. I would like to ask Senator Walters what she thinks stopping the tax is, if it is not a variety of contributions to the family. Besides that, Senator Walters did not address at all the way in which people would know how any taxpayer earning that amount of money would become eligible for tax rebates or contributions of the sort she was proposing.
