Her contribution, I think, betrayed a complete failure to understand the complexities of our tax system and our social security system and the way in which this Government has addressed both of those areas very comprehensively in its tax changes, through it tax cuts for low income families that it has introduced over the last three years of this Government, and now, with its family package. It has been able to target those most in need of the benefits of the changes proposed in this legislation.

It is a quite extraordinary piece of legislation. It is the greatest increase ever paid by government for children. Undeniably-this is what staggers me about Senator Walters; she has found a way to object to it-it goes to targeting assistance to those most in need. It is entirely consistent with the Government's commitment to move towards removing all children in Australia from poverty by 1990. The proposals under this legislation are marvellous. I do not think that is too strong a word. Low income workers who to this point have not taken up the assistance for which they may be eligible or those low income workers who now become eligible will now be able to receive $22 a week per child under 13 and $28 a week per child between 13 and 16. The Government recognises the increased costs entailed in providing care, clothing, support, et cetera, for teenage children. I think Senator Walters will also find that in Professor Cass's document. The increase from the current $17 a week to $22 a week for under-teenage children, and from $17 to $28 for teenage children up to 16 years of age, will be paid automatically to low income recipients of social security pensions or benefits. No family that has contacted my office-and many have-has been other than delighted with the prospect of this kind of increase in family income consequent upon the family package contained in this legislation.

Many thousands of people have been unaware of the family income supplement (FIS), which is now replaced by the family allowance supplement. I think it is very exciting to assist people to discover this new eligibility. They are certainly very pleased to see the prospects that exist for providing for their children. The Government recognises, very properly, that it has a contribution to make in the provision of income care for children, but the Government does not presume that it has full responsibility. It does not intend to take away the parents' principal responsibility for the care of their children; it intends, through the family allowance supplement and the family assistance package, to assist families in providing for their children. That is also very clearly documented in the social security review papers.

It is estimated that about one million children will benefit from the tax free benefits of this package. It is estimated that about 440,000 children from low income working families and about 740,000 children from out of work families will receive the benefit. That is a considerable number of children to benefit from this special new payment. In addition to those payments that will go automatically to people with one child and earning $300 per week, with an extra $12 per additional child, to be phased out depending on the income above the threshold, the package also includes extended rent assistance of up to $15 per week for low income working families in private rental accommodation. This is the first time that rental assistance has been offered to low income working families. Importantly, families on unemployment or sickness benefits will be able to receive that housing assistance from the time of their first benefit payment and will not have to serve a separate waiting period for rental assistance, as has been the case in the past.

Further to those two parts of the family package, the child disability allowance is to be increased to $112 per month per child for all families with disabled children. That payment will not be income tested and it is expected that approximately 10,000 extra children will come under the new eligibility criteria and be able to enjoy that assistance. The Government recognises the particular demands placed on parents in providing care, assistance, education, clothing, travel and all those things that are involved with a disabled child. Further, it recognises the importance of some assistance through this increase in the payment for disabled children.

As I mentioned earlier, I think it is very important to acknowledge that the Government does not intend in this legislation in any way to take over from families the responsibility for children, but to supplement what families can and do provide themselves. Very soon we will see debated in Parliament the child support legislation, which is a clear statement of how the Government sees the importance of public and private support for children in families going along together. Any suggestion, such as that of Senator Walters in her contribution, that this Government is not committed to families, I think is a nonsense. There is nothing we can say to argue against a person who has a blind conviction-sometimes known as a prejudice-about these matters. Senator Walters hears no argument of logic about it. One can only look at this package and be astonished that she would argue that it does not contain considerable measures to assist families.

Not only does this package assist families, but also it is unashamedly targeted to help those families most in need, that is, the low income working families in our community, those people who have to deal with the constraints of a small income and the consequent poverty. That poverty has many layers, which the Government recognises, and it appreciates that the best way to assist people out of that trap is to provide some income assistance. That is what this program is about. It is targeted to and on behalf of the children. As I said earlier, it is part of the Government's commitment to take steps to ensure that, by the year 1990, no child in this country is living in poverty. I think that is absolutely critical and something that this very wealthy country and this Government properly address.

Other amendments in this legislation go to changes in the job search allowance, which in January will replace the unemployment benefit for 16- and 17-year-olds, making it very clear that the income support provisions under this Bill are tied to the need for young or older people to be better prepared to join the work force. I think it is important that we spell out the principles behind that. The Government is very concerned, and certainly Minister Howe has said this on a number of occasions, that we should not entitle people to benefits and then have them forgotten by society-forgotten on unemployment benefits, on supporting parents' pensions or on age pensions. It is not the aim of this Government to have those people condemned to a life of poverty on permanent pensions or long term unemployment benefits. The changes introduced in this legislation aim for the reverse position-an insistence on government care and concerned for people who, for one reason or another, find themselves unable to get work. The job search allowance not only provides the money, but also it provides assistance in helping young unemployed people to find vocational training courses, and to seek instructions on job searching skills and so on. In other words, those people are not to be forgotten or wasted. I think that this measure is another very strong commitment by government to families, to the children of families and to our young people and the contribution that they can make if they are properly assisted.

One other point worthy of comment is that the legislation provides pensioner earning credits to encourage pensioners and supporting parents to take up short term work without the reduction in their pension that they previously would have had to suffer. This certainly will assist pensioners, particularly sole parents, to make a transition between relying on social security payments and becoming financially independent. It will do this by enabling people to have periods of employment without loss of pension. Those periods of employment are often very important in giving people the experience of getting back into the work force and of practising or learning skills that are very necessary for them if they want to get into the work force in a more permanent way.

All those measures are very much to the heart of this Government's commitment to the less privileged and to the low income earners in our community. I am amazed, if not shocked, that Senator Walters could come in here and say what she did, I think missing the point of the legislation and the proposed changes. The family allowance supplement and the family package are achievements of considerable pride. They will benefit families enormously. As I said, it is expected that more than one million children will benefit from these proposals. To argue that a government that implements such initiatives is disinterested in the family seems to me to be odd in the extreme. If Senator Walters wants to equate $200 a year dependent spouse rebate and extra child rebate-that is, $4 a week-with the contributions that this Government is making under these direct payments or with the Austudy allowance of $50 a week for 16-year-olds to whom she referred, my case rests on the nonsense of her figures.

I refer now to the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1987. This Bill relates to an area about which I am concerned as a member of the Senate Select Committee on Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes. Many of the issues in relation to standards of care and the provision of services for frail aged people were matters that we deliberated on at great length, and some of the recommendations in the Committee's report were taken up by the Minister in this Bill. Not all the recommendations have been taken up in legislation as yet, but, as the Government argues, this enabling legislation is one part of a process to improve the residential care program. The first part of the legislation enables the implementation of new hostel capital funding and recurrent funding arrangements. Until now capital funding for hostels has not necessarily been directed to those people who were less advantaged, those who were financially disadvantaged or people who had difficulty finding places in hostels. The Government is very concerned that such people should enjoy the benefits of hostel accommodation. It is particularly important that such people do not find their way, inappropriately, into nursing home care; that has been the situation in the past. Frail aged people, very inappropriately, have been placed in nursing homes. By rearranging the funding for hostels, the Government is concerned to ensure that a proper proportion of hostel places are provided for low income or financially disadvantaged people who are in need of that sort of half way, supported accommodation.

The amendments under this Bill also introduce elements of, I suppose, residents' rights. In particular, it relates to people who make an entry contribution in respect of their hostel accommodation; they will now clearly understand their right to take out that contribution, should they need or desire to do so. For example, people may find that they do not need to live in a hostel if they recover from a disability to the point where they can leave. Alternatively, people may be unhappy in a particular place and may want to leave. In the past there has been a lack of understanding of the rights of people in terms of their entry contribution, but those rights are made clear under this Bill. The rights of people to recoup a proportion of their entry contribution when they depart a hostel is made clear. This Bill protects those people in their decision if they should make that move.

The legislation also makes clear other residents' rights, and some of those provisions relate to the recommendations of the Committee. I suppose that indirectly people's rights are protected, but the Bill also protects those rights by enabling the officers of the Department of Community Services and Health to see records that properly account for funding arrangements in nursing homes. I guess I am moving sideways from hostel accommodation, but patients' rights is a very important point and it was referred to in the Committee's report. It is important that there is maximum protection for nursing home residents and taxpayers through the requirement for proper accounting and access to records by departmental officials so that it is clear what sort of funding arrangements are being made, what is happening to patients' contributions and the costs of staffing, provision of services, and so on. There has been evidence that some nursing homes have not acted entirely properly in the way in which they have kept their books, and, on behalf of both the taxpayer and the residents within those nursing homes, the Government has made clear that the proper keeping of records is a requirement under this legislation. There is a requirement for not only the keeping of records but also the provision of those records in a designated place so that they can be accessed for examination, if that is judged necessary or is required.

Opposition members in the other place have argued that there was insufficient consultation in relation to this Bill, but I believe that that suggestion arose from a misunderstanding. There has been extensive consultation to this point. The Australian Affiliation of Voluntary Care Associations stated that it was not informed that the Bill was to be introduced in Parliament, but that misunderstanding has been cleared up and a letter to the Minister has made clear that the representatives of the Australian Affiliation of Voluntary Care Associations are not now troubled or holding to that point. The confusion has been cleared.

The other area that has been a matter of some dispute is the detail that some people thought would be included in the legislation. An understanding of the legislation by those people has made clear that not only has consultation been sufficient to this point but also the points about which they were concerned-that is, some of the detail that will be introduced under regulations, which will therefore be open to disallowance in this place-will be contingent on further extensive consultation with all the providers in this area. Therefore, it is quite clear that the complaints raised by Opposition members in the other place are of no substance and it is important to lay them to rest. In reading the contributions of Opposition members in the other place I could see no other significant difficulty that they envisaged in relation to this Bill. I will be interested to hear the remainder of the debate in the Senate.

I said previously that the amendments under this legislation are part of the ongoing provision of care for the elderly under the residential care program. The Bill is complementary to a number of changes in the home and community care area whereby there is better provision of community assistance so that people can remain in their own homes. It fits very closely with the establishment of assessment teams to ensure that people are not wrongly admitted to nursing homes. That is not only very expensive for the community but also disadvantageous to the optimum health and living ability of those people who are wrongly placed. Over the past few years we have seen considerable changes in this area and encouragement for people to be rehabilitated, whether they enter nursing homes or sometimes even hostels. I believe this is a very exciting change. It is certainly something that many people who work in nursing homes have asked for for years. Previous funding arrangements worked against the prospect of rehabilitation programs, but the funding arrangements have been changed so that there is now considerable incentive and encouragement for those people who work in this area to provide that kind of assistance and health care to nursing home patients. As I said, even some hostel residents can benefit enormously from all those programs in the rehabilitation area.

Those changes must be borne in mind when we consider this Bill. It is part of a series of stages of a program to improve greatly the provision of care for the elderly and/or the frail aged-and I believe there is a distinction between the elderly and the frail aged-as well as hostel or nursing home care for those who can no longer remain living in their own homes. As I have said, the home and community care programs that very much assist elderly people to stay in their home for as long as possible should also be remembered.

Other points in this cognate debate covering changes to the Health Insurance Act and the National Health Act, I believe, would be better left to other colleagues to speak to or for the Minister to reply to in his summing up. I conclude my remarks simply by re-endorsing the changes made in the social security legislation to the family package. I think I said earlier that the package is marvellous and that this is a monumental piece of legislation. It will benefit over one million children and it represents the greatest increase in specific payments on behalf of children ever introduced by this Government in this country, as I understand. It is a matter of great pride that the Government has introduced this legislation.

I listened to the extraordinary nonsense by Senator Walters who suggested that such a package was an insult. This betrays her lack of understanding of what this legislation is about, how many people it will benefit and to whom it is targeted. It also seems that the final clear understanding that we all have that Senator Walters's insistence that this Government does nothing for families is beyond change. I think her insistence is utterly mischievous but in this case it is also splendidly wrongheaded. This piece of legislation is specifically targeted to families. Families in the community will know and benefit and they will not see it as a cynical vote catching trick.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating cognately the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987, the Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 and the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1987. I will deal first with the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987. I draw the Senate's attention to comments made in the Scrutiny of Bills Alert Digest dated 18 November 1987 because a large number of amendments are proposed to the Social Security Act 1947. Apparently a number of the amendments will be retrospective because the Bill has been in operation since 2 July 1987, that is some six months.

SPEECH.PARA: These extensive and detailed amendments represent the eighth time that this Bill has been amended. It has been renumbered consecutively and relettered alphabetically and this has created many problems for the people who reviewed and who have to use the Bill. In order to make sense of the proposed amendments one would have to have available a consolidated reprint of the Act. Even today no consolidated reprint of the Act is available to people such as members of parliament, professional people and members of community bodies who have to use the Bill. The penultimate paragraph of the Scrutiny of Bills Alert Digest states:

If it becomes difficult for the legislative scrutiny committees of the Parliament and their advisers to read and comprehend Bills without reference to a number of Acts which must be collated, re-numbered and re-lettered, it will be equally, if not more difficult for the Parliament and its members to properly examine proposed legislation. The Committee also notes that it is apparent that considerable resources are applied to the preparation and drafting of amendments to such complex statutes as the Social Security Act. It is also important that adequate resources be made available to ensure that timely printing of consolidated reprints of such legislation.
I take that statement to be a damning indictment of the legislative process of the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —That has been going on since 1947-one or two governments at least.

—It is the eighth rewrite of this legislation and we do not have a consolidated copy of the Act. As I have said, the Act has been in operation since 2 July this year. The Government has agreed that poverty and welfare are both increasing in this country. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) declared war on child hunger and poverty which he says he will solve. At the present time, even after the introduction of this Bill, the Government recognises that over half a million children will remain in poverty. The Government also recognises that in this legislation are built-in disincentives for people to work, that significant poverty traps in Australia still remain and that this year we have a lower level of housing commencements than we had in 1982-83. I remind the Senate that in that year Australia had a sizable drought. The Government also recognises that its investment in housing will be reduced this year and on top of that we have a declining birth rate.

SPEECH.PARA: I wonder whether we are not attacking our welfare problems from the wrong end. I am reminded of a history book I read once in which Queen Elizabeth I said that the poor would always be with us. At one time Confucius was credited with saying that if one gives a poor man a fish he will eat for a day, but if one teaches him to fish, he will eat forever. The new welfare industry does not subscribe to that theory. It says, `If you teach him to fish, he will eat fish forever and that is no good. You have to give him money so that he can choose what he eats' and there is quite a bit of sense in that.

Other countries have had problems with poverty and have tried many different systems. The welfare state blossomed in the United Kingdom after the Second World War. England was gradually reduced from being a world power to being nothing and the situation has been reversed only in recent years. The United States, under President Johnson, introduced war against poverty and went for the great society. Programs are largely in place but they are coming under increasing criticism because they have not worked. Food stamps, Medicaid, aid to families with dependent children and aid to minority groups are all programs which are coming under increasing criticism. However, those programs have not been repealed; they still exist and are still getting increasing funding although they are not working. America is faced with enormous welfare problems just as we are faced with them in Australia today. Most of the better educated analysts are coming to the stage of proving that the war on poverty is actually aggravating the problem rather than solving it. In fact the poor are being reduced to a destructive state of total dependency. America is introducing new measures such as Workfare which is a whole new concept that is being tried. If we had tried to introduce that sort of program in Australia 10 years ago we would have been howled down as making moral judgments on people, that we cannot do that sort of thing. It is now eminently acceptable that Workfare is one of the possible solutions to this problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where did you get that idea from?

—I did not get the idea of Workfare; it was generated in the United States of America because of its problems. It has not reached here yet but maybe it will. The honourable senator has not thought about it. Perhaps I can give a solution to the problem in a minute. There is a general view that only the Australian Labor Party (ALP) understands welfare and is prepared to do things for the poor and that the conservatives have no heart and only want the poor to become more deprived. Nothing could be further from the truth. The ALP has no monopoly on social conscience. Why has all of this welfare not eliminated poverty? We have been dishing out welfare for years, but it has not eliminated poverty; it is getting worse. As I said earlier in my speech, the welfare problem is getting worse and the expenditure is getting worse. Something is wrong.

SPEECH.PARA: No matter how well intentioned the Government's motives might be in trying to improve people's situations, the simple fact remains that anything the Government wants more of, it subsidises. Anything it wants less of, it taxes. If the Government has high unemployment benefits, it will get more unemployment, not less. If it has high sickness benefits, it will get more sickness, not less sickness. It is happening in front of our eyes. If it has high single parent benefits, it will get more single parents, not fewer single parents. And dare I say it, if it has high Aboriginal benefits, we will get more Aborigines, not fewer Aborigines.

If we are to eliminate poverty, I think we should introduce the principle that the giving of welfare benefits creates a mutual obligation. In other words, there is a duty attached to receiving welfare benefits and recipients should use part of those benefits to end the state of dependence that they are in. The current programs that we have recognise no such obligation-in a misplaced effort to protect the dignity and alleged rights of people. Able-bodied people in Australia have been able to choose not to work and to live on welfare. Of course, this has required other people to support them. We cannot blame other people for thinking that they are suckers for being exploited to support able-bodied people. On the other hand, we have not got any idea of temporary benefits. Once people get bene-fits, they get them forever. If benefits were rapidly withdrawn, that would be a big discouragement to increasing dependency on benefits.

In Australia we have centralised our payments of benefits. There has been no adjustment for local factors, no innovation and no incentive for experimentation in the distribution of benefits. I know this from my own experience on the Gold Coast. I write letters to all the people newly arrived in the electorate. A young fellow arrived in my office one day and said, `You have written me a letter and said that you are willing to help. What can you do?'. I said, `What do you want?'. He said, `A job'. I said, `What can you do?'. He said, `I will do anything'. It just so happened that I had been to the yacht club for a luncheon and I said, `Will you wash down the yachts?', and he said `I will do anything'. So I rang up and got him a job washing down yachts after they came in. He worked well and within a couple of weeks he had about eight other people working for him. In fact, he used me as a reference centre. He said to other people, `Forget the Commonwealth Employment Service. Go and see Senator Sheil, he will get you a job'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Jobs for the boys. Fair go!

—I do not know about that. Another young fellow arrived. As luck would have it, I was just back from inspecting a cattle feeding lot up in the valley and the car was filthy. I said, `Will you clean cars?'. He said, `Yes', and I got him a job in all the high rises around the coast, and now he employs at least 10 people. He is very private enterprise oriented; he charges more for cleaning a Rolls-Royce than he does for a Mercedes.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators-Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, if you want to live on that level, live on it. If you want to get out of it, get out of it. Actually, I think I am doing better on the Gold Coast than a lot of these CES offices. Another guy came along and I said, `Do you want to clean shoes?'. Now he has a contract cleaning shoes in all the high rises. Later I got a job for someone cleaning windows on high rise buildings. All these guys are now employing other fellows. They do not need a lot of education; they just need a lot of responsibility and a bit of get up and go.

SPEECH.PARA: I think we have slaughtered the brains of our kids by making them dependent on this welfare mentality that is all around Australia today. I think there are lots of other jobs available. We have killed our creature comforts of this world. We no longer have butlers. People used to be proud of being butlers, valets and cooks. We talk about the Chinese bringing interests into Australia. When the Chinese give their version of what are high-class qualifications, they say that they are acupuncture, massage and cooking. We have slaughtered the imagination of our people in getting jobs. I think this centralisation of welfare benefits has bred inflexibility and has inhibited economic growth. I think our national programs require eligibility criteria and assistance packages that are simple and universal purely for the convenience of bureaucratic administration. They cannot deal with an individual problem or a community problem as it occurs, so we have wound up with a whole lot of rigid rules and rigid entitlements in order to qualify for benefits. There is no flexible response to an individual. Centralisation also makes it harder to find any better approaches to the solution of the problem.

Another problem that I see is one that became known as empowerment. People who are poor do not have the power to fix their own problems and, by creating a welfare industry such as we have, we have robbed them even more of any power to fix their problems or to influence the policy that fixes them. In fact, the power in Australia today has gone not to the poor whom we are trying to look after; it has gone to professional social welfare organisations. These organisations have become experts at securing and directing government funds. If we made any attempt to reduce their power in the distribution of welfare in Australia, we would find an enormous outcry. I think this is one of the major areas that we have to concentrate on. If we interfere with the power of institutions such as the Australian Council of Social Service, the Queensland Council of Social Service, any of the other councils of social service or the Brotherhood of St Laurence, we will have an outcry on our hands, because they are the experts at getting government funds and they direct how they are going to be expended. They direct the programs. The programs may be of no benefit to the poor whatsoever; they are in the minds of the do-gooders who are running these institutions, and the interests of the poor get lost.

Perhaps we should assess the degree and the nature of society's present obligations to the poor. We should temper our idealism with some realism and we should link welfare with the steps taken by the recipient to improve his or her condition. We would then have a better chance of keeping a check on spending. But we must beware of massive spending programs on job training, day care and all these other enormous schemes that are funded by the Federal Government. Why should parents not be allowed to assume the responsibilities that they want to assume? Families should be relieved of most of the problems that are presently landed on their shoulders. The biggest one, of course, is tax. That is an enormous burden. For example, if the payment of welfare benefits allows a single mother to leave home and to live on her own, we are more or less condemning her to a life of poverty and hardship rather than having her supported by the family to which she belongs.

I firmly believe that the poor know more about their problems than any government does. In particular, they know more about their problems than any of the middle class philanthropists who have control of the money now. Just because someone is poor it does not mean that others know better what is in their interests. My plea is that we should decentralise our welfare services. The initiative to generate welfare services should come from families, churches and service organisations.

TALK.START.PARA: —How would you do it?

—It would be very simply done. I have worked with all of them. It takes a little initiative and imagination. Honourable senators opposite just want to have a big central organisation. They will face the problem they are facing right now-increasing expenditure and increasing poverty. That is what they have delivered. One could decentralise welfare services, and with a much better result. The fundamental structure should be the family, which is what honourable senators opposite want to destroy. The family is what the Government should concentrate on.
—Would you wipe out all welfare payments?

—Nobody argues against society's responsibility to children, the handicapped or the infirm. They are very different obligations to society's obligations to the able-bodied. Women can be handicapped and infirm. Honourable senators opposite should not be so narrow-minded. Let me go back to Confucius. If one gives a poor man a fish he will eat for a day; if one teaches him to fish he will eat forever. The Government thinks that it is no good to eat fish forever, and gives the poor money. There is a halfway stage. If the welfare services can give the recipient a voucher he can decide whether he wants food, housing or remedial education. That would put power in the hands of the poor. They could decide what services they wanted. Poor people would have the power to determine the expenditure of welfare moneys. They would become consumers and consumer advocates, and would be much more powerful in determining what sorts of services they required. If we did that, poor people may become powerful enough to provide services not only for themselves but for their community. Perhaps they could even manage public housing projects. It would do them good. It would increase their confidence and help them get out into the world. We should reactivate the family and the local community as active agents in the attack on poverty. Most importantly, we should re-establish the principle of mutual obligation between those who give welfare and those who receive it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard a very thoughtful address from Senator Sheil. Many of the things he said we take on board. This Government has done a lot of the things Senator Sheil talked about. Senator Sheil gave us the glorious picture of him on the Gold Coast throwing a fishing line and pulling out fish and more fish, rather than simply waiting for someone to come along and give him the fish. This Government, by its concentration on education and its provision of traineeships, apprenticeships and jobs, has done exactly what Senator Sheil advocates. When one is looking at our record, that is where one starts.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a package of very enlightened legislation but it has to be seen against the background of this Government having done mightily by the poor and unemployed. The Government has created about 800,000 jobs while it has been in office. It has instituted traineeships, created apprenticeships, furthered tertiary education and provided people with the means of catching their own fish. It will continue to do so. It has done so despite the very poor circumstances it inherited from the previous Government.

Senator Sheil said that this Government has been too concerned about trying to redress welfare problems by giving people money and assistance. But not only has this Government done so; previous governments have done so, and done so very well. I think we would all agree that Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, as Minister for Social Security during the Fraser Government, acted mightily in this context. It should be properly acknowledged that she did so. When Senator Chaney was a Minister for Social Security he also did well. He adorns this place now, and let us hope that he adorns the Opposition benches for many years to come.

Senator Sheil said that the Australian Labor Party maintains that its members are the only ones who care for the poor. That is not so. The churches care for the poor. Bishop Hollingworth in Melbourne is an example. I hope that the community as a whole is concerned about its fellow community members who are in need of assistance. It is all very well to maintain that the poor can somehow be educated overnight, that people can overcome the effects of accidents and the sicknesses with which they are afflicted, can overcome, in many cases, generations of hardship and an inability to get on in the world as well as others. Surely as decent human beings we want to raise these members of the community to equal status. It is true that people should do all they can to help themselves, but the reality is that often they cannot.

The other dangerous thing about Senator Sheil's approach is that if we go down the line of saying that in some way these people are not helping themselves, that they are deficient, that they are not equal citizens because they do not have the ability to do what we consider ordinary citizens should do, we begin to make them scapegoats. We say, `You are to blame for your own difficulties. You should go out and find a yacht to clean, or windows or shoes to clean, and if you do not do that you are to be condemned. We will give you some pittance but we make it clear that we will do so to reduce your dignity and sense of being a full citizen of the community. We will reduce your sense of self-worth'. If we get to that stage we are getting to a very sorry situation indeed.

I want to say something about what this Government has done over the years, particularly during the past year. It has tackled the economic problems this nation faces. It is true that for people to get out of poverty permanently they need jobs. That has been the thrust of this Government's approach over the years. It arises out of the accord which was signed in February 1983 between the Australia Labor Party (ALP) and the unions. Both constituent parts of the movement have struggled successfully to do something about it. The Government's record this year is impressive. Senator Sheil said that this Government ignored the family. The family package shows that that statement is quite incorrect. Mark Ryan, the Director of the Australian Council of Social Service, describes the family allowance supplement as the first significant move made by any government in trying to reduce the number of families living in poverty. This Government has targeted families which are in need and has provided the needed support. It is interesting that Labor, in every Budget since the election in 1983, has increased payments to families. The child payment is 120 per cent higher than equivalent payments in March 1983, and 180 per cent higher for older children.

The Social Welfare Research Centre concludes that the family package will mean a significant improvement in the incomes of poor families. It also estimates that the family package will reduce the poverty gap by $160m-from $350m to $190m. The commitment for this Government will be to set benchmarks to ensure that the family allowance supplement amounts to an enduring reform. The family package arose out of the social security review, which will continue to set new directions for the reform of social security systems in 1988. In other words, it is an ongoing review of the needs of people who cannot adequately look after themselves, and that commitment will continue. It is a targeted review that is directed by a proper alignment of need with the relief of that need.

Senator Sheil said that the community should not support all those who are in need of pensions or who claim pensions to the extent that it does. The inference was that somehow those people share unfairly in the community resources. It must be remembered that the whole community shares in the resources of the community, and that the taxation that is raised in the community goes towards the protection of all, whether by way of defence spending, roads, subsidised theatres, subsidised education and so on. All the things that are subsidised or paid for from the public purse are accepted by society. It seems to me a little hard to say that, society having accepted those things, those who are in need of welfare payments should be excluded. In other words, to use a crude expression, we all have our snouts in the trough. It seems unfair that those who enjoy the trough should shoulder out in some way the people who receive welfare.

I wish to refer to other advances made by this Government this year. I give particular praise to the Minister for Social Security, Mr Howe, who has striven grandly to achieve these things. Senator Sheil spoke of the poverty trap. It is interesting to note in that context that from 1 July this year the pensioner package increased the amount of money that pensioners can earn without reducing their pension payments from $30 to $40 a week for single pensioners and from $50 to $70 for couples. In addition, the new earnings credit, which started this month, will give pensioners the incentive to go ahead and supplement their incomes. They can earn up to $40 a week or $1,000 a year, even though that sum may be earned over a period of three or four weeks. All this goes to the relief of poverty traps.

A series of amendments have been put forward by the Opposition and by the Australian Democrats, all of which go to matters which are reasonably peripheral. They show that the general thrust of this legislation has the support of everybody in this chamber, including Senator Sheil, who will be voting for the legislation. Despite the rhetoric that is heard in this chamber, we all have a heart-including Senator Sheil. I have always accepted him as a tender-hearted man, and underneath all that rhetoric he is.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are a true Christian.

—That is true, and this legislation has a Christian base to it. When it comes to the thrust of this legislation, Senator Sheil and everybody will support it. They realise how magnificently this Government has risen to the needs of the poor and deprived. Senator Vanstone-another very reasonable senator-in opening this debate for the Opposition said that she accepted the thrust of the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: An amendment has been proposed to clause 11(2) of the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill (No. 2), dealing with assets. In assessing a pension for a year the pension will be reduced by an amount equal to 2.5 per cent of the value of property. That arises out of an Administrative Appeals Tribunal decision which provides that the question of whether a person can raise income from property is to be judged on a subjective rather than an objective test. It seems reasonable in those circumstances, where there must be a balance between financial responsibility and social responsibility, that, where people have property of considerable value, that should be taken into account in the assessment of their pension. The more one pensioner takes from the system the less that remains for others. In seeking to obtain equity, I believe that it is proper that the test should be objective. In any event, it seems that the Opposition and the Australian Democrats feel differently, but I invite them in pressing their case to take account of the balance that must be struck between social and economic responsibilities. The fact that they are seeking to amend this provision indicates that the real debate here is about how best to give pensions to those in need and how best to adjust those pensions to a proper level.

This legislation has support across the chamber, as is proper. It is a tribute to this Government, which in the last four or five years has been able to take steps in this area. I think all will agree that the Government has striven mightily to do what is right and just. Clearly, as Senator Sheil said, the poor are always with us. However, that is not an excuse for doing nothing; it is a challenge to see whether we can eliminate poverty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: -It is very interesting to note what one learns in this place. I was fascinated this evening to learn from Senator Sheil that the procreative activities of the Aboriginal community were in some way determined by the Government. I was also interested to note that he alluded to Confucius and fish. The fish is a symbol which goes back a long time in European history. Senator Cooney picked up this message when he said that the Government had provided the means of catching one's own fish. The Australian Democrats would comment that both the Government and the Opposition have pursued policies of environmental despoliation which have led to a decrease in fish stocks. While the Government may have provided the means of catching fish, there are very few fish there to catch.

SPEECH.PARA: The first of the three Bills before us this evening, the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill (No. 2), has already been dealt with partially by Senator McLean and will be further dealt with later by Senator Powell. I wish to deal with the other two Bills which are before us. The Australian Democrats are pleased to support the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill as it will continue the very necessary reform to the system of nursing homes in Australia. The last two sessions of Parliament have both seen major legislative change in nursing home care and several major reports over recent years have criticised the quality of care provided in some homes and the variations which exist between homes and between States and their funding. The Government has clearly addressed these concerns.

The Nursing Homes and Hostels Review recommended that as far as possible aged and disabled people should be supported in their homes and communities and that more residential care options should be available. The Democrats support this policy direction. There is now a general recognition of the importance of aged care policies and programs. More and more people are aware that Australian society is confronting an increase in the proportion of old people and is coming to terms with providing care for these elderly Australians. The proportion of persons under 15 years of age has fallen from 35 per cent in 1901 to 23 per cent in 1986 and it is projected to decline to 19 per cent by the year 2021. Thus the number of young people requiring expensive education is falling and will continue to fall further. Some of this money saved will need to be transferred to care for the aged.

At the other end of the scale, the figures show that the general population is projected to grow by 6.5 per cent in the next five years but the population between 65 and 75-that is, the young elderly-will increase by 35 per cent. The number of aged people over 74 will grow by 22 per cent; that of those aged 80 and over by 25 per cent and that of those 85 and over by 21 per cent. This remarkable growth in the older aged population in the next five years requires immediate attention from the Government. This legislation addresses this problem. What we see is not only more people over 65 but also more people in the very oldest groups. One study even suggests that the number of people in the over 85 group will eventually increase by 150 per cent.

Whilst the Democrats welcome an increase in community-based support services, and no one can argue with the appropriate allocation of nursing home beds, we are concerned that the Government is being distracted in its enthusiasm from new problems which will face us. We are concerned, for instance, that the provision of increased hostel funding appears to be contingent upon less reliance on our nursing home accommodation. In fact in a population in which the percentage of older people is increasing, the need for nursing homes will not necessarily decrease along with the provision of additional hostel beds and community services. While many people may currently be inappropriately placed in nursing homes, there are also many people on long waiting lists for those places. We may also be underestimating the demand which will be faced by our acute care hospitals in future years for procedures such as hip replacements. Creative solutions to a range of such issues will be required. To give just one example, Alzheimer's is a disease usually, but not always, of the elderly and it progresses until the patient essentially becomes a living vegetable requiring 24 hours a day home care. Some patients last in this dependent stage for well over 10 years. The latest work seems to be suggesting that this disease is genetically determined, holding out no hope for a cure but hope that in the long run genetic counselling and responsible procreation may reduce the incidence. But note, Mr Acting Deputy President, that this step will take at least 60 years to implement, posing a very considerable care problem in the meantime.

The provisions of the Bill before us relate to capital funding arrangements for hostels and recurrent funding arrangements for nursing homes. They are aimed, as the Government has said, at better targeting of services, enhancing equity of treatment, increasing the accountability of organisations which spend large amounts of public money, encouraging the provision of appropriate assessment and rehabilitation services and streamlining the workability of financial arrangements. These are all moves which we support.

We are pleased to see that the proportion of financially disadvantaged residents to be accommodated will be appropriately taken into account in assessing funding. It is appropriate that refundable entry contributions paid by residents be considered as part of an organisation's available funds. It is sensible that guidelines be developed and tabled by the Minister for the assessment of establishment capital grants. It is interesting to see the possibility of joint ventures for provision of accommodation being opened up.

The Bill contains many other particular changes which we will support. We strongly welcome the strengthening of privacy provisions in the Bill. The Opposition made reference to what it considers to be particularly arduous reporting requirements and harsh penalties applying to the industry and to proprietors. This was referred to by one honourable member in the other place as `using a sledgehammer to crack a nut'. In various social security amendments which the Democrats have opposed, the Government has introduced extraordinarily intrusive and draconian procedures and penalties. Perhaps there is a perverse sort of justice in organisations being harassed about accountability for public money to the same extent that individuals are. These proposals seem fair and equitable.

Unfortunately, there is some cause for scepticism about the Government's comfortable rhetoric about needs-based planning and effecting gradual change and in particular about extensive consultation. I noticed that Senator Crowley referred to this matter of consultation and claimed that those who had complained about lack of consultation were now satisfied. Nonetheless, the fact that that complaint occurred at all indicates that consultation was in some way inadequate. In debate in another place Opposition members made numerous references to this issue of consultation. They quoted from a letter which, I guess, is the letter to which Senator Crowley referred from the Voluntary Care Association of South Australia Inc. The Democrats also received a similar letter. It is couched indeed in very strong terms and it is highly critical of the way the Government and the Department of Finance have proceeded on this matter. From their account the so-called consultation entered into by the Department was anything but extensive. Bureaucrats flying between capital cities does not constitute effective and extensive consultation.

The support which this legislation is receiving in Parliament does not excuse the antics which have been recounted to us, such as the enormous discussion documents produced by the Department arriving only one or two days before they were scheduled to be discussed by the parties. Meaningless consultation is not only an enormous waste of taxpayer's money; but it is also insulting to those who are consulted. Thus, it generates a large amount of destructive ill feeling in a sector where we should be seeking to work co-operatively. The Voluntary Care Association of South Australia, for instance, said that it was surely in the best interests of Australian governments to ensure that non-profit organisations providing quality accommodation and care remained viable and that there was certainly no milage for any government that did not consult adequately.

I turn now to the final Bill, Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). I noted that Senator Crowley made the remark that governments were not disinterested in people living in poverty. I was rather distressed to hear that and I hope she meant that governments were not uninterested in people living in poverty. In that case, I would like to take her up on one particular issue which is dealt with in this piece of legislation. The Bill is intended to clarify the entitlements of certain social security recipients to free and concessional pharmaceuticals. The amendments are consequential upon changes to the social security system introduced by the Government following the May mini-Budget.

Many of these changes were rejected at the time by the Australian Democrats and passed only with the support of the Opposition. The Democrats considered many of the changes draconian and appallingly out of touch with the realities of life for the poor and unemployed of Australia. I notice that Senator Sheil referred to poverty traps. The concern we express about this Bill relates to what we believe is one of these quite serious poverty traps.

Clause 4 of the Bill amends the formula for calculating eligibility for a health care card and therefore to pharmaceuticals at the concessional rate of $2.50 per script. This technical change is a response to the differing levels of allowable income which now attach to dependent children, varying with their age, for the purposes of the family allowance supplement. The amount of $34 set by this legislation-which will be increased by regulation-reflects the current formula of twice the weekly rate of additional benefit payable for children. It will avoid having to take the age of children into account, since the family assistance scheme provides $22 a week for children under 13 and higher rates for children between 13 and 15 years, when assessing eligibility for a card.

Clause 5 of the Bill relates to the pharmaceutical entitlements of young people of 16 to 17 years of age. The May mini-Budget saw the abolition of unemployment and sickness benefits for these young people and the job search allowance put in its place. This provides young people with $25 to $50 per week depending on their parents' income. The point that I wish to make in relation to this is that this amount is extremely small. It is against that small amount of $25 to $50 a week job search allowance that the pharmaceutical benefit allowance at a concessional rate needs to be considered.

The Government is not proposing any corres- ponding reduction in the cost to young people of pharmaceuticals. Those who cannot find work will still be expected to pay the concessional rate of $2.50 per script despite a reduction in the weekly income of many of them. It is precisely these people to whom Senator Sheil was referring. They are the people who are seeking work by definition; they are in a job search situation.

For those many young people who suffer from disorders such as asthma, diabetes or epilepsy, which do not necessarily prevent them from seeking and actually obtaining work and holding down a job but nonetheless which can be quite debilitating and require constant medication, and whose family situation income is not such that their parents can or will pay for their pharmaceuticals, this burden of $2.50 per script can be quite intolerable. They are not expected to carry this until they reach the $250 per year safety net which applies to the rest of the community-irrespective of their income-because they would receive free pharmaceuticals under the safety net for the chronically ill once they have purchased 25 scripts per year. This amounts to a cost of $62.50 per year. This amount may not seem significant in itself but the fact remains that, under the Government's proposal these young people will be asked to pay $2.50 per script even when their income is as low as $25 per week. They are to be told that to fill a prescription it will cost them 10 per cent of their weekly income.

We all know that the level of the job search allowance is hardly enough to defray in many cases even the costs involved in actively seeking employment. Most of us would not take too kindly to one prescription costing 10 per cent of our weekly income even when a so-called safety net means our individual or family pharmaceutical costs cut out at between 1 1/2 and 2 1/2 weeks income spread over a year. To put this into perspective, $62.50 a year represents between approximately 1 1/2 and 2 1/2 weeks income on the job search allowance of $25 to $50 per week. The average weekly earnings in August was $394. So, for the average worker, 1 1/2 weeks income is $491 and 2 1/2 weeks income is $985. In other words, that by comparison is what we are asking these people on the job search allowance to pay for a prescription.

In this light the charge proposed to be levied by the Government on young people who suffer chronic illness yet who are actively looking for work is clearly an unreasonable and inequitable one. For this reason the Democrats would have liked to have moved an amendment to provide that all the recipients of the job search allowance receive free pharmaceuticals. We do not believe that this would be particularly expensive for the Government. The reason that we do not move an amendment simply relates to the complexity of the Bill which is being amended and which has been amended a number of times in the past. Indeed, it would have been preferable for amendments to the Bill to be moved in the Committee of the Whole to ensure that recipients of the job search allowance would be statutorily entitled to free pharmaceutical benefits without any further income test.

It would have involved amending clauses 5 and 8 and substituting different amendments to the principal legislation. The task of drafting such amendments is rendered almost impossible by the chaotic state of the principal legislation. The National Health Act and the Health Insurance Act have not been reprinted since 1980 and 1981 respectively and there are a number of lengthy amending Acts to each. It is therefore a major and time consuming task simply to discover the state of the principal legislation before one even begins to ascertain what amendments are necessary. In the time available it was not possible to draft the necessary amendments and so the feeling of the Senate has been tested by way of a second reading motion on this issue. This is a further example of the great difficulties caused by the failure of the Attorney-General's Department to reprint complicated and frequently amended Acts. The lack of up to date reprints means that honourable senators cannot even ascertain the state of legislation they are amending.

Clause 8 of the Bill deals with the entitlements of people who previously received particular pensions and benefits to which free pharmaceuticals attached as a fringe benefit. Due to the implementation of the Government's May mini-Budget attacks on welfare, many supporting parents and class A widows-that is, divorced or separated women with dependent children-lost their eligibility for these forms of support from 1 September. The Government anticipated that many of these people would transfer to the unemployment benefit which attracts only concessional and not free pharmaceuticals.

In response to the representations of what it calls the welfare lobby, the Government has to some extent seen the error of its ways. Clause 8 provides that free pharmaceuticals should continue to be provided until-this is an arbitrary date-the end of the year for those who, even more arbitrarily, lose their entitlement prior to the end of this year. The Democrats support this amendment in as much as it is an ad hoc short term band-aid attempt to address the difficulties which are being faced by people in their transition from the widow's pension and the supporting parent benefit. However, it is clearly not an adequate response to the needs of people-primarily older women-for training in skills development and for support in the face of too few job vacancies.

As I indicated earlier, the Democrats will propose many amendments-amendments concerning the Government's inadequate social security system-to the legislation being debated cognately with this Bill. I foreshadow my amendment, which was circulated to honourable senators. I will move:
At the end of the motion, add:
``, but the Senate is of the opinion that recipients of the job search allowance should be entitled to free pharmaceutical benefits without any further income test''.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today my home city of Melbourne witnessed another shooting tragedy even more appalling in terms of its carnage than the Hoddle Street massacre in Clifton Hill only four months ago tomorrow. The reports are still to be confirmed as to all the details, but it appears that at least nine people are dead and five have been wounded in the Telecom Australia office in Queen Street, Melbourne, really in the centre of the city. I wish to join with the Victorian Premier, John Cain, and the Leader of the Opposition in Victoria, Jeff Kennett, in their expressions of shock at the tragedy that has occurred. I would like also to join with them in extending my deepest sympathy to the relatives of the victims.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that today also happens to be the anniversary of the shooting of John Lennon in New York in, I think, 1980. If one had said six months ago to the people of Melbourne that a massacre of this type could occur, one simply would not have been believed. Now, within a space of four months, we have had two massacres. I do not know what that means in terms of the society in which we live today other than that there is obviously something dreadfully wrong. I believe that of all the problems facing our society, our community and our governments there is nothing more pressing than the need to attempt to get at the reasons for these seemingly senseless and certainly dreadful acts of violence.

I believe that violence breeds violence in any community. Unless we approach these events as a matter of the greatest urgency and do so with the greatest professionalism and all the skills that we as a modern society ought to be able to bring to these issues, I really fear very seriously indeed for the future of our society. As I say, it is difficult to say much more in the absence of further information. There are many Press reports on the massacre. We will doubtless learn more of the detail. It appears to have been done by a young person, as was the Hoddle Street massacre four months ago. The person who then shot at random and killed people in Hoddle Street was approximately 20 years of age. The person who committed today's carnage was apparently a young man of 22. We do not yet know any more details about it. I just want to take this opportunity, as a Victorian and an Australian-and I am sure all members of the Parliament on both sides of the chamber will join me in this-to express our deepest sympathy and our great horror at what has happened.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that honourable senators on both sides of the chamber would share the sense of shock and horror at the massacre that has taken place. I do not have the details available to me, but I know they are as briefly outlined by Senator Short. Whilst one cannot always make allowance for the aberrations of some disturbed members of our community, nevertheless this incident brings into focus the need for a uniform approach to gun laws throughout Australia, and I believe it strengthens the case that has been made out at meetings of the Australian Police Ministers Council as recently as 12 days ago in Hobart that there ought to be a concerted effort by all jurisdictions to bring about a uniform system of licensing and granting permits for certain classes of weapons, at least as one step in trying to reduce the occasions on which lethal weapons come into the hands of persons who are really so disturbed that to put those weapons in their hands is to invite the sort of incident which tragically occurred today. In other words, it requires real political will and effort on the part of governments to achieve greater gun control. I believe it can be achieved.

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed, the Victorian experience has been that some of the more strident elements of the gun lobby, when taken on, do in fact come to realise that they do not enjoy great public support and that, when proper allowance is made for some farming, rural, recreational and sporting uses, the community is prepared to sanction tough measures to try to reduce the occasions on which these weapons come into the hands of, as I say, some disturbed members of our community. It is not a simple issue. But I agree that it was very proper of Senator Short to raise this matter in the adjournment debate so that honourable senators from all sides of the chamber could express their condolences to the families concerned and their shock that this incident should occur in our community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to join my colleagues in extending condolences to the families that have tragically lost members. I do so both as a Victorian senator and as a Melbourne City Councillor. The carnage in fact took place in my ward, the central ward. I remember only too vividly the Russell Street bombing. This was probably the time when Melbourne was first exposed to a terrorist act. I was close by at the time. As a central ward councillor then I was called upon to make comment. I said that we must now realise that, due to the Russell Street bombing, Melbourne had lost its innocence-if I can use that word, although `protection' might be a better word. I said that we had to give greater support to the law courts and to the police force-two institutions that over the years have been sorely tested and sorely criticised for wanting to strengthen their positions.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the next State election in Victoria should bring to light the law and order issue if such incidents as these are ever to be properly dealt with by governments. I also await further information on the incident. As I said before, I extend my expression of sympathy and shock at the tragedy of the incident. I recall the Russell Street bombing and how close I was to it, and I know the shock-no other word can really describe it-of such incidents.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 10.39 p.m.
